IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance Medical imaging is one of the key methods used by cancer researchers to study human biology in health and disease. The imaging informatics platform described in this application will enable cancer researchers to capture, analyze, and share imaging and related data. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age is considered the leading risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) with AD risk doubling every five years after age 65. There is a significant lack in studies that characterize in a systematic and integrative way the contribution of aging to AD development in preclinical stage. We will integrate novel quantitative markers of brain microstructure and network neuroscience and study a well-characterized sample of (older) adults in preclinical AD stage to characterize the neural markers that are vulnerable in aging and contribute to AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Replacement of healthy muscle tissue with intramuscular fat, a shared feature of sarcopenia and neuromuscular diseases such as Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy, results in loss of muscle mass and strength. The short-term goal of this project is to identify mechanisms by which fat replaces muscle, with the long-term goal of developing strategies to counter intramuscular fat infiltration and prevent the decline in muscle function.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preterm infants are at high risk for brain injuries due to alterations in brain blood flow and oxygenation, especially after the occurrence of intraventricular hemorrhage, and currently there is no reliable bedside method to monitor these functional parameters continuously in premature brains. This project will develop and test a new, noncontact, fast, high-resolution, and portable optical device, which enables immediate and continuous imaging of brain blood flow, oxygenation, metabolism, and functional connectivity in neonatal piglets and preterm infants. Compared to currently available technologies, this noninvasive, multi-parameter, functional imager will provide a more comprehensive and accurate assessment of neonatal brain health/injury, which may help optimize care for critically ill neonates and reduce harm to their brains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative (relevance): The five-year survival of patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is only 27.4%, thus there is an unmet need for more effective therapies. In order to improve the outcome of AML patients, it is important to understand the biology of leukemia stem cells (LSCs) which are capable of initiating leukemia and are resistant to treatment. This proposal seeks to understand the mechanisms through which non-leukemia cells (collectively called the microenvironment) in the bone marrow of AML patients support LSCs and to design new therapies that target these mechanisms and eliminate LSCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Proposal Title: The impact of social determinants, conditional cash transfers and primary health care on HIV/AIDS: an integrated retrospective and forecasting approach based on a cohort of 100 million Brazilians Project Narrative Despite considerable progress has been made in controlling HIV/AIDS epidemics in several countries, challenges remain in terms of scaling up successful national programs. This study will use one of the largest longitudinal dataset from the linkage of socioeconomic and health data to evaluate the effects of socioeconomic determinants, cash transfer programmes and primary care on the incidence, hospitalization, adherence to treatment and mortality from HIV/AIDS. Innovative mathematical models will be created to forecast the impact of alternative scenarios and identify the best policy options to reduce the burden of the disease. Results are expected to inform national efforts to maintain progress made in controlling HIV/AIDS in Brazil and demonstrate potential strengths and weaknesses of such programs in other countries experiencing challenges in sustaining HIV/AIDS, health care, and social protection programs, including the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposed in-vivo in-vitro project, we will develop and validate a patient-specific QCT-based computational technique to objectively estimate fracture risks associated with physical activities in the elderly. This technique can provide evidence-based recommendations for patients and clinicians on the safety of several physical activities in the short term, and will be translated into patient populations for fracture risk assessment in the long term.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: The Women’s Digit is a previously developed ratcheting prosthetic finger that is sized to fit a 5th percentile to 95th percentile female hand. With no electronics or batteries, the cost, size, and complexity are reduced all while increasing reliability and durability. The amputation of full or partial fingers can cause physical, psychosocial, and economic damage to an individual. Replacement of a finger requires a mechanical design that can withstand the forces, torques, and environmental conditions of everyday life. The challenging requirements for an effective prosthetic finger have caused an absence of products for women Veterans with smaller hand sizes. This proposal seeks to address this void through the laboratory evaluation and a clinical take-home trial of the Biomechatronics Development Laboratory’s (BDL) Women’s Digit.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Racial minorities, ethnic minorities, and individuals with low socioeconomic status (SES) are vulnerable groups that have long faced disparities in health care access and outcomes. Voluntary bundled payments could exacerbate these disparities, particularly for lower extremity joint replacement (LEJR) for osteoarthritis, congestive heart failure (CHF), and sepsis – the most prevalent procedures and conditions with existing disparities. To inform payment policy that promotes parity, this study will examine how hospitals’ and physician groups’ participation in the largest voluntary bundled payment programs impacts access and outcomes for racial minorities, ethnic minorities, and low SES individuals.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The effect of voluntary bundled payments on vulnerable populations

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RNA editing catalyzed by the ADAR enzymes is perturbed in a variety of human diseases. In addition, siRNA and miRNA-triggered RNA interference (RNAi) pathways hold promise for the development of new therapeutic RNAs. The proposed studies will extend our basic understanding of the process of RNA editing, lead to new methods for the control of RNA editing and advance approaches for the modification and optimization of therapeutic RNAs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Gene therapies are an extremely powerful array of tools for treating many diseases at their source but are limited for neurological applications by the challenge of delivering them to the brain. The technology of focused ultrasound-mediated disruption of the blood-brain barrier can facilitate delivery of normally non-penetrant agents into the brain. Here we develop and validate strategies using this technology to improve delivery of gene therapies to the brain, focusing on the specific application of delivering a micro- RNA therapy for the treatment of Huntington’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While medical cannabis has been approved in many states for the treatment of pain, the effects of medical cannabis on prescription opioid/benzodiazepine use patterns and health outcomes at the patient-level has not been fully examined to date. Additionally, adults aged ≥50 represent a population that is vulnerable to potential detrimental effects of co-using both cannabis products and opioids/benzodiazepines. This study aims to examine the impact of medical cannabis on changes in prescription opioid/benzodiazepine use and health outcomes among older adults using innovative data linkage.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE The Pediatric Injury and Violence Prevention Student Internship Training Program (INSIGHT) is an intensive, eight-week interdisciplinary and rigorous research education course in pediatric injury and violence prevention for upper-level undergraduate students. Trainees are matched to research faculty experts in pediatric trauma and injury control, and all work involves a health equity lens. Research areas include elucidating risk factors and outcomes of pediatric injury and violence, community engaged research in injury and violence prevention, acute and chronic care of injured patients, trauma outcomes, and interventions to return the injured child and adolescent to full potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Repeat expansions disorders such as Huntington’s Disease and Friedreich Ataxia are severely debilitating rare neurodegenerative disorders, for which, despite the underlying genetic mutations being known for over 20 years now, there are still no effective therapies available, suggesting that novel approaches are necessary. There is growing evidence that somatic repeat expansion is a shared hallmark across the different repeat expansion disorders and that this may contribute to disease onset and progression, supporting further investigation of repeat expansion mechanism(s) as potential therapeutic targets. This study is aimed at: 1) identification of non- invasive samples that can be used as potential biomarkers of disease; 2) development of novel methodology to better size and quantify repeat instability; 3) discovery and characterization of genetic modifiers of somatic repeat expansions, 4) development of novel therapeutics targeting the repeat expansion process as a potential universal treatment for these devastating disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pseudomonas aeruginosa, an opportunistic human pathogen that causes a variety of difficult or impossible to resolve infections, uses quorum sensing to control virulence, and quorum sensing has become a target for development of novel antimicrobials. Efforts to develop quorum-sensing inhibitors as therapeutics will rely on a better understanding of the role of quorum sensing in virulence and on a basic understanding of the selective pressures leading to quorum-sensing control of gene expression in P. aeruginosa. Studies of P. aeruginosa quorum sensing are also providing fundamental understanding of the molecular underpinnings of cooperation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Caveolins are an unusual family of membrane proteins that form small flask-shaped structures at the surface of cells. By ways that are not yet fully understood, these structures regulate normal physiological functions such as lipid storage and cardiovascular function, and when defective they can cause the development of multiple diseases including cancer, pulmonary arterial hypertension, and muscular dystrophy. We will use a combination of structural, biochemical, biophysical, cell biological, and computational approaches to investigate how caveolins function at the cellular level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older persons are more likely to suffer from chronic pain than younger people, and the prevalence of persistent pain increases with age. There is strong evidence for the decline of endogenous pain modulatory function with age. This decline may predispose older adults to an increased risk of chronic pain conditions, such as osteoarthritis (OA), a chronic pain condition that disproportionately affects the aged population, especially elderly women. In this project, we will explore brain circuits that underlie age-related changes in descending pain modulatory function and the mechanistic links between dysfunctional pain modulatory systems and chronic OA pain in the aged population. Specifically, we will examine whether enhancing the strength of specific brain circuitries mediating endogenous pain modulation, either experimentally or through exercise, can improve OA pain outcomes in aged populations. Findings of this project will stimulate progress toward the development of novel evidence-based pain treatment strategies for older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In lupus nephritis, renal tubular epithelial cell injury is a better predictor of progression to end stage kidney disease than glomerular injury. Proximal tubular epithelial cells of the kidney accumulate iron in lupus nephritis which can induce Ferroptosis, an iron dependent form of regulated cell death. We want to understand the contribution of ferroptosis in augmenting proximal tubular epithelial cells pathology in lupus nephritis and use this information to repurpose ferroptosis inhibitors as novel adjunct therapy for lupus nephritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a heterogeneous systemic condition associated with serious morbidity and premature mortality, yet treatment options are limited. There is uncertainty regarding the optimal use of the two FDA-approved lupus medications, hydroxychloroquine and belimumab, due in part to the risks of adverse treatment effects including hydroxychloroquine retinopathy and infection. This Career Development Award focuses on applying advanced clinical epidemiology and patient-centered decision science to integrate personalized risks of potential harms and benefits with patient preferences to guide the personalized, patient- centered use of key lupus medications, including specifically the optimal dose of hydroxychloroquine in SLE care.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Advanced peripheral neuroprostheses will require high-density (HD) interconnections that are enabled by our proposed research effort. These systems will contribute to the distribution of new clinical interventions for Veterans based on effective life enhancing technology to the veteran population, in whom lower extremity paralysis or weakness is common. Specifically, motor nerve dysfunction due to stroke or incomplete spinal cord injury can create debilitating conditions that affect a Veteran's ability to walk and engage in physical activity. HD stimulation and in-line connector technology for walking assistance has the potential to enhance functional independence by providing patients with a means to maneuver. Combat- related amputations have been steady, too, and new prosthetic technology for amputees can restore natural sensations in amputated limbs; our connectors help miniaturize such systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE: In this proposal, we will develop and characterizing a platform of gene engineered syngeneic immunosuppressive and active GBM therapeutic tumor cells (ThTC) and assess their therapeutic efficacy of ThTC in primary and recurrent GBM models of resection. We will also develop therapeutic patient derived human resected tumor cells (hThTC) and test them in mouse GBM models derived from primary and recurrent resected GBM patients. The developed agents and strategies will be designed to be clinically translatable and should have a major impact in translating cell based therapies for a broad spectrum of metastatic tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Younger adults with severe mental illness (SMI) seldom receive targeted, evidence-based strategies intended to prevent diabetes and related cardiovascular complications, despite heightened risk for cardiometabolic disease. Clinical Decision Support (CDS) tools are computer algorithms that use patients’ data, predictive analytics, and clinical evidence to help patients and clinicians navigate complex treatment decisions. The proposed research will create the foundations for a novel CDS tool seeking to promote cardiometabolic disease prevention care for adults with SMI under age 45 who have recently started antipsychotic medications (a diabetes risk factor) through the following activities: (1) development of diabetes risk prediction models based on > 50,000 electronic health records for individuals in this population; (2) engagement of patient, clinician, and health system leader stakeholders in designing CDS tool risk/recommendation messaging and implementation pathways; and, (3) testing the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary clinical effects of using CDS tool messaging within an existing telehealth population management program serving adults with SMI.

This project will help us improve documentation so nurses can focus more on patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Myosin 18 and its role in skeletal muscle: H. Lee Sweeney, P.I.      Relevance:  Myosin 18B  is  expressed  primarily  in striated  muscle  cells,  while the  closely  related  myosin 18A  is  found  in  all  cells,  including  muscle  cells.  These  myosins  are  thought  to  play  a  critical  role  in  the  formation  of  myosin  II  filaments  and  loss  of  myosin  18B  leads  to  myopathies  in  humans.  The  design  and  function  of  these  motor  proteins has not been elucidated and must be in order to understand how they function in muscle formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: One of the big questions in understanding the brain is why individuals are differentially resilient to stress and injury. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ABCD Study consortium uses multimodal brain imaging, cognitive and clinical assessments, bioassays, mobile monitoring, and careful assessment of substance use, environment, psychopathological symptoms, and social functioning in 11,878 9-10 year-olds to be followed over 10 years, to determine the effects of substance use on adolescent brain and cognitive development. This ABCD Research Project Site will follow and assess participants enrolled in the study. These data will be shared with the scientific community to address a comprehensive range of questions concerning youth development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A better understanding of the barriers and facilitators for colorectal cancer screening among medically underserved African Americans will assist in monitoring more effective outreach efforts and impacting colorectal cancer disparities in groups suffering the greatest burden of the disease, thereby improving public health. The proposed study will monitor colorectal cancer screening among a cohort of African American patients in community health centers and leverage community-engaged research to study colorectal cancer screening adherence among African Americans with a goal to increase stool-based screening rates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gliomas account for 80% of all malignant brain and central nervous system tumors, and are responsible for an estimated 200,000 deaths worldwide and ~15,000 deaths in the United States annually. Standard of care for glioma has not changed in over 15 years. This application proposes the analysis of precise mechanisms that drive gliomagenesis using novel genetically engineered mouse models and to discover functional targets of IDH mutations, potentially assisting in the development of new therapies to combat this deadly cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Lay Summary: Heart attack and stroke remain the leading causes of death for men and women worldwide. Clinical observations link the hormone aldosterone with increased risk of heart attack and stroke and the hormone estrogen with protection from heart attack and stroke. Aldosterone action is increased in obesity and aging, the two fastest growing demographics in the USA. This proposal uses innovative approaches to understand how these two hormones interact with one another within blood vessels and in the immune system to contribute to heart disease. The results will help identify new ways to prevent heart attack and stroke in sex-specific ways in the rapidly growing aging and obese populations in which heart disease risk is very high.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative There is a persistent scarcity of physicians and diverse clinical researchers engaged in the addiction research workforce, as reflected in the low numbers of NIDA research project awardees with an MD (15% in 2020) and even fewer awardees from underrepresented racial/ethnic minority (URM) populations (less than 4%). Research training programs, such as the Diversity in Addiction Research Training (DART) program (DA020537-16; formerly the Drug Abuse Research Training program), for which this application seeks renewal, will increase the number of URM investigators by involving more URM trainees in the research training pipeline earlier in their education. Greater diversity cultivates robust learning environments, fosters creativity and innovation, and promotes culturally competent care, all of which will help reduce racial/ethnic health disparities in addiction and associated mental health conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project involves the preparation and study of proteins containing non-proteinogenic amino acids, using selected modified bacterial ribosomes to enable the incorporation of amino acids not incorporated readily by wild-type ribosomes. Two of the initiatives involve the preparation and study of proteins containing specific sites of phosphorylation or glycosylation; phosphorylated proteins include Iκ-Bα and NF-κB, while the glycosylated protein to be studied is murine interferon-β. Additionally, we will prepare proteins containing nucleobase amino acids, enabling the design of proteins able to interact in a predictable, modified fashion with their normal nucleic acid targets; proteins to be studied include transcriptional regulator Rob, and Zn finger protein Zif268.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) is an age-related risk factor for inflammation and fibrosis, which are important contributors to chronic kidney disease (CKD) progression. The proposed investigation will examine associations of CHIP with kidney disease progression in large cohorts of individuals with kidney disease and in well-established animal models of kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Self-healing dental materials have the capability of autonomically repairing damage that may occur when the restoration is subjected to, for example, excessive masticatory forces. This study proposes the synthesis of tougher healing agents, which will be able to bring this technology closer to translation to real-life uses. These modifications will prevent resin composite weakening by the addition of surface-functionalized microcapsules and turn self-healing dental materials into a feasible strategy by the introduction of coaxial electrohydrodynamic atomization, as advanced method for capsules synthesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the risks conferred by SES-related stress, most low-income, rural children will not develop drug use problems—a phenomenon known as resilience. However, little is known regarding the influence of contextual protective factors in the indirect link between childhood adversity and drug use vulnerability among rural children. Thus, we propose to investigate the protective effects of rural context on neural risk processes associated with drug use vulnerability versus resilience among rural children (ages 7-10 years) to better inform the design and implementation of substance use prevention programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative New therapeutics are desperately needed for the treatment of diseases with unmet needs, such as infectious and immunological diseases. This proposal uses an ecology-driven approach to discover new drugs from the microbiome of marine egg masses, which have ecological pressures that are predicted to have driven the evolution of novel antibiotics and immunomodulating agents. Chemical investigations into egg mass symbionts will lead to the discovery of novel chemistry and has the potential to repopulate the drug pipeline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our previous work shows that restoring the balance between regulatory T cells and other immune cells can effectively reverse chronic migraine-related behavioral and cellular sensitizations in mice. In this application, we propose to test the hypothesis that neuro-immune interactions contribute to the chronification and resolution of migraine headache through regulating the activity of primary afferent neurons in the trigeminovascular pathway. This will elucidate the mechanisms underlying migraine chronification and help developing new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The synaptic plasticity and memory hypothesis asserts that memory is stored by learning-induced functional modifications at a subset of the synapses of the neurons that are activated to encode the learning experience. We will critically test the hypothesis by tracing which synaptic populations persistently strengthen after formation of a specific place memory, by optogenetically activating and recording the discharge of a subset of the hippocampal neurons that encode the memory after control and inhibiting manipulations of the molecular tracer, which is the currently best validated molecular mechanism that is demonstrated to be necessary for persistent synaptic plasticity and long-term memory storage in these neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project seeks to advance public health by improving the very poor survival rate of patients with prostate cancer (PCa) due to the presence of metastases and no available curative therapies. Our research will identify alterations causing PCa to spread to other tissues by tracking the metastatic clones as they develop using our new model system, EvoCaP, both in the presence and absence of standard therapy. By identifying genes and pathways that cause PCa to spread and colonize different organs, our project is designed to ﬁnd new, vital drug targets previously missed by traditional methods of identiﬁcation, to treat advanced forms of metastatic PCa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is widely accepted that long-term intake of ultra-processed foods has detrimental effects on host intestinal health; however, the underlying mechanisms by which processed ingredient diet escalates susceptibility to intestinal inflammation are ill-defined, thus preventing us from devising a dietary-based intervention(s) to reduce the onset and occurrence of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Our preliminary observation demonstrates that the processed ingredient diet (chiefly comprised of refined starch, sugar, and fat but lacking in whole grain contents) increases the propensity to develop IBD by impairing the host mucosal immune responses against invading (opportunistic) microorganisms in the gut. This proposal seeks to further investigate this exciting novel observation, address the potential underlying mechanisms, and identify processed diet-linked microbial metabolites that escalate susceptibility to IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative An oncogenic kinase, ACK1, phosphorylates the ATP synthase alpha-subunit, preventing binding of its physiological inhibitor, IF1, enhancing ATP synthesis in cancer cells. This `resourceful’ version of oxidative phosphorylation employed by cancer cell wherein phospho-ATP5F1a directs undiminished ATP synthesis likely to support progression of prostate cancer to malignant stage. Treatment of cancer cells with (R)-9b promoted IF1 binding, leading to significant reduction in ATP levels and initiated a distinct mitophagic response, uncovering a new category of tyrosine kinase inhibitor targeting mitochondrial metabolism specifically in cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Adenylyl cyclase, the focus of the proposed study, modulates cyclic AMP, a molecule that is vital to modulating many pathways throughout human physiology. Significant pathological consequences, including cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, neuropsychiatric disorders, diabetes, heart disease, and drug abuse result from aberrant signaling of cyclic AMP. Thus, adenylyl cyclases hold great potential as therapeutic targets in disease, but our current understanding of the basic biology of these enzymes is lacking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with gastrointestinal (GI) cancers that metastasize to the peritoneal cavity suffer high morbidity and mortality and have few effective treatment options. Mutations in the GNAS gene are associated with higher rates of peritoneal metastasis, as well as decreased responses to chemotherapy in many GI cancers. The study will investigate the impact of GNAS mutations on tumor molecular signaling cascades and tumor progression, improve fundamental knowledge of tumor peritoneal metastasis, and evaluate GNAS inhibition as a new promising treatment strategy for the large number of patients with metastatic GI cancers.

PHR: Project Narrative Neurodegenerative disorders, including Huntington's disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, represent a major class of diseases with unmet medical needs. Therapeutic oligonucleotides are promising sequence- specific drugs for the treatment of genetically defined neurodegenerative disorders, but their use is limited by the lack of safe and effective delivery methods, especially for the brain. The goal of this proposal is to develop novel oligonucleotide chemistry platforms to inhibit toxic gene expression in the brain and spinal cord.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Difficulties in employment and postsecondary education among young adults with autism spectrum disorder are nearly universal, with challenges both in obtaining and maintaining these positions. Yet, almost nothing is known about the factors that promote postsecondary employment/educational stability, resulting in a dearth of evidence-based interventions and programs to support sustained participation. The proposed research will have high public health impact by providing new knowledge that can be rapidly translated into novel interventions to support young adults with autism spectrum disorder in maintaining employment/educational positions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tetracycline antibiotics (i.e., minocycline, doxycycline) are a common systemic treatment for acne during adolescence, a critical developmental phase during which the skeleton accrues substantial bone mass. The proposed research will discern how tetracyclines modify gut bacteria to affect skeletal maturation, bone health, and fracture risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this application is to improve the durability of pediatric medical devices made of implantable biomaterials thus reducing the need for multiple cardiac re-operations in children. Our lab discovered that the permanent incorporation of circulating proteins via glycation can impair the structure of the biomaterials and favor the absorption of calcium-binding proteins. Since glycation and calcification precursors are overexpressed in children, we believe that our strategies to mitigate protein absorption will be particularly efficient in pediatric patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Primary hyperparathyroidism is caused by a parathyroid single adenoma in almost 90% of cases and is usually cured surgically. Although preoperative localization such as sestamibi SPECT/CT and intraoperative PTH blood tests have greatly improved surgical therapy of primary hyperparathyroidism in patients, there is still no capability for real-time, intraoperative navigation to localize parathyroid glands during surgery. Furthermore, it is imperative that surgeons identify and preserve normal parathyroid glands during thyroid surgery to avoid postoperative hypocalcemia, where invisible near-infrared fluorescent light can provide sensitive and specific guidance during surgery, but only if optimal contrast agents are available.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple approaches have been investigated to reduce the substantial care and cost burden of treating infants with neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome (NOWS) postnatally, including through dyadic approaches such as the Eat, Sleep, Console (ESC) protocol that encourages mothers to instinctively care for their newborns during the birth hospitalization. Far less attention has been paid to understanding the clinical needs and subsequent trajectory of care for infants with NOWS during the remainder of their first year of life—including the risks and costs of hospital readmissions and how best to support mothers with OUD in keeping their infants safe during a time when both mother and child are especially vulnerable. This proposal addresses the challenges and costs of caring for infants with NOWS once they leave the hospital and are in the care of their parents, social workers, and community healthcare providers with two studies that shift the focus from the immediate post-partum period to the first year of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative: mRNA 3’ processing is an essential step in eukaryotic gene expression and alternative polyadenylation is an important mechanism for gene regulation. In this proposal, we will characterize the structure-function relationship of the mRNA 3’ processing complex and the mechanisms by which RNA-binding proteins and post-translational modifications of the core mRNA 3’ processing factors regulate alternative polyadenylation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Prostate cancer is the most commonly diagnosed non-skin cancer in men, and the second most common cause of cancer death for men: it is a high-incidence, high-fatality, high-morbidity and high- cost cancer that is growing increasingly frequent in our aging population. We hypothesize that the clinical and molecular evolution of localized prostate cancers are shaped by germline genomic features and present strong preliminary data to support this concept. This proposal with quantify the contribution of germline to prostate cancer evolution through TWAS, ancestry studies and large cohort generalization studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative People with or being evaluated for the diagnosis of diabetes and their providers usually take for granted that their hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) result faithfully reflects their blood sugar control because the amount of sugar on hemoglobin is determined by how much sugar it has been exposed to over its life time. However, new devices that can routinely measure blood sugar continuously for weeks with low cost and convenience confirm that in as great as 1 out of 3 people there is a significant mismatch between HbA1c and the blood sugar directly measured by the devices. Therefore, the purpose of this proposal is to demonstrate that these mismatches are primarily due to variation in the lifespan of the red blood cell, the cell in the blood in which Hemoglobin is located; this will personalize HbA1c allowing it to complement the new devices and be a better measure of blood sugar control improving the care of millions of people with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In order to survive, organisms need to respond and adapt to stress signals from the environment. Our work focuses on both a general stress response, which confers broad cross-protection to multiple stressors, and specific stress responses elicited by DNA damage. Both of these stress responses have relevance for molecular evolution and the development of novel antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative It is critically important to promote interest and motivation for underrepresented minority and first-generation students in introductory biology and chemistry courses, which act as a gateway to successive courses and biomedical careers. Increasing the pool of talent for doctorates in the biomedical sciences is crucial, for these are the persons who will pioneer essential advances to improve the health of the U.S. population. I propose a set of large-scale, multi-institutional field experiments, with long-term follow-up of students, to test a utility-value intervention intended to help promote motivation and performance for underrepresented minority and first-generation students in biology and chemistry classes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Glaucoma is the leading cause of irreversible blindness in the world, which is projected to affect ~6.3 million Americans by 2050, and intraocular pressure (IOP) is a leading contributor to glaucoma. The project addresses the major limitations of current glaucoma therapy by advancing a sustained-release IOP- lowering formulation that coordinates multiple targets to normalize IOP, and possibly protect retinal ganglion cells. Minimum performance metrics for the novel formulation will position researchers to move toward clinical trials and eventually to commercialization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: We are in the midst of a growing epidemic of obesity, insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes. There are few sustainable prevention strategies and not enough fully effective treatments for these serious disorders. Major gaps exist in our knowledge of the molecular mechanisms underlying insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes, limiting our ability to develop highly effective and safe therapies. Attention has focused on understanding the problems with glucose or lipid metabolism separately but the mechanistic links between these pathways are poorly understood. We recently discovered a new class of lipids that have beneficial metabolic and anti-inflammatory effects. The levels of these lipids are low in people who are at risk for, or have, type 2 diabetes. Studies in this proposal will determine how levels of these beneficial lipids are regulated in normal physiologic states and in obesity and diabetes. Understanding the mechanisms regulating these lipids could provide new insights into the pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes and new treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Working parents of children with mental health disabilities (MHD) experience chronic stress linked to unique contextual factors that lead them to not disclose their child's health status because of fear of discrimination, retaliation and job loss. Uncertainty regarding the outcome of disclosure can create decisional conflict regarding whether, when, what, and how much to disclose of their child's MHD to employers when seeking workplace support to manage disability-related care demands, which in turn contributes to increased risk of stress related illnesses. Activities proposed in this project seek to mitigate decisional conflict and reduce stress related to disclosing their child's health status at work by developing and testing a web-based decision aid providing structured feedback on whether, what and when to disclose their disability-related care demands to their supervisor based on knowledge of risks, benefits and priority-setting activities that provides individualized feedback on disclosure preferences, and resources supporting the highest ranked priority.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: My Choice: Developing a Workplace Disclosure Decision Aid and Resources for Working Parents of Children with Mental Health Disabilities
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Liquid-phase separated biomolecular condensates spatially organize RNA regulation into p- bodies and stress granules in eukaryotes. Here we investigate if simple bacteria cells that lack organelles, exploit liquid phase separation to organize and regulate mRNA decay in a manner similar to p-bodies and stress granules. We anticipate these studies will reveal new broad layers of bacterial gene regulation that impact cellular processes such as virulence and could be targeted for antibiotic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Fewer than half of all children with high-risk neuroblastoma become long-term survivors. The goal of this project is to develop biomarkers to improve risk stratification at diagnosis, biomarkers of minimal residual disease for early therapy intervention, and the identification of gene networks which drive high-risk neuroblastoma. This work will have a transformative impact by identifying new ways to diagnose and monitor neuroblastoma using liquid biopsies, potentially enabling early introduction of novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will create a coordinating center to deliver mentoring and research experiences in STEM for high school students from groups historically excluded in the sciences (e.g., ethnic and gender minorities, rural students, economically disadvantaged) across Department of Health & Human Services Region A. Mentors from across the region will be trained and equipped by the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory DNA Learning Center to bring advanced genomics into a summer research and school year mentoring program. Ultimately, a sustainable network of mentors and students will create new, inclusive opportunities that diversify the nation’s STEM workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ABCD Study consortium uses multimodal brain imaging, cognitive and clinical assessments, bioassays, mobile monitoring, and careful assessment of substance use, environment, psychopathological symptoms, and social functioning in 11,878 9-10 year-olds to be followed over 10 years, with 607 followed at University of Maryland Baltimore (UMB), to determine the effects of substance use on adolescent brain and cognitive development. This ABCD Research Project Site will follow and assess participants enrolled in the study. These data will be shared with the scientific community to address a comprehensive range of questions concerning youth development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research will examine recently discovered RNA modifications and molecular mechanisms that govern the lifetime of messenger RNA in bacterial cells. The knowledge thereby acquired is expected to be of value in understanding the regulatory processes that control bacterial pathogenesis and antibiotic sensitivity. Because of their broad applicability, the concepts and methods developed in the course of these studies have the potential to accelerate progress toward elucidating the mechanisms by which messenger RNA degradation impacts not only microbial infection but also human cell physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Mitochondrial iron uptake and consequent stimulation of reactive oxygen species formation contributes to hepatotoxicity. The proposed study will elucidate the molecular pathways of mitochondrial iron uptake and  exchange, specifically the role of mitoferrin and its possible interaction with the mitochondrial calcium uniporter complex. These studies will fill an important gap in our understanding of iron-dependent hepatotoxicity, and the knowledge gained should lead to new therapies for hepatic diseases associated with iron overload.

PHR: Project Relevance The overarching goal of this proposal is to improve our understanding of how tissue injury occurs in patients with disorders termed ‘porphyrias’ that encompass eight genetic and several acquired diseases caused by abnormal accumulation of natural pigment byproducts. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Out of all daily experiences, salient ones are likeliest to leave long-lasting memories, yet the neural mechanisms underlying the preferential transformation of salient experiences into long- term memories are poorly understood. Dopaminergic neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA-DA) are critically involved in online salience coding, yet their role in offline consolidation of these experiences into long-term memory is considerably less understood. The proposed research will address this knowledge gap utilizing optical and electrophysiological recordings of neural activity and closed-loop manipulations of specific neural circuits in freely behaving, learning and sleeping mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Personalized, adaptive, brain stimulation has the potential to benefit disabling behavioral symptoms such as apathy and impulsivity across a wide range of neurological conditions, including Parkinson’s disease, but is currently limited by a lack of understanding of how the brain assesses rewards to drive actions. The goal of this project is to determine how rewards are evaluated across the frontal cortex - basal ganglia circuits and to evaluate the mechanistic role of the structures and signals of this network in Parkinson’s disease. This foundational understanding will direct future stimulation therapies to reduce the burden of apathy and impulsivity in Parkinson’s disease and other neurological disorders in a precise and principled manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to investigate differences in disease phenotype and disease progression in a larger cohort of subjects with sporadic inclusion body myositis subjects, including muscle pathology, and to examine if a set of blood and skeletal muscle-based biomarkers influence the disease behavior. These biomarkers include antibodies to the NT5c1A antigen as well as variant T-lymphocyte population in blood and muscle. Furthermore, we would like to continue to examine the distribution of Kv1.3 potassium channels in blood and muscles to see if it can potentially be targeted by pharmacological agents. Knowledge of this will help us design more effective and efficient clinical trials in IBM using newer generation immunosuppressive agents. Upon completion of these aims, we will 1) understand the disease phenotype, including pattern of respiratory involvement, and disease progression in sIBM better and understand the influence of serum antibodies to NT5c1A antibodies on the natural history and disease behavior; 2) define differences in serum variant T-cells and cytokine signatures in sIBM patients and their influence on disease progression and behavior; and 3) understand muscle pathology and immune cell distribution in sIBM patients and its relationship to NT5c1A antibodies. These findings may influence future trial design in sIBM. Finally, we will have created a thirteen-site consortium of myositis treatment centers that will be ready to adopt quickly any future clinical trials aimed at changing the course of sIBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular toxicity presents a significant problem for cancer therapy, as the adverse effects often interfere with the treatments and compromise patients' long-term survival. This proposal will interrogate the interplay between genetic variants in the etiology of doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity by employing the iPSC-CM “cell village” platform coupled with engineered heart tissue, scRNA-seq, scATAC-seq, and CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing technologies. The knowledge we collect here with the “cell village” model should be instrumental in interrogating interindividual susceptibility at a large-scale and high throughput fashion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative: ASCVD progresses with aging and causes one-third of deaths worldwide. The protection in females against ASCVD is lost in postmenopausal women and has not been replicated in clinical trials, in part because the mechanisms are not completely understood. By using animal models of surgical menopause and hormone therapy overlayed with bone marrow transplant techniques, this project will define a novel mechanism to provide a platform for developing therapeutic methods to replicate the protection of sex hormones against ASCVD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will generate a human RNA structure-omics signature using bioinformatics and cheminformatics tools to determine and validate RNA targets for small molecule drug design. These studies will expand the druggable human genome by delivering a comprehensive map of targetable RNA structures and determine an efficient path to annotate the transcriptome in disease-associated pathways. These approaches will broadly enable the design of precision medicines and chemical probes for RNA targets previously thought to be “undruggable”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Public Health Statement Traumatic brain injury (TBI) remains a public health concern, the consequences of which can lead to long-lasting disability and cognitive dysfunction. Unfortunately, the neural mechanism underlying memory dysfunction in the chronic stage of injury and effective strategies to improve learning and memory are not available. The present proposal will investigate if stimulation of hippocampal neuron and/or administration of specific drugs can be used to improve hippocampal place cell function and memory after TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Deficits in olfaction are long-established symptoms of Alzheimer’s Disease whose potential to reveal mechanisms leading to this disease has yet to be realized. Recent evidence that the olfactory epithelium and its olfactory sensory neurons are vulnerable to genetic variants linked to Alzheimer’s Disease open opportunities to investigate early effects leading to neurodegeneration in a neural tissue that is easily accessible, including via biopsy in humans. This project investigates the effects of human apoliproprotein E alleles on the olfactory epithelium and its neurons in mouse models, including whether switching expression from a neurodegenerative allele to a neuroprotective allele prevents and reverses effects linked to Alzheimer’s Disease.

PHR: Project Narrative Periodontal disease affects 42% of adult Americans, yet there are no effective adjunctive treatment options following traditional non-surgical or surgical intervention. The research outlined in this proposal will identify major epigenetic mechanisms engaged in periodontal disease progression and target these processes for the design of novel chemical probes and therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Healthcare provider (such as dialysis facilities and transplant centers) profiling is of nationwide importance. The statistical analysis along with further reviews may lead to changes in budgeting allocations and even suspension for providers with extremely poor outcomes. Existing profiling approaches typically assume that the risk adjustment is perfect, and the between-provider variation is entirely due to the quality of care, which, however, is often invalid. In addition, analyzing large-scale databases introduces computational difficulties, particularly when the event of interest is recurrent, and the numbers of sample size and the dimension of parameters are large. How to integrate streaming recurrent event data adds another level of difficulty. In view of these difficulties. Finally, the COVID-19 pandemic has dramatically changed how healthcare care is delivered. It is crucial that the profiling methods account for temporal and geospatial variation and accurately evaluate providers’ performance during the pandemic. Our proposed methods address these statistical challenges and, in broader applications, will advance the development of quality control procedures and support better-informed healthcare policy decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDA) is a lethal disease with a low survival rate and limited treatment options. Pilot studies reveal that the tumor suppressive activities of type 1 interferon (IFN1) cytokines against development and progression of PDA are undermined by pancreatic inflammation, which downregulates the IFN1 receptor IFNAR1 and also disarms pathway effectors downstream of IFNAR1. Studies proposed here will determine the importance of the IFN1-IFNAR1 pathway in PDA, delineate the mechanisms of inactivation of this pathway during PDA development and progression and potentially pave the road to novel therapies aimed to re- activate downstream targets of IFNAR1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative People infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV-1) can successfully control their infection with current antiretroviral therapies, but roughly half of treated patients present with a range of cognitive impairments referred to as HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder (HAND). Researchers have long studied the underlying bases of this disorder using animal and cellular model systems, which have provided important insights into the underlying pathology but have not yet led to an effective therapy for patients. Since these models may incompletely reflect the disease in humans, this project proposes to develop a human brain slice culture of HIV infection and antiretroviral treatment, which will better reflect today’s adult human patients and provide a platform to study the mechanisms leading to HAND and novel therapeutic approaches.

PHR: Relevance to Public Health:  At the core of chemistry lies the power to manipulate the elements for the preparation of specific arrays of atoms in a predictable and reliable fashion. As synthetic chemists, our ability to construct molecules with exquisite precision is unique within the sciences. In this proposal, we outline broad approaches toward the construction of important linkages and describe the implemention of these methods in highly complex situations relevant to human medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to interparental conflict is a leading risk factor for children who experience parental divorce and research suggests that children’s effective coping is a malleable protective mechanism to prevent mental health problems for these children. However, no existing evidence-based prevention programs have been shown to be effective in helping children cope with the uncontrollable stressor of interparental conflict following divorce. The proposed project will use user-centered design strategies to inform the development of intervention components designed to improve children’s effective coping to reduce mental health problems in children from high conflict divorced families and then a factorial optimization trial to assess effects of the coping intervention components.

PHR: Stroke is the leading cause of adult disability in the United States; aphasia, an impairment of the ability to process language, is one of the most devastating results of left hemisphere stroke. ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Public Health Statement Triple-negative breast cancer is an aggressive form of breast cancer with limited treatment strategies. We propose to study in depth mechanism of action of tumor-suppressive role of UBR7, a novel H2B ubiquitin ligase, in triple-negative breast cancer as well as identify potential therapeutic vulnerabilities imparted by its loss. Our work is expected to provide critical insights into the role of a new histone modifier in triple negative breast cancer, which could provide biological insights into role of epigenome in this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) infects more than half the adult population of the United States and remains the most common cause of viral encephalitis and infectious blindness, yet the pathogenesis of these most severe manifestations remain unclear. We have identified leucine-rich repeat kinase 2 (LRRK2) as a novel pathogenic determinant of severe HSV-1 infection. We propose to determine how LRRK2 and the common LRRK2 mutation, G2019S, alter the innate immune response to HSV-1, expanding our understanding of severe herpesvirus pathology and finding novel therapeutic opportunities to ameliorate the most morbid outcomes caused by this ubiquitous virus.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: The Hopkins Population Center (HPC) supports the production of innovative, impactful research on the relationship of population dynamics to population health. HPC research supports the priorities of the Population Dynamics Branch of NICHD, especially focusing on reproductive health and maternal, child and family health and the consequences of poverty and inequality on population health and well-being. The HPC contributes to the development of public health interventions with population impact by supporting research into multi-level social determinants of health, and disseminates its findings broadly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute myeloid leukemia is a major form of the blood cancer with very few targeted therapies. Over 50% of patients, who responded to initial chemotherapies, relapsed within five years and die from this disease. The aim of this application is to provide molecular insights into acute myeloid leukemia for better development of novel and effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Caribbean Hispanics are a population with a disproportionately high prevalence of cardio-metabolic disorders but with a limited expectation of benefits from current pharmacogenetic studies conducted mainly in subjects of mostly European ancestry. We focus on gene-drug interactions (GDDIs) to estimate the modifying effect of cilostazol on the weighted genetic risk score (wGRS)-driven prediction model for clopidogrel responsiveness and hence develop urgently-needed pharmacogenomic-driven prescription guidelines for this population while also using a semi-mechanistic population-based PK-PD analysis of such GDDI. Our project combines machine learning techniques (i.e., artificial intelligence), a pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics modeling approach, active metabolites measurements and genotyping with the development of more accurate rules for better predictability of GDDIs between clopidogrel and cilostazol in cardiovascular patients from this medically underserved population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: More than 80% of patients undergoing treatment for head and neck cancer are prescribed opioid pain killers for management of radiation-associated pain, and unfortunately, 6 months after finishing radiotherapy, one-third of head and neck cancer patients will still be opioid-dependent. Chronic opioid use is associated with side effects such as constipation and decreased alertness; it can also lead to opioid abuse, misuse, addiction, and eventual overdose. Safer, more effective and less addictive pain relief strategies are desperately needed, and our proposed research addresses that need by investigating a novel radiation-activated pain signaling pathway that might serve as an excellent target that could be inhibited with new pain medications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) has shown efficacy in reducing symptoms and rates of mood relapse in adolescents at high risk for severe mood disorders (SMD; i.e., bipolar I/II disorder and recurrent or unremitting major depression), a significant limitation to the CBT’s efficacy is the low rate of participant adherence to the prescribed between-session homework tasks. Mobile health applications have the potential to improve adherence to and acceptance of treatment through embedded treatment content, skill-practice, thought and symptom monitoring, all of which are facilitated by reward contingencies and notifications. This study will examine whether a mobile application-enhanced CBT can improve participant adherence and treatment acceptance for adolescents at high risk for SMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: This research will contribute to determining if taking daily escitalopram (a medication that is approved by the FDA for treatment of depression and anxiety) boosts language therapy in helping people recover from language impairment (aphasia) after stroke, independently of its effects on depression. Aphasia has an important impact on the interpersonal relationships of stroke survivors and their re-entry into work and social settings. This research will lay the groundwork for designing a Phase III clinical trial language therapy plus escitalopram (compared to placebo) for aphasia early after stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: High-risk human papillomavirus infections cause cervical cancer and other genital and oropharyngeal cancers that account for nearly 5% of cancers worldwide. HPV-positive cancers are poorly differentiated and restoring differentiation in a cancer caused by HPV infection has high therapeutic potential. The goal of this proposal is to understand how the high-risk HPV E7 oncoprotein inhibits epithelial differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myocardial infarction is one of the most common cardiac injuries worldwide and routinely leads to heart failure. In a myocardial infarction, part of the heart is deprived of oxygen, but the mechanisms of how oxygen deprivation causes changes in cardiac function are poorly understood. The goal of this project is to engineer innovative cell culture devices to determine how oxygen deprivation changes the function of cells in the heart, which can lead to new therapeutic strategies for mitigating the effects of a myocardial infarction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the third most common and second deadliest cancer globally and has no effective treatment options for late-stage disease. Immunotherapies, such as anti-PD-1 therapy, target T cells to increase antitumor immunity and show a high response rate in a small subset of patients. This study aims to understand the non-coding RNA regulation of T cell biology in immunotherapy-responsive patients, and improve outcomes in treatment-resistant CRC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ABCD Study consortium uses multimodal brain imaging, cognitive and clinical assessments, bioassays, mobile monitoring, and careful assessment of substance use, environment, psychopathological symptoms, and social functioning in 11,878 9-10 year-olds to be followed over 10 years, to determine the effects of substance use on adolescent brain and cognitive development. This ABCD Research Project Site will follow and assess participants enrolled in the study. These data will be shared with the scientific community to address a comprehensive range of questions concerning youth development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The South Carolina Clinical and Translational Research Institute (SCTR)! has transformed the research environment across South Carolina by creating a Learning Health System characterized by strong training and infrastructure resources that stimulate collaboration and innovation as a means to accelerate the translation of biomedical research discoveries into human health improvements. A major focus of this application is to strengthen SCTR’s statewide collaborations through innovative partnerships and initiatives with an emphasis on rural and medically underserved communities where significant health disparities exist. We will develop, demonstrate and disseminate innovative ways to train a diverse workforce and address barriers to translational research, and we will continue to collaborate across the CTSA Consortium to maximize impact and improve the health of the nation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias are more likely to be hospitalized and are at risk for medication and health problems after discharge, potentially worsened by new use of medications that affect cognition. This study will examine the effectiveness of two Medicare programs that provide medication reviews to reduce inappropriate medication use and adverse outcomes for older adults with dementia after hospitalization. This research will generate evidence to motivate health policy changes to improve the safe use of medications in older adults with dementia, a matter of national public health relevance and aligned with the mission of the National Institute on Aging (NIA).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Asthma disproportionately affects children in urban communities in the United States and imposes a great personal and health care burden. Despite treatment advances, a significant proportion of patients do not achieve disease control and continue to have high levels of morbidity and currently no intervention has proven to either prevent or cure this disease. By identifying and addressing these unmet needs in this application, we propose to improve current asthma care in urban children, pursue disease modification, and ultimately develop effective strategies to prevent asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: Narrative Lung cancer, primarily caused by cigarette smoking, is the leading cause of cancer death in the U.S., and lung cancer mortality is far higher among those of lower socioeconomic status than their higher SES counterparts. Offering small escalating financial incentives for smoking abstinence dramatically increases cessation rates among socioeconomically disadvantaged adults when incentives are included as an adjunct to clinic-based smoking cessation treatment. The primary purpose of the proposed project is to evaluate the efficacy and cost- effectiveness of an automated, smartphone-based approach to incentivizing smoking cessation, which is a critical step towards the widespread dissemination of CM treatment with the ultimate goal of reducing tobacco- related cancers and cancer disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Respiratory viruses are an important cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The early innate immune response to viral infections needs to be finely tuned in order to generate just enough protective immunity, without causing too much inflammation and lung injury. In this proposal, we will investigate a new aspect of the early innate immune response to respiratory viruses, that we hope will shed some light on this balancing act of the immune system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many human diseases, from cancer to diabetes, can be caused by the misregulation of genes due to mutations in the DNA binding sites for key transcription factors. This project aims to understand at a high-resolution, mechanistic level, how transcription factors recognize these binding sites. Particular attention is paid to transcription factors that are members of large DNA binding families, such as homeodomain proteins, that have very similar DNA binding specificities on their own, yet carry out distinct functions in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative The brain arteriovenous malformation (bAVM) associated intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) accounts for 25% of total hemorrhagic stroke in young patients and resulted in severe long-term disability and death. Currently, there is no non-invasive and safe therapy due to a lack of understanding of the ICH mechanism in bAVM. We will explore the role of microglia/macrophages in bAVM associated ICH and provide the preclinical efficacy of microglia/macrophages modulation to improve bAVM patient’s life quality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity is associated with increased risk for chronic diseases and mortality. Binge eating and binge eating disorder are characterized by self-regulation problems and are strongly related to excess weight; thus, binge eating represents an important modifiable behavior to target in obesity prevention and intervention efforts. The proposed project will use a multimethod approach to examine affect, attention bias towards food, and impulsivity in a sample of adults at risk for obesity, with the goal of elucidating how self-regulatory processes predict momentary binge eating and short-term weight change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – DIRECTORS OVERVIEW The O'Neal Comprehensive Cancer Center is committed to reducing the cancer burdens and cancer disparities in the State of Alabama. This is done through a basic science and population science strategic research plan that is developed with community engagement and focused on elucidating the risk factors and mechanistic underpinnings of these cancer burdens and cancer disparities. The results of this work are then translated through diagnostic and therapeutic clinical trials to impact cancer outcomes and behavioral interventions to mitigate cancer risks and improve the quality of life of cancer survivors in our catchment area.

PHR: Endometriosis is a poorly understood painful condition that incapacitates and affects the productivity and well-being of millions of women around the world. Symptoms of this disease are considered significant sources of stress occurring throughout the reproductive life of these patients. This study will reveal novel therapeutic approaches for patients with endometriosis by creating a new area of investigation for better treatments that could improve women’s health.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Most of the 500,000 patients in this country on hemodialysis use an arteriovenous fistula (AVF) as their vascular access. These “lifelines”, however, have a 50% failure rate at 6 months due to an ingrowth of cells. Our goal is to understand more about this ingrowth so that we can save our patients’ “lifeline”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Repetitive alcohol use, escalated intake, and relapse are hallmark pathologies of alcohol use disorders (AUD). In this preclinical project, we are focused on evaluating TARP γ-8, a novel target in the brain that controls alcohol- seeking behavior. We are taking a multidisciplinary approach that involves genetic, behavioral, pharmacological, molecular, and physiological techniques to fully characterize TARP γ-8 regulation of alcohol use, escalated intake, and relapse in mouse behavioral models. Successful completion of the proposed studies has potential to lead to new therapeutic strategies for treating behavioral pathologies associated with AUD.

PHR: Mucosal inflammatory diseases, such as Inflammatory Bowel Diseases (IBD), result in significant shifts in tissure metabolism that represent potential therapeutic targets. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Mutations in proteins that regulate cutting and rejoining of RNA (called RNA splicing) are common in many cancers, but the mechanism by which they cause cancer are unclear. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is critical to understanding the long-term trajectory of COVID-19 and risk of neuropsychiatric disorders in late life. When considering the already existing public health crises of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias and mental health conditions in adults aged 65 years and older, the degree to which COVID-19 may add to these crises is deeply concerning. Findings from the proposed project will inform intervention and prevention strategies for risk of age-related neurological complications and neurodegeneration and long-term management of these disorders in older adults with a history of COVID-19.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than half a million pregnant women each year have untreated sleep apnea, and it is not known whether this impacts her child’s brain development or function. In rats, we modeled the repeated episodes of low oxygen that a pregnant woman with sleep apnea would experience, and found that the male offspring’s developing brain is permanently altered, creating behavioral deficits and a constellation of learning and memory impairments reminiscent of autism spectrum disorder in humans. The studies proposed here will identify and manipulate maternal factors that may contribute to this neuropsychiatric pathology in order to identify novel therapeutic targets to prevent or reverse these adverse outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRITIVE  As a D-ARC, the Center for HIV and Research in Mental Health (CHARM) successfully re-ignited and dramatically grew high-impact meaningfully community-engaged research efforts and infrastructure at the University of Miami, located in a region of the U.S. that is one of the hardest hit geographic areas affected by the HIV/AIDS epidemic. Transitioning to a Full-ARC after successfully meeting D-ARC goals will capitalize on our trajectory, facilitating continued growth of multidisciplinary research addressing HIV-related mental health disparities and the impact of these disparities on the HIV care and prevention continua.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Studying how cancer develops in animal models allows us to better understand human cancer and find new treatments. The proposed project is focused on the developing new tools that will allow researchers to turn on cancer signals by activating a light source implanted into mice. These new approaches will understand how cancers develop and find new treatments for early and late stages of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Perseverative behaviors are prominent, disabling, and often treatment-resistant symptoms of several neuropsychiatric disorders. We will use chemogenetics and fiber photometry in awake behaving mice to identify the mechanisms by which medial versus lateral orbitofrontal-striatal circuits regulate perseverative behavior. The proposed work could lead to novel therapeutic strategies for treating perseverative behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative. The future of our nation requires a well-trained scientific workforce that is inclusive and as diverse as the populations that comprise the USA. Unfortunately, not all demographic groups have access to the opportunities that prepare them for careers in basic biomedical sciences e.g. U.S. citizens and permanent residents belonging to certain ethnic groups are especially underrepresented in their participation in science, technology, engineering, mathematics (STEM) and in basic biomedical research careers. The proposed holistic program is integrated and developmentally-appropriate, that will enhance trainees’ critical thinking, self- efficacy, research capacity, and communication skills so that at graduation, these undergraduates will have the skills and mental agility to gain entry into top-tier research programs, to further science, and to become independent inclusive scientists and leaders in the scientific enterprise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the widespread use of efficacious antiretroviral therapies in controlling peripheral infection and improving life of HIV patients, The prevalence and severity of HIV-1-associated neurocognitive disorders (HAND) are greatly enhanced (~70%) due to concomitant use of drugs of abuse such as cocaine. Dysregulation of dopamine signaling has been implicated as a risk determinant of HAND. Our study will determine a novel, previously uncertain molecular mechanism(s) driving Tat-induced dysfunction of dopamine system by direct interaction with vesicular monoamine transporter, which is associated with Tat-mediated cognitive/behavioral deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacterial virulence often relies on the secretion of effectors across the cell envelope, which mediate numerous processes including biofilm formation, nutrient acquisition, and immune evasion. Herein, we propose to characterize a putative variation of the type VIII secretion system (T8SS) that is required for surface-association of polysaccharides in the diverse, clinically-relevant Gram-negative pathogens Acinetobacter baumannii and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, thereby facilitating biofilm formation. As this uncharacterized T8SS variant is widespread in Gram-negative bacteria, findings from this research may have broad-reaching implications on our understanding of the biology and virulence of numerous pathogens.
