IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Targeting unique features of cancer cells is a preferred therapeutic strategy to inhibit metastatic progression while limiting off-target effects in normal cells. We are testing new ideas on how the unique feature of increased intracellular pH (pHi) in cancers compared with normal adult cells can be targeted to limit cancer metabolism and tumorigenesis. Our expected outcomes are substantial new views on the importance of increased pHi in cancer progression that will impact new therapeutic strategies to limit progression of cancers from different tissue origins and genetic backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Public Relevance Statement African American population is projected to increase up to 18% by 2060 in the US and as the population increases, the deleterious effects of maternal hyperglycemia will also. Sleep disparities exist in African American pregnant women and can lead to disparities in maternal hyperglycemia and related maternal and fetal complications of pregnancy. This innovative study using individually tailored, culturally adapted intervention has the potential to advance science, reduce hyperglycemia, improve glucose metabolism, and improve maternal- fetal well-being by demonstrating the effectiveness of sleep BETTER intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: UCI ADRC Overall Project Narrative The U.S. is in the midst of a crisis on Alzheimer's disease (AD) and Orange County California is in the epicenter as there are more people with AD living here than in 26 other states. The University of California, Irvine Alzheimer's Disease Research Center (UCI ADRC) is strategically located to have a major positive impact as we identify, quantify, and validate factors that influence the risk of AD across the lifespan. The UCI ADRC brings energetic and innovative multi-dimensional and multi-disciplinary approaches toward solving this insidious disease, contributes to several national collaborative efforts, and provides key resources to the research community, including studying special populations impacted by the disease, such as underrepresented ethnic groups, adults with Down syndrome, and the oldest-old.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dillard University proposes to initiate new academic development activities that will strengthen and enhance our existing research and academic support activities for underrepresented (UR) students. As a competitive liberal arts HBCU, Dillard’s U-RISE program will implement an interdisciplinary early inquiry-based group research program and a collaborative intervention and retention program to increase overall UR student applications to research graduate degree programs, and promote their entry into biomedical/ behavioral careers. By improving on our current graduate school application rate, Dillard will have a significant impact on UR students who plan to attend graduate school and finish a research doctoral degree.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The basis of this proposal is to elucidate the mechanism(s) of ultrasound scattering in biological tissues by systematically studying structure functions using solid tumors from animal models and hepatocellular carcinoma in adult human subjects, and thereby improve the accuracy of Quantitative Ultrasound (QUS, the quantification of tissue microstructure) techniques in noninvasive tumor detection and classification. The successful completion of this study will have significant impact at both the basic and clinical science levels to improve the accuracy of tumor diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: This proposal examines the role of the human chorion as an active site of blood cell production. The development of macrophages from hematopoietic stem cells in the chorion and their role in providing immunity will be investigated. Results from this study will provide insight into conditions such as chronic chorioamnionitis that threaten pregnancy and may lead to fetal demise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We found that targeting the oncogenic KRAS-MAPK pathway in pancreatic cancer cells leads to marked induction of TNF secretion, which drives both death and survival including autophagy. Selective inhibition of MK2, which controls the survival signaling, aggravates TNF-mediated tumor cell death. On this basis, we will investigate the mechanisms by which MK2 signaling controls cell survival in cancer cells and shapes the surrounding fibroblasts and immune cells, with the overarching goal of developing novel therapeutic strategies that can be advanced into the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severe traumatic brain injury (TBI) in young adults causes serious chronic consequences and lifelong disabilities that urgently require therapies for improving recovery months and years after TBI, but no treatment is available to improve TBI recovery in this chronic phase. Building on our preliminary studies that treatment with two bone marrow-generated growth factors at 3 and 6 months post-severe TBI in young adult mice improves functional outcomes, the objective of this proposed study is to determine how this treatment repairs a severe TBI-damaged brain in the chronic phase. It is expected that the proposed mechanistic studies will provide critical evidence needed for the development of an evidence-based therapy for enhancing severe TBI recovery in the chronic phase.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Coordinate regulation of gene expression is a fundamental property of developing multicellular systems, and its dysfunction is linked to diverse human diseases. This work has two goals. One is to understand how non-coding RNAs regulate gene expression. Second, how do metabolism, cell-cell signaling, and morphogenesis interact with programmatic gene regulation to elicit important developmental processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We previously determine that deep brain stimulation (DBS) shortens the persistency of drug seeking, while increasing BDNF expression in the hippocampus. Therefore, this research project will determine the best parameters to prevent drug reinstatement, as well as to pursue pharmacological and circuit-based studies to unravel DBS’ mechanisms of action. Since our animal model of extinction, resembles exposure-based therapies in humans, the identification of DBS-induced pro-extinction molecules in the corticomesolimbic reward circuit, combined with pharmacological treatments, represents a future approach to alleviate substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Due to the aging of the U.S. population, the societal burden of ADRD is on the rise. This burden disproportionately affects non-Latinx Black families, but modifiable mechanisms underlying racial inequalities in ADRD are not understood. It is therefore critical to identify new targets for interventions and policies at the individual, interpersonal, and environmental levels to reduce ADRD risk and eliminate ADRD inequalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relevance Balanced immune responses are essential for favorable outcomes during infections and comprise the crosstalk between microbial-tailored effector mechanisms able to control pathogen replication and fine-tuned regulatory pathways that prevent excessive immunopathology at the infection target tissues. This project will provide mechanistic insights about how the interplay between effector and regulatory immune responses rules the generation of cellular immunity to T. cruzi and consequently, the control of parasite replication, the immunopathology and the severity of chronic Chagas disease. This knowledge could provide new targets for the rational design of new therapeutic treatments aimed at enhancing protective cellular responses without compromising tissue homeostasis during Chagas disease and other chronic infections.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Florida Summer Institute in Biostatistics and Data Science (Florida SIBDS) addresses the critical shortage of biostatisticians and inclusion of a pipeline of qualified young adults from groups typically underrepresented in the behavioral and biomedical sciences. Florida SIBDS is lead by experienced senior biostatistics faculty with strong commitments to teaching, collaboration and conduct of clinical and translational research. Students will participate in learning exercises and receive mentorship by faculty and peers regarding curriculum and career goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal outlines the development and implementation of microfabricated cell culture platforms that enable the convergence of engineered cell microenvironments with targeted cell signaling manipulations. This integrated approach will facilitate unique experiments focused on the spatial and temporal mechanisms governing liver progenitor cell differentiation. In addition, these platforms could be widely applicable for studies on cell fate specification, including the optimization of stem cell differentiation protocols, as well as the examination of signaling mechanisms in cancer and degenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol abuse represents a major public health concern and is consistently among the leading causes of preventable death in the United States and worldwide. Despite significant effort, much remains unknown as to the neurobiological basis of attraction to alcohol and why some individuals are vulnerable to developing harmful drinking patterns over time. This proposal focuses on defining how the mesocortical dopamine system, which exerts powerful neuromodulatory influence over prefrontal cortex, contributes to alcohol-related decision making and the development of excessive drinking behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ABCD Study consortium uses multimodal brain imaging, cognitive and clinical assessments, bioassays, mobile monitoring, and careful assessment of substance use, environment, psychopathological symptoms, and social functioning in 11,878 9-10 year-olds to be followed over 10 years, to determine the effects of substance use on adolescent brain and cognitive development. This ABCD Research Project Site will follow and assess participants enrolled in the study. These data will be shared with the scientific community to address a comprehensive range of questions concerning youth development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Sensory maps of each brain hemisphere process information from the opposite side of the body. Congenital defects in somatosensory pathways result in an abnormal map formation in the cortex. We will investigate the development and plasticity of a bilateral facial map in the cortex and how it is incorporated into the rest of the corticocortical circuitry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colorectal cancer is the third most common cancer in the United States and second leading cause of cancer- related mortality in both men and women combined. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, including Cox-2 inhibitors, have shown promise in reducing disease risk; however, these drugs are often associated with significant toxicities. Therefore, there is a clear need to develop other novel chemoprevention strategies. The proposed studies will lay the foundation for developing sulforaphane as a chemopreventive agent for patients at high risk for developing colorectal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed “Sjögren’s Team for Accelerating Medicines Partnership (STAMP)” is strategically positioned to apply cutting-edge technologies to interrogate the tissue and systems biology of Sjögren’s disease (SjD) to better understand 1) the pathogenesis of SjD and identify therapeutic targets, and new biomarkers; and 2) disease mechanisms inherent to progression of SjD from non-SjD to SjD, and from “early SjD” to “advanced SjD”. To achieve these goals, we plan to develop a 5-year scientific research agenda, and design standardized clinical research protocols to recruit, enroll, phenotype, and collect relevant biospecimens from, observational cohorts of individuals with SjD and controls.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Asthma is a chronic lung disease affecting millions worldwide. We currently have a limited understanding of how the changes to mucus observed in disease contribute to its function. The proposed research aims to provide a new, highly valuable means to understand the impact of disease-associated changes in mucus composition to lung airway dysfunction in asthma and other related muco-obstructive lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because once we understand the mechanisms that control the different steps of tissue regeneration, we can better design strategies to manipulate specific aspects of the tissue damage response, while avoiding unwanted side effects, after acute injury or chronic illness. Ultimately this knowledge has the potential to guide our efforts to regrow essential human tissues such as pancreatic islets, cardiac muscle, lung alveoli, and digits or appendages, which will have a profound impact on the treatment of patients who suffer from diabetes, heart disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, cystic fibrosis and traumatic injury. Therefore, the proposed research fulfills the mission of the NIH to pursue fundamental knowledge of biology that will reduce the burdens caused by chronic illness and traumatic injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE The proposed study targets the complex, prevalent, and difficult-to-treat psychiatric comorbidity of alcohol use disorder (AUD) and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Building on promising preliminary data and provider input, this study will evaluate a new integrated behavioral intervention that synergistically combines two evidence-based treatments: Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT) for PTSD and Relapse Prevention (RP) for AUD. This study has the potential to significantly improve patient outcomes, transform clinical practice, advance the science of comorbidity in this area, and reduce expenditures associated with AUD and PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The adenosine-producing (adenosinergic) pathway in tumor-derived exosomes (TEX) emerges as a critical mechanism in suppression of T-cell responses to immunotherapy and in promoting tumor progression. This project will further elucidate the role of TEX in adenosine-mediated immune suppression as well as tumor progression in cancer and will assess the performance of adenosinergic activity in TEX as a potential biomarker of prognosis and response to therapy in patients with cancer.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - Overall The UC Davis Environmental Health Sciences Center has, in its first four years, advanced understanding of various health conditions and the exposures that contribute to them. These include neurodevelopmental disorders, metabolic conditions like diabetes, and respiratory problems such as asthma. By learning what factors increase the risk or severity of these conditions, this research sets the stage for interventions that can prevent them, and thereby improve public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding epithelial stem cell regulation within tissues will serve to repair or replace cells or organs damaged by injury, disease, and aging. The strategies vary from generating cell types and tissues in a dish for transplantation purposes to directly stimulating the damaged organ in the living organism. This field has been exponentially growing for the past decade, and this conference will allow bringing together scientists from currently disparate areas, which will create synergy and result in faster progress in this field that is highly medically significant.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The TBI literature provides preliminary evidence supporting associations between TBI exposures and poor health and functional outcomes, particularly as they occur in the context of the traumatic and stressful circumstances of military deployment. For this proposal, the researchers will work with and support the creation of a curated, unified dataset from LIMBIC and TRACTS prospective, longitudinal studies and demonstrate the feasibility of analytic approaches to detect for associations between objective, functional physiologic measures of TBI-related dysfunction, with clinically relevant outcome measures of TBI, including symptom burden and response to treatment. This proposed research will lay the foundations for the use of extant and ongoing prospective, longitudinal datasets and linked big datasets to generate generalizable, clinically relevant information on the role of objective, measurable assessments of brain function after TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The reduced efficacy of vaccines and monoclonal antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern underscores the need for more universal antiviral approaches. I will investigate the structure and dynamics of highly conserved regions within Spike, the main target of neutralizing antibodies, and identify structural correlates of broadly reactive antibody Fc effector functions. This work will reveal key vulnerabilities of the Spike protein to inform the design of cross- reactive antibody therapies, Spike inhibitors, and vaccines.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV-exposed uninfected infants (iHEU) are disproportionately affected by GBS and RSV related illnesses owing partly due to lower maternal antibodies and impaired transplacental antibody transfer. Whether maternally acquired antibodies are functionally defective remains unknown. We therefore plan to test the hypothesis that iHEU acquire functionally defective antibodies that rapidly wane during infancy leaving them vulnerable to GBS and RSV illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Among structural congenital heart defects (CHDs), abnormal valve development makes up the most common malformations, including defects in valve leaflet anatomy and function. While perturbations of retinoic acid (RA) signaling are associated with CHDs, little is known about the role of RA in vertebrate valve development. The results of this proposal will illuminate mechanisms underlying the requirements of RA in vertebrate valve development, which may provide insight into the causes of valve defects and may aid in the generation of novel strategies for the prevention, repair, and maintenance of valve diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Viral and bacterial infection and associated inflammation drive expansion and differentiation of hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells. These processes can be corrupted by germline genetic variation, which creates a predisposition to bone marrow failure through unknown mechanisms. We will develop systems and address mechanisms to understand how variation impacts infection/inflammation-instigated genetic networks. As fungal infection is common in patients with bone marrow failure and immunodeficiency, understanding the relationship between variation, infection, and hematopoiesis has critical fundamental and clinical/translational implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Age-dependent neurodegeneration is a major health and socioeconomic burden that will worsen as  human lifespan steadily increases. The mechanisms of degeneration initiation and progression, as well as protective pathways to combat disease, remain poorly understood. We propose to elucidate how proteins implicated in the polyglutamine family of degenerative diseases are regulated in intact animals and in human cells with the purpose of learning new ways to combat them therapeutically.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Pediatric critical care and trauma physician-scientists discover knowledge that is vital for the health of children. The nation is facing a shortage of pediatric critical care and trauma physician-scientists. The goal of the PCCTSDP is to increase the number of diverse, well-trained, successfully funded physician-scientists in pediatric critical care and trauma surgery who are capable of sustaining careers in basic, clinical, translational and health services research that advance the understanding and care of critically ill and injured children and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Fragile X syndrome (FXS), caused by loss of FMRP, is a common form of inherited intellectual disability and the leading monogenetic cause of autism. This research in a mouse model will identify a novel function for FMRP to regulate endocytic adapter proteins, which are essential for proper communication at synapses in the brain. This research will explore a potential new therapeutic strategy to correct for impairments in synapse plasticity and hyperexcitability in FXS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The malaria parasite exercises morphological changes to complete its life cycle. We identified a protein which associates with the parasite cytoskeleton in two life stages and is hypothesized to be essential for parasite replication. We aim to characterize its functional role in the blood stages of malaria infection and map its interactions to explore the parasite cytoskeleton and inform the rational design of antimalarial drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Switching to e-cigarettes is a harm-reducing alternative to combustible cigarettes for persistent smokers. Flavors may appeal to and aid these smokers unable to quit with traditional approaches. Yet, there are no prospective studies of the effect of flavor on initial and sustained switching from combustible cigarettes to e-cigarettes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE ALX4 is a transcription factor that is important for proper bone, skull, and limb development, and mutations in ALX4 are associated with several different human birth defects that affect the development of the face, skull, and limbs. The overall goal of this proposal is to determine high-resolution structures of ALX4 and use biochemical/cellular assays to understand how ALX4 disease associated variants affect its function. Completion of these studies is important for understanding ALX4 function under normal physiological and pathophysiological contexts and will lay the groundwork for future studies to study ALX4 using in vivo models and initiate drug discovery projects focused on ALX4.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  CAR-T cell therapy has shown astounding success in treating refractory or relapsed B cell malignancies, and is being explored as a promising immunotherapeutic agent against solid tumors as well as HIV, HCV and other public health relevant chronic viral infections with no efficacious vaccines or treatments available yet. Studies outlined in this proposal seek to address a key challenge in solid tumor CAR-T immunotherapy – homing and migration of adoptively transferred CAR-T therapeutic product to solid tumors. Leveraging bioengineering strategies that enhance chemoattractant expression by CAR-T cells in tumor sites, this proposal explores the possibility of transforming CAR-T cells into effector T cell beacons for enhanced therapeutic efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative East and Southern African (ESA) countries have heavily invested in reducing HIV among adolescent girls by implementing social protection programs designed to promote safer sexual behavior and increase HIV testing. However, adolescent girls are not a monolithic population, and it is likely that marginalized sub-populations, like adolescent mothers, face social and economic barriers to participation which may limit their ability to engage in and benefit from social protection programs. This study will leverage publicly available, nationally representative data from the Population-based HIV Impact Assessment (PHIA) Projects across 8 African countries to understand whether adolescent mothers participate in social protection programs, which adolescent mothers participate in these programs, and which programs to prioritize to optimize impacts of HIV prevention initiatives for AMs across countries with high HIV-burden among girls.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Globally, 2.7 million children are living with HIV and over 90% of them live in sub-Saharan Africa where HIV subtypes A, C and D are predominant. In adults, HIV subtypes differ in virulence and transmissibility, but whether the same is true in children is unknown. The goal of this study is to determine the interplay of virologic and immunologic factors that slow disease progression in perinatal HIV and modulate the HIV reservoir size to stimulate innovative approaches towards HIV remission in children with perinatal HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Through continuation and enhancement of the Atlanta African American Maternal-Child Cohort, we will further leverage this unique environmental epidemiology cohort, our collaboration with a historically Black medical school, and our team’s expertise in exposure assessment, perinatal health, and omic sciences to advance environmental health science around predictive toxicology and individual susceptibility. We aim to expand: 1) enrollment and engagement in longitudinal follow-up of African American mother-child dyads through key windows of susceptibility (pregnancy through early childhood); 2) data collection to incorporate measures of environmental health equity (area-level measures of deprivation, segregation, air pollution) and environmental injustice (high-resolution metabolomics to identify bio-transformed metabolites linked with personal care product use); and 3) engagement with early stage investigators of the Morehouse School of Medicine NIEHS- supported Frontiers in Environmental Science and Health (FrESH) training program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The project aims to investigate the role of nonclassical monocytes in primary graft dysfunction (PGD) and injury in other organs following lung transplant. The project has two aims: to study how host classical monocytes promote the migration and retention of donor nonclassical monocytes in other organs, and to understand the opposing roles of donor and recipient nonclassical monocytes in PGD and remote organ injury. The insights gained will help develop new strategies to improve outcomes after lung transplant surgery.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The voltage-gated ion channel CatSper is an exceptionally promising and validated target for male contraception because it is exclusively expressed in sperm, is critical for sperm function, and is required for male fertility. CatSper knock-out mice are completely infertile and naturally occurring CatSper mutations are a cause of male factor infertility in humans. We are developing compounds to inhibit CatSper and sperm function that can be used as male contraceptives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Flaviviruses, including West Nile virus, remain pathogens of global health importance with limited therapeutic or vaccine interventions. Initiation of antiviral immunity is critical for clearance of viral infection and programming of adaptive immunity; however, we currently lack the understanding of types and localizations of viral RNAs that drive productive innate immune activation. This project aims to identify immunostimulatory viral RNA species that trigger RIG-I-like receptor mediated antiviral immunity during West Nile virus infection and define their localization and accessibility in the context of viral replication compartments and cytosolic pattern recognition receptors.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A significant unmet need for worldwide population control exists due to the lack of available safe, effective, and reversible oral male contraceptives. To close this critical translational gap, we propose to target the testis-specific RNA binding protein RBM46 as a contraceptive approach. The overarching goals of this project are to screen for small molecules that bind RBM46, develop these “binders” into proteolysis targeting chimeras (PROTACs) to specifically degrade RBM46 protein in differentiating spermatogonia, and then determine whether use of these PROTACS induces reversible male sterility in both mice and marmosets, a non-human primate model with closer similarity to humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  This project seeks to help people with severe essential tremor improve their therapy through advanced closed loop medical device technology. These studies will make important contributions to the public health because it builds on rapid advances in technology to give subjects better treatment of a common illness, essential tremor. It will also help improve our understanding of how the brain perceives and controls limb movement so we can provide better clinical solutions to the affected subjects. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with benign epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes (BECTS), the most common pediatric epilepsy syndrome, have a mild seizure disorder but yet have moderate difficulties with language that impact their quality of life more than the seizures. Separate from the seizures, these children have frequent abnormal activity in their brain known as interictal epileptiform discharges (IEDs), which we currently do not treat. This project uses a form of non-invasive brain stimulation (called transcranial magnetic stimulation) to determine the impact of IEDs on brain regions important for language in order to investigate: (1) if treatment of IEDs could improve language; and (2) if brain stimulation may be a novel treatment option.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Mutant KRAS protein drives several cancer related pathways and remains a highly sought after target. We have discovered that targeting nuclear transporter XPO1 by specific inhibitors of nuclear export drugs can synergize with KRAS targeted drugs. We will perform critical pre-clinical analysis of this synergy to bring forward a novel and effective combination therapy targeting the KRAS and nuclear protein transport axis in oncogenic RAS driven tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is a common medical condition affecting at least 10-20% of the adult US population, it is poorly understood in terms of the mechanisms causing reflux and how symptoms are triggered by reflux. This proposal will attempt to develop a better understanding of the complex interaction of the brain-gut connection in promoting reflux symptoms by performing clinical trials using behavioral therapies to improve symptoms in GERD. This project will also enable us to develop a better understanding of how psychological distress can impact gastrointestinal diseases as we will study how changes in stress affect symptoms in patients with the same physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Memory impairment is a core deficit accompanying many neurological disorders. This proposal will examine how compartmentalized plasticity modulates learning and memory, from the molecular through the circuit levels. These experiments will add to the knowledge base required for rational design of treatments for memory disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defects in chromatin organization, gene transcription, and DNA packaging are major causes of human disease, notably cancer. Our studies will uncover the functions of readers and writers of histone post-translational modifications and histone variants, as well as the function of a histone chaperone complex. These studies will advance our fundamental understanding of the chromatin regulators that are dysregulated in human disease, thereby identifying new targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Several neurological diseases are characterized by defects in protein homeostasis within the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and secretory pathway. The long-term objective of this proposal is to study (i) how ATase1, ATase2 and GDAC collaborate to ensure essential neuronal functions, and (ii) how this collaboration is lost in neurological disorders. The ultimate goal is to explore therapeutic strategies with the potential to define new avenues of research (and treatment) for different neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Splenic marginal zone lymphoma is the most common form of cancer arising in the spleen. Current diagnosis is based on histopathologic criteria and requires splenectomy despite the fact that virtually all cases involve peripheral blood. We and others have recently determined the genomic aberrations that characterize this disease and propose to employ state–of-the-art and sensitive genomic sequencing approaches to achieve early and accurate disease diagnosis. The studies in this proposal will lead to development of simple blood-based assays that will improve early detection and promote implementation of early and appropriate treatment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative We will test whether (i) exogenous melatonin during the day increases the number of uterine contractions in full- term pregnant women, (ii) exogenous melatonin can increase light-exposure associated suppression of uterine contractions at night in late-term pregnant women, and (iii) there is a relationship between circulating melatonin levels and number of uterine contractions. The findings in this research project will contribute vital information to our understanding of the causal role of melatonin in changing the number of uterine contractions, and may have important clinical implications.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ABCD Study consortium uses multimodal brain imaging, cognitive and clinical assessments, bioassays, mobile monitoring, and careful assessment of substance use, environment, psychopathological symptoms, and social functioning in 11,878 9-10 year-olds to be followed over 10 years, to determine the effects of substance use on adolescent brain and cognitive development. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative HIV-infected individuals are at high risk of developing cardio-vascular disease (CVD), even when HIV infection is controlled by treatment. We hypothesize that susceptibility to CVD is promoted by the extracellular vesicles containing HIV protein Nef, which are released from HIV-infected cells and modify membranes of the cells related to CVD. We will investigate new treatments designed to reverse the effects of Nef on cell membrane.

PHR: Project Narrative Now that we have identified the key genetic loci that modulate rheumatoid arthritis (RA), we seek to define the mechanism by which these loci cause disease. Here we explore an innovative model of genetic susceptibility that links the role of the MHC and alleles within T cell regulatory regions. If our strategy is successful, it will pave the way to unlocking new therapeutic strategies to treat RA and possibly cure it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Human African trypanosomiasis and Chagas disease are classed as neglected tropical diseases by the World Health Organization. They suffer from a lack of financial investment from the for-profit pharmaceutical industry, yet current treatments are associated with limited efficacy, increasing instances of treatment failure, high cost and long-term toxicity issues. This project will focus on the development of compounds that meet the Target Product Profiles for the respective disease with the view of obtaining pre-clinical candidates and understanding the mode of action and/or identifying the target of lead series.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Human signaling networks involve large sets of proteins exhibiting highly complex patterns of posttranslational modifications (PTMs) that govern their structure and function. Since changes in PTMs (e.g., phosphorylation and acetylation) occur at multiple sites, understanding such networks at the systems and mechanistic levels remains an elusive and unmet goal. This work seeks to develop new genomic and proteomic tools to encode multiple and programmable combinations of phosphorylated and acetylated amino acids into proteins that reveal new protein interactions at the molecular level to facilitate the development of new therapies for human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Coordinated specialty care for early psychosis shows significant promise to reduce long-term chronicity and dysfunction associated with schizophrenia-spectrum disorders, however, few young adults with early psychosis present to these services. Mobile health tools provide a unique opportunity to remotely engage this population and target help-seeking beliefs, but little is known about whether and how these approaches can address this gap. The proposed project aims to take a user-centered design approach to developing and testing an mHealth tool that promotes help seeking among young adults with early psychosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Overall component Understanding the biology of human skin diseases is critical to alleviating suffering and curing these diseases in patients. However, mice and other animals are imperfect models for humans and many therapies developed in mice are not successful in humans. This Center will recruit, empower and support researchers at any institution who wish to work on human cells and tissues by providing access to human tissue biobanks and cutting edge analytic techniques that will allow them to carry out high-quality, human-based research that is directly relevant to human skin disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  A cell-autonomous molecular clock powers the 24-hour cycles of endogenous regulation of physiology, known as circadian rhythms, which align physiology and behavior to the inherent rotation of the earth. Dysregulation of circadian rhythms has negative physiological effects, such as causing sleep disorders. Our project will increase the understanding of the molecular basis of circadian rhythms, informing the etiology of circadian-based sleep disorders and thereby leading to the development of novel therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In many studies on the risk of disease, investigators analyze the spatial patterns of health outcomes and evaluate residential environmental exposures at the time of study enrollment in hopes of identifying potential causal environmental factors. However, for cancers with long latencies residential locations many years prior to diagnosis are important for determining where and when relevant environmental exposures occurred. In this project we will develop statistical methods that incorporate residential histories to estimate the effect of historic environmental and socio-spatial exposures and identify areas of elevated cancer risk over time.

PHR: Project Narrative: Population Research Institute The Population Research Institute (PRI) at the Pennsylvania State University provides services and activities designed to promote the interdisciplinary study of population dynamics and improve understanding of the conditions needed to support healthy developmental trajectories from early childhood into adulthood. The population science research supported by this award will inform interventions and policies designed to reduce health disparities and improve healthy lifespan development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Young infants show remarkably different reactions to expectancy violations, but it is not clear why. This research will examine how infants distinguish between different types of events, contributing fundamental knowledge about early cognitive and social capacities with implications for enhancing human development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The goal of the University of Louisville Center for Integrative Environmental Health Sciences is to understand how exposure to environmental toxicants interacts with life style factors and how these co-exposures impact human health and disease, as modified by life stage and gender. This knowledge will provide better prevention and intervention strategies to improve the health of the people in western Kentucky.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are one of the most common infections diagnosed each year and a driving force behind the increasing bacterial resistance to antibiotics. This project will investigate how bacteriophages, viruses that infect bacteria, can be used as new treatments for UTIs. The project will also define the safety of using bacteriophages to treat UTIs and describe how bacteria try to avoid being killed by bacteriophages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The highly conserved extracellular signal-regulated kinase (Erk) pathway regulates tissue growth and patterning throughout development, and mutations in Erk pathway components are common causes of cancer. Understanding how cells interpret complex and dynamic Erk signals to yield distinct cell fates will significantly inform our understanding of how this pathway contributes to disease, yet these mechanisms have been difficult to identify. I propose to use innovative optogenetic tools in the Drosophila embryo, a classic and well-defined in vivo model for Erk signal interpretation, to define the molecular mechanisms by which this important pathway measures and interprets Erk signal dose to effect gene expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kidney transplantation is one of two treatment options for patients with lupus nephritis-associated end-stage kidney disease (LN-ESKD), although there is little information regarding access to early steps in the kidney transplant process for this patient population. The proposed research project will use a multilevel approach to evaluate access to referral for an evaluation at a kidney transplant center (the first step in the kidney transplant process) in patients with LN-ESKD by examining socioeconomic and health system factors that may be impacting referral access. The results of this project could be used to inform interventions that focus on timely referral for kidney transplant and ultimately improve long-term outcomes among LN-ESKD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The COVID-19 pandemic demonstrated the potential of epidemiological modeling for planning public health responses, but also exposed significant practical obstacles to its real-world application in local-level decision- making. Here we face this challenge head on, developing a next-generation informatics portal called EpiMoRPH that standardizes and automates the model evaluation process, facilitating collaborations between modelers and public health stakeholders to determine the best modeling approaches to address local needs. Moreover, we will develop an Optimization Engine, which will provide a substantially automated toolkit for local public health stakeholders to build disease control strategies that balance minimizing disease outcomes and maximizing equitable distribution of interventions across racial, ethnic, and socioeconomic sectors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the most commonly diagnosed noncutaneous malignancy and the second leading cause of cancer mortality for American men, prostate cancer remains an important public health concern. Advanced prostate cancer is resistant to therapeutics blocking immune checkpoint molecules such as PD1 or CTLA4 with the cold tumor microenvironment as a major contributing factor. Upon completion of our project, we will define the functional role and mechanisms of the chromatin regulatory protein PYGO2 (frequently amplified in advanced prostate cancer) as the key signaling hub to foster the cold prostate tumor microenvironment, and identify PYGO2 inhibitors with the potential to turn the microenvironment from cold to hot and enhance the response of prostate cancer to immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accurate assessment of children’s (5-12yrs) free-living physical activity energy expenditure (PAEE) is fundamental to understanding the complex and interdependent relationship between children’s PAEE and health outcomes, such as diabetes and obesity. The inclusion of activity type in regression equations that use movement and heart rate may allow for more accurate assessment of children’s free-living PAEE beyond that of combining movement and heart rate. The unique ability of consumer wearables to autodetect activity type and assess heart rate and movement metrics could advance the assessment of children’s free-living PAEE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This T32 grant, “Obesity & Gastrointestinal Surgery Scientist Training Program” integrates all aspects of obesity and gastrointestinal surgery research at the University of Michigan – from “bench to bedside, and practice to policy”— allowing us to address fundamental questions about obesity and gastrointestinal surgery in a multidisciplinary way. As outlined in our proposal, we believe the University of Michigan is in a unique position to conduct this training program due to a critical mass of scientists focused on both basic science and health services research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Radiation therapy with high dose rates is undergoing a revolution because of the recent realization the scope of normal tissue damage is modulated by the dose rate. This research program will establish the dosimetry tools and mechanisms needed to understand, control and plan this type of FLASH radiation therapy treatment, which spares normal tissues more than tumor tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In neurons, the scaffolding protein gephyrin plays a critical role in altering GABAergic synaptic inhibition during plasticity. The goal of this project is to study gephyrin synthesis during inhibitory synaptic plasticity to understand neuronal mechanisms underlying precise and lasting changes in inhibitory synaptic strength. This will provide crucial insight into how inhibitory synaptic plasticity supports the balance of excitation and inhibition, the disruption of which is implicated in pathologies such as epilepsy, schizophrenia, and autism spectrum disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE In this proposal, we will be developing, disseminating, and evaluating a web-based software tool that can perform MRI analyses for the diagnostic accuracy of Parkinsonism. Our goal is to leverage our years of experience and algorithm development, to test a prospective cohort of Parkinson’s disease, Multiple System Atrophy, and Progressive Supranuclear Palsy. We expect that at the end of the project, we will have validated a web-based software tool that can use MRIs from different vendors to read, analyze, and predict the diagnosis of different forms of Parkinsonism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiometabolic disease (CMD), often a precursor to cardiovascular disease, is associated with a two-fold risk of mortality from coronary artery disease and is particularly prevalent in African American women. Chronic stress, associated with discrimination and racism, is linked to CMD. This investigation will evaluate the effectiveness of a novel 8-week, group-based empowerment-building program, Resilience, Stress, and Ethnicity (RiSE), in providing sustainable improvement in well-being, inflammation, and DNA methylation with the potential of decreasing risk for CMD in this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Neuronal activity can promote the growth of high-grade gliomas, but it is not known whether neuronal activity influences low-grade glioma growth or glioma initiation in general. The goal of this proposal is to employ the Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) brain cancer predisposition syndrome as an experimental platform to mechanistically determine whether neuronal activity is a critical driver of low-grade glioma initiation and growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project proposes a novel, multi-target approach for repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) treatment of Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) and comorbid fibromyalgia (FM), which is associated with significant disability and is highly resistant to treatment. In the short-term, this project aims to evaluate the effectiveness of augmenting rTMS treatment for depression with a secondary target for pain in MDD patients with FM comorbidity and to identify the differences in and the interaction of brain networks affected in MDD and FM using a machine learning approach. In the long-term, this project promises to increase our understanding of this serious comorbid condition and improve treatment outcomes for the subpopulation of patients with MDD and potentially other mood disorder confounded by chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We have proposed a pivotal role of CysLTR1 in regulating tumor-induced MDSC accumulation for both immune suppression and promotion of tumor progression. Our work will not only advance current understandings of how inflammatory lipid mediators in the tumor microenvironment fine-tune emergency myelopoiesis during cancer progression, but will provide the basis for development of novel therapies targeting tumor-infiltrating MDSCs in human cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This study will test the hypothesis that tumor cell-intrinsic genetic alterations correlate with response to MEK inhibition in systemic histiocytocytic neoplasms. Although ARAF and MEK1/2 mutations are recurrent across many cancers, the enrichment of these mutations in histiocytoses provides a unique opportunity to functionally dissect mechanisms by which ARAF and MEK1/2 regulate MAPK signaling and drive cancer. The results from this study will improve our understanding of histiocytosis pathogenesis, mechanisms of MAPK pathway activation in cancer, and determinants of response to MEK inhibition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to prevention of hematological malignancies (HM) as there are no current strategies for monitoring or intervening on healthy people with pre disease mutations detectable in blood years before the diagnosis of HM. While it is known that the presence of these mutations increase risk of HM, the exact mutational and cell extrinsic (inflammatory and metabolic) factors that impact the progression of these mutations to HM is not known. At the conclusion of the research study we will be able to delineate a HM specific mutational risk with detailed inflammatory and metabolic pathways that can be utilized for monitoring and creating an interception strategy for HM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is used to study the structure, function, interactions, and dynamics of proteins, with important implications for therapeutic development. However, interpreting NMR information is extremely challenging and labor intensive, especially for large proteins, which produce many overlapping, weak NMR signals. We are developing next-generation methods in which key information is more clearly visible and accessible in the NMR data, using a highly coordinated platform of emerging biochemical, biophysical, mathematical, and computational techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE When a US hospital system is overwhelmed by disaster, Crisis Standards of Care guide the triage teams forced to choose which patients receive scarce life support treatments in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU). Most US State Crisis Standards of Care rely on the Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score, but SOFA is inaccurate and racially biased. This project will 1) use structural equation modeling to develop an equitable life support allocation (ELSA) score with place-based disadvantage indices and 2) create the ICU Crisis Simulation Model (ICSM), open-source simulation software that evaluates the efficiency and equity of proposed life support allocation protocols.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative In the U.S. approximately 70,000 pedestrian injuries and over 6,000 deaths occur annually and pedestrians are commonly under the influence of alcohol when they are injured or killed; approximately 40% of fatally struck pedestrians are under the influence of alcohol at the time they were killed. Current urban planning and design trends and initiatives in the U.S. are likely to place more pedestrians at risk of injury and fatality, particularly pedestrians who are under the influence of alcohol, and current Federal and municipal plans to reduce pedestrian injuries provide no provisions for pedestrians who are under the influence of alcohol. We propose to build web- based geospatial tools to support research on alcohol and pedestrian injury and to conduct a national location- based case-control study of pedestrian fatalities, to answer the questions of whether proximity to retail alcohol outlets, nightlife districts and services for the homeless increase the risk of pedestrian fatality and whether this risk is heightened by built environment features that encourage pedestrian activity, place pedestrians near road traffic and cause distractions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Transcriptional regulation represents a major control mechanism of gene expression in eukaryotes. Cell-specific expression of ~20,000 genes in human cells requires hundreds of protein factors acting in a multistep manner. Through structural and functional studies, we seek to define the complex molecular mechanisms of gene transcription derived by different RNA polymerases at distinct regulatory steps.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer is the leading cause of death for Latino and Asian ethnic groups, who are among the fastest growing U.S. populations. In this study we will pool cancer registry data across five states containing the majority of these populations and link to contextual data to determine which patients live inside ethnic enclaves—distinct neighborhoods with high concentrations of individuals of the same ethnic origin (“co-ethnic residents”), linguistically isolated residents, and immigrants. We will study the relationship among ethnic enclaves, patient nativity (U.S.- or foreign-born) and cancer incidence, stage at diagnosis, survival for three cancer types (breast, cervix, colorectal) for Asian Americans and Latinos, with attention to the 9 major ethnic groups (Cuban, Mexican, Puerto Rican, Chinese, Filipino, Japanese, Korean, South Asian and Vietnamese).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative To generate accurate movements, the brain benefits from learning sensorimotor associations that are stored as motor memories through the process of synaptic plasticity in the cerebellum. The inability to form and store accurate representations of these associations may result in movement disorders that impair the quality of life for many people. Therefore, the goal of this project is to identify the locations in the cerebellum where motor memories are stored for different types of learning and uncover the molecular and synaptic features that allow for a diversity of memories that vary in duration, magnitude, and direction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Increasing competition for scarce research dollars and other hardships facing those in academic medicine, as well as the lure of private practice, discourage trainees from careers in digestive diseases-related research. The overall goal of this T32 training program is to seek, nurture and mentor talented pre- and postdoctoral trainees committed to research or leadership positions in academia, federal agencies or industry, and provide them with successful role models and the tools needed to persevere and succeed in this harsh environment. To accomplish these goals, our multidisciplinary faculty offers an integrated, individualized curriculum for training in basic or clinical & translational digestive diseases-related science in a diverse and resource-rich research environment with strong institutional support.

PROJECT_TITLE: Research Training in Gastroenterology and Hepatology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will provide a framework to use routinely collected South African laboratory data to track tuberculosis (TB) patients through time and space, incorporating HIV data. This will allow us to define the TB care cascade nationally and by facility (clinic/hospital), incorporating patients’ movements, thus enabling the targeting of these locations with locally appropriate interventions. We will also be able to evaluate the impact of HIV treatment scale-up and introduction of new TB diagnostics on TB morbidity and mortality – directly relevant to the NIH’s mission of reducing morbidity and mortality due to tuberculosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance. c-Myc is a central driver of cancers and is a validated drug target, however, no MYC-targeted therapeutic is available despite over 35 years of pursuit because the MYC protein is considered “undruggable”. The c-Myc promoter G-quadruplex represents a novel target for c-Myc inhibition; nucleolin is involved in the c-Myc regulation by G4-targeted compounds and the nucleolin-MycG4 complex could serve as a more specific target for drug development. If successful, our study will have important implications because the design of G4-targeted drugs to date has been focused solely on MycG4 DNA.

PHR: The objective of the Research Institute Rheumatology Training Program at Hospital for Special Surgery (HSS) is to train (1) outstanding physicians to become independent investigators; (2) Ph.D. scientists in rheumatic disease research enable multidisciplinary research to improve clinical outcomes and advance patient care; and (3) attract Ph.D. and MD-PhD. candidates into rheumatology research. The unique environment at HSS, focused on study of and care for patients with autoimmune and musculoskeletal diseases, is the setting for comprehensive training of the next generation of academic leaders who ultimately will impact the lives of patients with rheumatic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defects in cellular responses to DNA double-strand breaks can lead to mutations, deletions or other alterations in the genome and underlie many diseases. Our proposed studies will determine the regulation of linkage- specific ubiquitin modification on damaged chromatin and the underlying mechanism for DNA repair and transcription inhibition at DSBs. Our findings should provide novel insights into the understanding of the complex DNA response network that protects genome integrity, which is essential for translation into tools and treatment to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Injury is a leading cause of death and disability of older adults in the United States and older adults account for one-third of 911 calls for injury, but little is known about the health impact of emergency medical services (EMS) care for this population. This application will support a new investigator who aspires to a research career focused EMS and surgical care of injured older adults, especially the impact of prehospital EMS care on long-term health and functional status following injury diagnosis. The award will enable the investigator to develop knowledge and skills necessary to conduct independent research investigating patterns of care and health outcomes for injured older adults, which will lead to more effective treatment of this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Oral and oropharyngeal cancer survivors carry a high symptom burden that results in many self care requirements that can be overwhelming complex difficult to manage and can result in compromised quality of life unmet needs and low participation in self-care. There are no empirically based interventions to enhance skills and confidence to manage oral cancer survivors self care. This study proposes to evaluate a promising online intervention called Empowered Survivor or ES for short and evaluate its impact on self efficacy in managing care preparedness for managing survivorship and health related quality of life as well as engagement in several key self-care behaviors. Should ES prove efficacious it will serve as a model of care and advance both science and practice for cancer survivors particularly those who reside in the community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Enhancer hijacking events have been reported in the pathogenesis of cancer and other diseases. However, there has been no computational method to systematically detect such events genome-wide. Here we propose a series of algorithms to detect enhancer hijacking events in Hi-C data and will perform functional validation experiments to evaluate our predictions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Capitalizing on UCLA’s unique strengths, I propose to create a new and cutting-edge Center of Aging and Mitochondrial Health, with an emphasis on Alzheimer’s disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Low amounts of vitamin K in the diet are converted to an activated form in the body that is used for blood clotting by two proteins called VKORC1 and the carboxylase. VKORC1 is inhibited by the drug warfarin, which is used by millions of people worldwide to control blood clotting, for example with mechanical heart valves, while the carboxylase modifies vitamin K-dependent proteins to activate them for roles in blood coagulation, bone development, cell growth and embryonic development. Determining how VKORC1 and the carboxylase function has important ramifications for understanding these aspects of human health and producing activated vitamin K-dependent proteins as potential therapeutic drugs.

PHR: Overall: Narrative The application of high-content immune profiling tools has revolutionized our ability to decode disease etiology and processes. This Human Immune Project Consortium, Maternal ‘Omics to Maximize Immunity (MOMi), seeks to use a multi-OMICs approach to decode the unique nature of the immune system that evolves across gestation. The Projects will generate foundational data to guide rational design of customized vaccines that optimize both maternal and neonatal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stroke is the leading cause of disability in the United States, leaving a substantial number of survivors with permanent weakness. Neuromodulation of sensorimotor areas using physiologically targeted low-frequency stimulation is an innovative new direction to facilitate recovery of motor function. Our proposal seeks to optimize stimulation parameters as well as to develop electrophysiological makers of network function that delineate underlying mechanisms of action.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of the NICHD Neonatal Research Network is to improve healthcare and neurodevelopmental outcomes for newborns born premature, low birthweight, or with other serious conditions by performing rigorous and reproducible multi-site clinical trials and observational studies. This consortium of academic medical centers provides the neonatal population and faculty expertise to advance the field of neonatal- perinatal medicine. New opportunities are provided with new protocol proposal and selection processes as well as encouraging the participation of investigators from outside the Network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Small molecule therapeutics have tremendously improved human health and the ability to gain access to these materials is fundamental to this endeavor, but the science required towards this goal must continuously evolve to meet contemporary challenges. Here, we aim to develop novel chemical transformations that enable the efficient preparation of chiral scaffolds found in preclinical and clinical agents. The resulting reaction technology will be of utility to discovery chemists and have widespread impact on the synthesis of bioactive molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/ Public Health Relevance The recent increasing prevalence, severity, and healthcare burden of sinoatrial (SA) node dysfunction emphasize the need for more detailed studies of SA node functions that allow for effective targeted therapy to treat and prevent SA node dysfunction. This project aims to develop a multicellular SA node organoid capable of generating robust pacemaking and conduction by reproducing SA node’s structure and fail-safe mechanism. If successful, the studies will define if tissue-level architecture and multicellular compositions mediate SA node’s robust pacemaking and conduction and may reveal a high-fidelity tissue-level biological pacemaker as a novel therapeutic strategy for SA node dysfunctions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epidemic modeling is vital for reducing the spread of HIV and other infectious diseases, but often these models lack realistic social data, particularly data reflective of the populations impacted by drug use and HIV. In line with the urgent need for better data on the social systems around individuals, our team developed a free, open-source, NIDA/NIH BD2K-funded software suite called Network Canvas. While Network Canvas has already substantially improved the ability of researchers to quickly and accurately capture complex network and contextual data, it requires modernization to further its timely and broad reach and evaluation to understand its impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL) is an extremely aggressive mature T-cell malignancy with limited treatment options. As such, improved understanding of pathogenesis and novel therapeutic strategies are urgently needed. Based on our preliminary studies, we hypothesize that mutations in an epigenetic modifier, EP300, and expression of a transcription factor, BCL6, cooperate to cause abnormalities in gene expression and DNA replication. In this project, we will carry out mechanistic studies to test this hypothesis, and evaluate the efficacy of PARP inhibitor-based therapy in novel preclinical models of ATLL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative The mature brain has a remarkable ability to maintain long-term homeostasis throughout adulthood. We have identified a key molecule, called miR-29, which has an essential function in maintaining the mature brain during normal healthy aging. The experiments we propose focus on investigating the mechanisms of action of miR-29 in the adult brain as well as test its therapeutic efficacy in models of Alzheimer’s Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Using a multidisciplinary team approach, we are poised to map the cell-type specific genes, pathways, networks, and circuits vulnerable to the TBI pathology across brain regions and time points. We will use a combination of single cell RNA sequencing technology (scRNAseq), multiplexed error robust fluorescent in situ hybridization (MERFISH), advanced network modeling, and experimental validation and functional studies to unravel novel and fundamental gene and cell connectivity perturbations that can be used as biomarkers and targets of TBI in a data-driven, unbiased manner.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The NICHD Neonatal Research Network’s ongoing commitment to improving health outcomes in infants born preterm and with other high-risk conditions, and reducing known disparities, requires participation of Clinical Centers with track records of high-quality neonatal research. The Lurie Children’s-Northwestern University Study Center (LC-NU SC) in Chicago is a high-volume clinical center with a diverse population, one of the largest high- risk delivery services in the United States (over 12,000 births per year) and 148 NICU beds between the Lurie Children’s Hospital Level IV NICU and the immediately adjacent Prentice Women’s Hospital Level III NICU. With basic science and clinical investigative expertise in perinatal origins of health and disease, the genetic basis of neonatal conditions, neonatal growth and nutrition, health equity, and early detection of neurodevelopmental abnormalities, the LC-NU SC will be a significant contributor to the Neonatal Research Network’s goal of equitable and optimal health outcomes for vulnerable newborns.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For the first time ever, Lithuania has implemented all three of the World Health Organization’s “best buys” for alcohol control policy within a relatively short timeframe, allowing for an evaluation of their combined effect on health, crime, and violence, as well as an evaluation comparing the costs of their implementation to the return on investment via the reduction in hospitalization rates. Lithuania will be compared to surrounding countries in the eastern part of the European Union, to ensure that any changes observed within the country were not part of a regional trend independent of the “best buy” interventions. The proposed study will provide findings, never before possible, that are generalizable to other high-income countries, such as the United States.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Women with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDD) face obstacles throughout pregnancy that lead to morbidity and mortality. This project contributes to public health knowledge by using a novel data set of all Medicaid covered pregnancies to women with IDD from 2011-2022 to identify the impacts of pre-pregnancy Medicaid enrollment, adequate prenatal care, and Home and Community Based Service waivers on reducing maternal morbidity for women with IDD. In parallel, we will conduct qualitative interviews with women with IDD who have been or are pregnant to understand their lived experience in relation to Medicaid service use and prenatal enrollment, which will inform and be informed by quantitative analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Frontotemporal dementia is the most common form of dementia for people under age 60, but curative treatment is currently unavailable due to our limited understanding of the molecular etiology. This proposed research aims at developing mass spectrometry-based strategies to determine how GRN mutations, which result in progranulin deficiency, impair lysosomal functions and eventually lead to frontotemporal dementia. The molecular insights gained from this research will decipher the relationship between progranulin, lysosomes, and frontotemporal dementia, providing potential therapeutic target to develop disease- modifying treatments for FTD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondrial diseases, the most common group of inherited metabolic disorders, are caused by impairment of oxidative phosphorylation and manifest with severe myopathic and neurological features. Although the energetic defects arising from genetic errors in nuclear and mitochondrial DNA are often known, metabolic targets and many aspects of disease pathogenesis are yet to be elucidated and therefore no proven effective treatments or cures are available. This project investigates the metabolic consequences of oxidative phosphorylation dysfunction and focuses on the development of novel metabolism-based strategies to treat mitochondrial myopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-HSCT) is a potentially life-saving option for many blood disorders, however, it is often complicated by graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) which occurs when the donor’s cells (the graft) perceive the recipient’s healthy cells (the host) as foreign and attack and destroy them. GvHD is spurred by the presence of minor histocompatibility antigens (mHAgs) – proteins found on donor cells that provoke a rejection response if genetically different from the recipient’s cells – often arising from a common type of genetic variation known as nonsynonymous single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs). We hypothesize that the identification of tissue-specific mHAgs on an individual recipient-donor basis, predicted through analysis of patient and donor DNA, can enable personalized risk assessment of GvHD, improve current donor selection algorithms and enable personalized tailoring of post-transplant immunosuppression in accordance to patient- specific GvHD risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increasing the number of under-represented minority (URM) PhDs trained in the behavioral, or neurosciences increases diversity in the biomedical workforce. This ENDURE application will facilitate entry into biomedical PhD programs for URM students, by a focus on preparing them as undergrads for admission to competitive, high quality, PhD programs and success once admitted. Research experiential and didactic training, along with increased attention to writing, research literature evaluation and oral presentation at the ENDURE Meeting will ensure that this ENDURE program continues to facilitate entry of URM students into neuroscience PhD programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The Data Coordination Center (DCC) will have scientific and coordination responsibilities for the Clinical Centers, NIDDK Project Scientist, and oversight bodies for the consortium studying the Physiology of the Weight Reduced State. The DCC will provide scientific, analytical, logistical, and administrative expertise to support the consortium which will include a weight loss intervention and weight loss maintenance study “to elucidate the physiology of the weight reduced state and the mechanisms of individual variability in weight maintenance.” This includes study design, implementation and monitoring, data management, data analysis, interpreting and reporting findings, facilitating ancillary studies, and tracking and archiving data and biospecimens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  There are currently no disease modifying therapies for the spinocerebellar ataxias. One important barrier for development of new therapies for spinocerebellar ataxia and other neurodegenerative diseases is the lack of tools to objectively and sensitively measure a beneficial clinical response to a drug. This project aims to develop systems based on everyday technologies and sophisticated computational methods to provide accessible tools for early detection, precise severity measurement, and prediction of disease progression in spinocerebellar ataxias.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Almost half of the women of reproductive age in the U.S. are deficient in iodine. We will apply advanced novel methods to measure urinary iodine in women during preconception and throughout pregnancy and in the placenta to estimate the effects of iodine deficiency before and during pregnancy on critical reproductive and perinatal health outcomes including infertility, pregnancy loss, preterm delivery, and birth size. Iodine is a low- cost intervention, that could be used to target women at risk for adverse outcomes.
