IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Project Narrative In 2050, people older than 65 will be almost double the number in 2012, increasing the importance of late life cognitive functions, which in animals depend on new neuron production in the hippocampus, the ability of new neurons to connect in brain circuits, and brain regional blood flow. There have been controversial finings regarding the ability of the human hippocampus to make new neurons throughout our lifespan, and data suggest that aging is associated with decreased connections between neurons, and reduced blood supply in the neurogenic niche, which can affect brain function. The proposed research will, for the first time, identify molecular features of the hippocampus neurogenic niche, providing anatomical mapping of gene and protein expression at the single-cell level, and allow studying changes occurring across the human lifespan in normally aging individuals from adolescence to over 90 years of age, and compare healthy aging with Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) reside on the cell surface positioned to receive a wide range of cues (from photons to odors to hormones) and to elicit a response in the corresponding cell. GPCRs are targets of an estimated 34% of all currently approved drugs, yet we do not fully understand the events upstream or downstream of their activation. This proposal will determine how a single GPCR functions in the development of two very different organs and it identifies other GPCRs that also function in these same organs.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Assisted Reproductive Technology (ART) is a widespread treatment for infertility, over 300,000 treatment cycles were performed in the US in 2018, but success rates remain low. In this project, we will develop novel machine learning algorithms and a clinical decision support system to assist embryologists in embryo selection. Our tools will also enable embryologists and biologists to obtain new information on the earliest stages of human embryo development, which will advance the fundamental science of human biology and lead to further improvements in ART practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project studies how cognitive and functional reserve may reduce the clinical consequences of brain changes due to Alzheimer's disease (AD), cerebrovascular disease, and associated disorders. The public health goals of this project are to identify behavioral and lifestyle factors across the life span that promote reserve and protect people against the effects of AD and related diseases. Racial/ethnic minority groups may bare a disproportion burden of these diseases, and understanding factors that promote cognitive health in these groups is a national priority.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: There is an urgent need to develop new therapies against KRAS-mutant lung cancer (KMLC) based on a better understanding of how KMLC cells maintain their survival and gain metastatic capacity. On the basis of the preliminary results presented here, we postulate that 2 types of collagen modifications by lysyl hydroxylase 2, an enzyme that is highly expressed in KMLC cells, drive tumor progression and metastasis. If proven true, these findings would advance our understanding of the mechanisms of KMLC progression and would provide a rationale to develop and test the efficacy of selective antagonists of lysyl hydroxylase 2 in KMLC patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed inception cohort study CAMEO will be unique in providing a robust, novel platform to study clinical and biological factors that contribute to bowel healing in pediatric Crohn's disease that can then be immediately translated into clinical practice, as well as guiding future therapies targeting the host immune responses and microbiota in patients unlikely to achieve healing with current approaches. Achieving higher rates of bowel healing will improve quality of life, mitigate need for surgery and hospitalizations, and potentially reduce long term healthcare expenditures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant for public health, because the expected results of the proposed experiments will inform models for cortical coding of location and movement speed supporting memory-guided navigation. Innovative experiments will investigate the contribution of different sensory modalities to the encoding of a cognitive map and modulation of encoding and retrieval by the neuromodulator acetylcholine. The project is relevant to NIMH's mission, because the expected results will contribute to our mechanistic understanding of the cognitive processes underlying the coding of location for memory function and the role of cholinergic modulation underlying these processes, which are altered in psychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia and major depressive disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A growing body of evidence including our own studies suggest that biological differences contribute to the lower treatment response and poorer survival experienced by African American women with Triple Negative Breast Cancer (TNBC), an aggressive breast cancer subset. We have established a highly synergistic inter- institution collaboration in order to enable detailed molecular analysis of TNBCs in African American women and to correlate the findings with treatment outcomes. These studies will be complemented by experiments to test new treatment approaches and find predictive biomarkers, all focused on developing more effective and personalized approaches to treatment of TNBC in the African American population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Nucleotide repeat expansions in C9-ALS/FTD produce toxic DPR proteins that are synthesized from an unusual initiation codon but are elongated by the classical ribosomal machinery using components of the tRNA pool one codon at a time. Little is known how the composition of the tRNA pool affects the disease outcome, although the repetitive use of a tRNA in high demand can deplete its charging with the cognate amino acid and its maturation with necessary modifications. Here, we will determine the quality of the tRNA pool in patient- derived and in control cells between the iPSC and the differentiated iPSN state to provide new insight that is important for understanding the disease and for exploring new therapeutic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed work seeks to answer important outstanding questions about the function and regulation of the actin cytoskeleton using infectious microbes as cell-biological tools. The actin cytoskeleton plays critical roles in basic cell features and behaviors including shape, migration, division, and intracellular transport, and its misregulation is a crucial contributor to pathogenesis, for example, in inflammation, cardiovascular disease, cancer metastasis, and microbial infection. Therefore, understanding actin regulation and function may lead to new approaches for diagnosing and treating human disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Eunice Kennedy Shriver NICHD Neonatal Research Network works collaboratively to conduct large multicenter clinical trials and observational studies to facilitate the conduct of neonatal medicine, with the goal of improving the health of low birth weight and premature infants. Sharp Mary Birch Hospital for Women & Newborns, and its satellite Sharp Grossmont Hospital; both Level III NICUs, can contribute academically and provide top-level enrollment of participants as a clinical center – Sharp Neonatal Research Institute (NRI). The Sharp NRI, through its highly experienced investigative team and history of successful participation in multiple published clinical trials, offers the Network an exceptional environment for an outstanding research institute that will help will expedite enrollment and help assure high neurodevelopmental follow-up compliance in current and future Network trials.

PHR: Project Narrative We propose a proof-of-concept trial in Parkinson disease (PD) to test whether 2 years of citalopram, compared to placebo, can alter the build-up of toxic amyloid-beta plaques in the visuospatial cortex of the brain linked to visuospatial cognitive impairment in PD. This project is relevant to public health because it aims to test and validate a new approach to reduce biomarkers related to dementia risk in a common neurologic condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer mortality with a 5-year survival rate of less than 20% following standard of care treatment. There is strong evidence that targeted delivery of inhaled chemotherapy medication to the lung at a fraction of the current dose will have a major impact on increasing survival and reducing lung tumor burden in lung cancer patients with far less side effects than those associated with current systemic intravenous chemotherapy. Based on preliminary data, we will develop a novel inhaled chemotherapy treatment in order to directly target pulmonary tumors in order to improve survival in lung cancer patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Premature birth is a major socioeconomic problem that affects 10-15% of pregnancies and causes 70-80% of neonatal mortality and morbidity. Clearly, the final phase of fetal development is best achieved in a healthy womb environment rather than in the neonatal intensive care unit. To this end, we must develop effective treatments to prevent preterm birth. Our goal is to elucidate the mechanism by which the steroid hormone progesterone exerts anti-inflammatory effects in uterine smooth muscle cells to promote uterine relaxation and quiescence for most of pregnancy, and how those actions are withdrawn to induce parturition; especially inflammation-induced preterm labor. The proposed research tests a novel mechanism by which inflammatory stimuli induce preterm labor by modulating progesterone signaling in myometrial cells via progesterone receptor phosphorylation. A clear understanding of this process may reveal novel therapeutic targets to decrease the burden of prematurity by lowering the risk for inflammation-induced preterm birth.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The NICHD Neonatal Research Network was established by the NICHD in 1986 to rapidly design, conduct, and publish clinical studies to improve the health of neonates. We are one of only two centers that have continuously contributed to the NRN in every cycle since 1986. Our medical and nursing staffs firmly believe that patients benefit from research. Our large diverse inborn delivery service with essentially no loss to back transport is ideal for neonatal clinical trials. We eagerly anticipate participating in the next cycle of the NRN and will continue to lead and innovate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In diabetes mellitus, downstream complications such as diabetic neuropathy and vascular damage lead to impaired wound healing, which can result in severe, non-healing ulcers of the lower extremities that may require amputation. Advances in wound healing research have identified some potential mechanisms for this impaired healing, but treatments for diabetic ulcers are lacking in comparison to the overall improvement in the management of diabetes. To that end, this work aims to further understand the inherent deficits in diabetic skin by determining the effects of topically applied novel small molecule NRF2 activators on wound healing and tissue integrity in diabetic wounds and investigating the mechanisms driving their effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative  Image guided surgery is widely used to safely navigate around complex structures like the ethmoid bone and critical structures such as the brain; its utility is greatly enhanced when coupled with intraoperative radiographic imaging because the anatomic changes caused by surgery are clearly elucidated and can be incorporated into the surgical plan. This project will develop computational methods that exploit readily available endoscopic video to improve the accuracy of navigation and to provide intraoperative updates to the anatomic model. This technology will enhance surgical decisions in the operating room and enable precise navigation throughout the surgery without the need for additional radiologic imaging in the operating room.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To capture the expression profile of patients diagnosed with frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), we will employ an innovative sequencing technology. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: CENTRE FOR RESEARCH IN INFECTIOUS DISEASES - CRID
PHR: Project Narrative The use of neonicotinoids in agricultural pest management is contributing to reduce the susceptibility of mosquito populations to clothianidin, a neonicotinoid recently approved for use in indoor residual spraying targeting malaria vectors. Our project aims to test whether the utility of clothianidin in public health is currently being threatened in some agricultural regions in Africa. This research will be very important to preserve the efficacy of this active ingredient in malaria vector control. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Hepatitis B virus-related hepatocellular carcinoma (HBV+ HCC) attributes to 85% of all HCC cases in China, and therapeutic options are limited. This project will forge a collaboration between a computational team in the US and an HCC oncology team in China to perform comprehensive molecular characterization of a large Chinese HBV+ HCC cohort using the new proteogenomic approach that systematically integrates genomics and mass spectrometry-based proteomics data. This collaborative project will produce new biomarkers, drug targets, and therapeutic agents for the prognosis and treatment of HCC as well as experimentally validated computational methods that can be broadly applied to proteogenomic studies in other cancer types and other diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent landmark studies have provided evidence that “small vessel” coronary dysfunction in patients with otherwise normal coronary arteries is a major cause of heart disease and can lead to poor health outcomes including heart failure. This research proposal seeks to develop a noninvasive approach for diagnosis and monitoring of small-vessel coronary dysfunction by developing innovative and reliable magnetic resonance imaging strategies. Our proposal has the potential to improve patient care in this population by providing a noninvasive alternative to the established invasive testing procedure, which carries a risk of complications and is only available at highly specialized medical centers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Smoking, drinking, and illicit drug use are major sources of morbidity and mortality in the population, and all of these behaviors tend to begin in adolescence. Monitoring the Future (MTF) has played a vital role in measuring, tracking, and understanding these behaviors among American adolescents and adults from 1975 through the present. This application is to continue this important work from 2022/23 through 2026/27 by conducting annual, national surveys of 8th, 10th, and 12th grade students that include questions on more than 50 categories of substances, and analyzing these data in conjunction with longitudinal data from the existing and new MTF panels (a companion R01 application requests funding to continue to collect panel data).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: We currently know very little about the cells that make up our eardrum, how they function to help us hear, or how problems with them cause diseases of the ear. This study uses cutting edge molecular tools to gain a deeper understanding of what these cells are and how they function. With a better understanding of these cells, we should be able to come up with better treatments for patients currently suffering of diseases of the ear canal and eardrum.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Via our long-standing efforts to develop novel approaches for the better management and prevention of otitis media (OM), we have extensively characterized the functionality of antibodies directed against two unique biofilm-associated determinants of nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae (NTHI) that both prevent biofilm formation and, uniquely, disrupt pre-existing biofilms in vitro and in vivo. Action of these antibodies release this predominant otopathogen from its protected residence within the biofilm into a highly vulnerable ‘newly released’ (NRel) state, a recently discovered phenotype which is the most sensitive to killing by traditional antibiotics, and extends our understanding beyond the heretofore believed duality that bacteria responsible for chronic and recurrent diseases exist only in either a ‘planktonic’ or ‘biofilm-resident’ state. In consideration of a recent paradigm shift, wherein thought leaders have challenged us to consider new ways to combine the power of induced immunity with the more considered use of antibiotics as our “last hope against multi-drug resistant bacteria and persistent disease” as a means to achieve the strongest possible therapeutic outcome, herein we have designed studies that will expand upon compelling preliminary data to use specifically targeted antibodies to force recalcitrant biofilm-resident NTHI into the highly vulnerable NRel state so they can now be readily eliminated, and thereby leverage our new understanding to more effectively combat NTHI-induced OM and multiple other diseases caused by this high priority, antibiotic-resistant pathogen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Next generation multipurpose prevention technologies that comprise of contraceptive and HIV prevention are urgently needed especially among at-risk women. We propose to develop a long-acting nanofluidic implant offering 2-year constant contraceptive and antiretroviral co-delivery, in a discreet, user-independent and safe manner for long-term use. Successful completion of our proposed work will yield a dual prevention product for advancement towards clinical development to provide women a single, convenient approach to protect their sexual and reproductive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Sleep dysfunction is common and disabling across a wide range of neurological and psychiatric conditions, leading to worsening daytime symptoms, accelerating disease progression and marking a major public health challenge. In patients with Parkinson’s disease, we will use chronically implanted cortical and basal ganglia electrodes plus sensing-enabled closed-loop Deep Brain Stimulation to evaluate which neural structures, signals and connections are disrupted by pathological oscillations in sleep. Understanding the fundamental mechanisms of sleep dysfunction represents a key knowledge gap preventing forward progress in developing precision neuromodulation therapies for sleep, secondary motor / non-motor symptoms and potentially disease progression in Parkinson’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Arthritis in the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) refers to the degradation of the cartilage and death of cells in the joint. In this proposal, we define how degradation of cartilage is communicated to the cell and how this process suppresses mechanisms that protect against cell death. This work will define new mechanisms that initiate TMJ arthritis and new potential therapeutic targets to attenuate or reverse the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) is a cancer of the immature myeloid cells of the bone marrow. Current treatments are associated with significant, even life threatening, side effects. This project will define the role of the CBFB-MYH11 oncogene and its co-factor HDAC1 in regulating leukemia maintenance, and test whether inhibitors of these proteins have the potential to cure CBFB-MYH11 driven AML. Successful completion of this project will provide important new insights into the biology of leukemia cells and lead to significant improvements in the treatment of AML.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Efficient synthesis of thyroid hormone requires the secretion and iodination of the thyroglobulin protein; failure to secrete thyroglobulin leads to hypothyroidism. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While it is known that stress can cause proteins to go to wrong locations inside the cell, the biochemical mechanisms and consequences are mostly unknown. We will characterize the causes, mechanisms, protein substrates, and consequences of stress-dependent secretory protein mistargeting inside human cells. The outcome will be to reveal how this stress-induced secretory protein mistargeting is related to the maintenance of human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Behavioral Activation (BA) psychotherapy has emerged as a first-line treatment for adolescent depression, yet the underlying neurobiological mechanisms of BA’s efficacy remain unclear. A fuller understanding of BA’s targets of treatment engagement requires multiple assessments linking trajectories of behavioral and symptom change with trajectories of change in these neural circuits over the course of therapy as opposed to just pre/post comparisons. This study will provide insights that can be used to develop new treatment biomarkers, inform BA treatment augmentation, further novel treatment development, and facilitate precision-based psychotherapy interventions to more effectively treat this major public health problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric acute respiratory distress syndrome (PARDS) is a form of severe lung injury that causes acute respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation (artificial respiration) in thousands of US children per year. While poorly studied in children, injurious mechanical ventilation practices have been associated with the development of new or progressive multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (NPMODS) and higher mortality in adults with ARDS. This proposal will use novel approaches to investigate the associations between mechanical ventilation management, NPMODS, and post-intensive care unit morbidity to identify focused mechanical ventilation interventions to target in future clinical trials in children with PARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast cancer is the most frequently diagnosed cancer in women. Advances in its detection and treatment have substantially increased long-term survival among patients with breast cancer, but there is considerable individual variability in the progression of the disease and the extent to which it dysregulates other important biological systems. The goal of the proposed research is to determine how tumors alter sleep and metabolism, which in turn can further compromise the health and well-being of breast cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Individuals with psychosis are less motivated than healthy individuals to exert effort to obtain rewards on experimental tasks, deficits which are related to symptoms of amotivation and function in everyday life, but individuals with depression do not despite showing reduced responses to rewards. Here we extend our work to examine: a) the processes that contribute to social as well as monetary motivation; b) the differential role of dopamine function in psychosis versus mood pathology; and c) the longitudinal relations between cognitive control and motivation in the everyday lives of individuals with psychosis and mood pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer cells encase themselves in a soft material coating, termed the cellular glycocalyx, with specific properties that protect against recognition and destruction by the immune system. In this project, we will investigate the mechanisms through which the cancer cell glycocalyx physically protects against attack by Natural Killer (NK) cells, key frontline defenders of the human immune system that guard against cancer. The new mechanistic insight will inform the development of engineered NK cell therapeutics that are intended to overcome the protective glycocalyx barrier of cancer cells and improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Primary care access and continuity of care improve outcomes for older adults with multimorbidity (multiple chronic conditions), so a recent decline in primary care office visit rates – likely due in part to barriers attending office visits – raises concerns about these two core functions of high-value outpatient care. The proposed study will determine if multimorbid older adults with Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and AD-related dementia (AD/ADRD) and social risk factors were at greater risk of office visit barriers; assess how expansion of virtual care catalyzed by the Covid-19 pandemic affects primary care use for those with AD/ADRD and social risk factors; and determine whether a novel continuity measure that includes virtual care is associated with preventable hospitalizations among multimorbid older adults. The results of this research – using national claims-linked Medicare survey data and claims-linked electronic health record data in a large Medicare Accountable Care Organization – will identify policy and delivery changes needed to promote high-value outpatient care and improve outcomes among multimorbid older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The percentage of the US population over the age of 60 is growing steadily, and issues affecting quality of life and mobility of the elderly are of significant concern. Tendinopathy in later stage aging may be impacted by adolescent exercise, but the relationship between these phenomena is not well understood. This project aims to test if early life exercise relates to improved tendon performance in late life, and seeks to understand the contributing mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because over 20 million people worldwide suffer from focal drug-resistant epilepsy and are potential candidates for cure with epilepsy surgical interventions or devices. Upon successful completion of the proposed research, we expect our contribution to be the development of a biomarker to predict outcomes to responsive neurostimulation device therapy for epilepsy. Our findings may inform physicians and patients on the most effective therapy for an individual patient with drug-resistant epilepsy and pave the way to bringing quantitative rigor into clinical decision making for epilepsy patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol-associated liver disease affects several million people in the United States. Gut-derived bacterial products are necessary for progression of alcohol-associated liver disease, but changes in the intestinal fungi are poorly characterized. Understanding the mechanisms by which intestinal fungi promote alcohol-associated liver disease would greatly enhance our ability to design preventive and therapeutic interventions for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Breast cancer ranks second among cancer deaths in women in the United States. In this project, we will examine the underlying mechanisms of how profilin1, a major actin cytoskeleton regulatory protein, controls the early steps of breast cancer metastasis. Specifically, we will identify how Pfn1 dysregulation alters the signaling pathways at the cell membrane-cytosol interface to promote specific dissemination-promoting steps leading to tumor cell escape from the primary tumor. A successful completion of this study will yield novel insights into fundamental tumor cell biology, provide molecular underpinnings of basic adenocarcinoma behaviors that lead to progression in metastatic breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative PTH1-34 (Teriparatide, Forteo®) and Abaloparatide (Tymlos®) target the PTH receptor and are approved anabolic drugs for Osteoporosis, a widespread bone fragility chronic condition linked to aging and characterized by dysfunctions of cells in bone, often associated with an increase in bone marrow fat. Bone forming cells (osteoblasts) and fat cells (adipocytes) share a common precursor, and understanding PTH influence on the choice of cells to become a bone or a fat cell is important for the development of future treatments for osteoporosis, fracture healing as well as for the cell therapy aimed at bone regeneration. This grant will investigate whether preventing bone marrow fat will favor bone formation in response to PTH treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative  We propose to design, pilot test, and validate the efficacy of innovative new multivariate protocols for estimating risk for fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD). In the R61 Phase we will research, create, design, and pilot test new protocols for: 1) interviewing mothers (with biomarker validation) to determine daily/weekly prenatal alcohol exposure across pregnancy and postpartum alcohol use during breastfeeding; 2) determining maternal experience with stress, trauma, and mental health status during pregnancy and their contribution to FASD diagnostic traits; 3) interviewing fathers regarding paternal traits that contribute to risk for FASD; and 4) establishing a comprehensive, summary FASD risk score from the above innovations when combined with multiple other empirically-established variables of risk. The R33 Phase will draw on our existing clinical epidemiology infrastructure, the experience of our multi-disciplinary team, and the participants in existing longitudinal cohorts to assess the efficacy of multivariate FASD risk assessment in two applications: A) a multivariate assessment of FASD risk via a prospective study of 200 women recruited from prenatal clinics, and their offspring who will be assessed postpartum for FASD traits; and B) and linking retrospectively-collected multivariate FASD risk information with data from two existing cohorts of mothers and their children who have been previously assessed for FASD and the severity of their physical, neurodevelopmental, and behavioral traits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease is considered the most costly and burdensome disease in the U.S, and its public health impact will only grow with the increase of older adults in the next decade. Despite the protracted progression of AD brain pathology, little is known about its early temporal course from middle to older age, particularly for in vivo neuroimaging indices. With neuroimaging, cognitive, and biomarker data beginning when participants were in their 50s, the longitudinal VETSA MRI project stands to advance progress toward early identification, and in turn, toward improving quality of life and reducing societal burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our genetic information must be duplicated accurately each time a cell in our body divides and distributed appropriately to the daughter cells in order to prevent the accumulation of mutations and preserve the integrity of the genome. This proposal seeks to understand how various pathways that act to preserve genomic integrity during DNA replication operate and interact with one another and how the topoisomerases and condensins that manage chromosome conformation and segregation cooperate to accomplish their task.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rooted in life course developmental theory, the proposed study examines how disruptions related to the COVID-19 pandemic are associated with immediate and longitudinal changes in adolescents' and their parents' alcohol and other substance use. Testing life course principles about developmental timing, linked lives, and cumulative disadvantage, we will specifically investigate how the timing of COVID-19 pandemic- induced disruptions, other family members' substance use patterns, and youth's personal, dispositional, and relational qualities shape teens' alcohol and other substance use trajectories over the arc of the pandemic. Understanding how adolescents and parents suffered, adapted, and coped with pandemic challenges is critical for developing responses to other public health emergencies, including economic crises and natural disasters, for anticipating long-term trends in alcohol and other substance use among the current cohort of adolescents, and for supporting recovery from this era.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Transplant-associated thrombotic microangiopathy (TA-TMA) is an often-fatal hematologic disorder without an effective treatment currently. This project aims to provide a better understanding of the epidemiology and risk factors for this rare disease and to design and test a dynamic risk prediction tool through a prospective cohort study. Results of this proposal will be helpful to the understanding of the disease and the design of future interventional trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current application is a comprehensive analysis of prenatal maternal risk factors (alcohol use, smoking, depression, and anxiety), as well as deep phenotyping of infant electrophysiological/physiological data, and associations with neurobehavioral outcomes. It will use extant data from ~11,000 participants from the Safe Passage Study and extant neurodevelopmental outcome data from a subset of participants at 12 months and 24-37 months of age. Findings will have important implications for public health by documenting the effects of prenatal maternal substance abuse and psychological health on shaping children’s cognitive and social- emotional development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative There is a pressing need to find new compounds to help manage pain due to the ongoing opioid epidemic, and plants, being a source of other analgesic drugs, provide a useful starting point for discovering such compounds. Aconitum is a plant species used in traditional Chinese medicine that produces analgesic diterpenoid alkaloids, while American medicinal Aconitum species also produce diterpenoid alkaloids, but have not been explored in detail for analgesic properties. This project will analyze eight Aconitum species, specifically regarding their analgesic diterpenoid alkaloids that lack cardiotoxicity, with the goal of identifying lead compounds for future preclinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) which is the fourth leading cause of kidney failure is characterized by development of multiple cysts, hollow sacks containing liquid, which replace normal tissues and lead to kidney failure. Growing evidence suggests that high ATP level in the cysts is involved in PKD progression but the origins and pathogenic effects of the ATP accumulation in cysts remains unknown. If funded, the proposed project would contribute to fundamental knowledge and provide a strong evidential base for targeting purinergic signaling in ADPKD treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Social behavior deficits are key features of many psychiatric disorders, yet little is known about how the brain controls normal social behaviors. I propose to dissect the role of the medial prefrontal cortex circuits in social dominance by combining wireless electrophysiology, calcium imaging, optogenetics and machine learning. This study will broaden our understanding of how neural circuits control normal social behaviors and will contribute to the identification of novel interventions for social deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) is a deadly hematologic malignancy that results from the progressive acquisition of mutations over time. Mutations in the hematopoietic transcription factor CEBPA must precede mutations in the cytokine receptor CSF3R in order for leukemia to develop. This proposal seeks to understand the mechanism of this order dependent leukemia development and leverage this understanding to develop novel therapeutics.

PHR: Project Narrative: High levels of cholesterol are linked to many chronic diseases including heart disease, type II diabetes and fatty liver disease. We have generated novel mouse models where cells in the body have lost the ability to respond to changes in cholesterol. When fed a high cholesterol diet these mice rapidly develop liver disease and will provide a new model system to study how cholesterol influences many chronic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project addresses the critical need for an accurate rapid, point-of-care test for Chagas disease. This parasitic infection has emerged as a threat to public health and the blood supply both within the U.S. and internationally, yet only one FDA-cleared, commercial rapid test for Chagas disease is currently available. In Phase II, we propose to complete development of a Chagas disease lateral flow rapid test based on native antigens of the parasite. We will carry out a clinical study to support a 510(k) submission to FDA, and achieve clearance of the Chagas point-of-care test for in vitro diagnosis of infected individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reports on resurgence in Plasmodium falciparum malaria cases, after years of control, indicates that a highly efficacious vaccine is needed, yet, promising malaria vaccines first tested in high income countries, show disappointing results in endemic areas. Our multi-omics technologies that has uncovered the importance of baseline immunological profiles to predict vaccine induced and naturally acquired immunity, will be applied to malaria vaccine cohorts from diverse geographical areas to understand malaria vaccine (hypo)responsiveness. The knowledge will build a strong foundation for developing an improved malaria vaccine with high efficacy in malaria endemic areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PBTC Project Narrative The Pediatric Brain Tumor Consortium (PBTC) conducts novel and innovative clinical trials for Pediatric Central Nervous System (CNS) malignancies that incorporate correlative biology, genomics, pharmacology and sophisticated imaging techniques to advance the understanding of high-risk and recurrent pediatric brain tumors. PBTC trials are designed to define appropriate dosing, describe pediatric-specific toxicities and tumor biology as well as to identify early signals of efficacy, thereby directly impacting future prognostication and treatment strategies. It is only through this continued prospective and systematic drug development via early phase clinical trials that the overarching goal of achieving longer, healthier lives with less morbidity can ultimately be realized for children with CNS tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative This proposal is focused on examining the role of surface sensing in Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilm formation and pathogenesis as it relates to chronic infection. The expression of several key biofilm matrix components are known to be initiated upon interaction with a surface. This proposal will address gaps in our knowledge as to how surface sensing works and its contribution to pathogenesis; future therapeutic strategies (particularly ones directed towards biofilm communities) will benefit from such knowledge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Ovarian cancer remains the most deadly gynecological malignancy facing women, with a 5-year survival rate of less than 28% for advanced stage patients with marked peritoneal metastatic spread. For successful metastasis to occur, tumor cells must adapt to survive anchorage independence in the hostile environment of the peritoneal cavity. Our work focuses on novel mitochondrial signaling pathways that regulate cell survival adaptations during ovarian cancer metastasis and will delineate if these can be exploited to therapeutically target metastatic ovarian cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Glial cells were long considered to serve merely in a supportive role for neuronal cell function. Recent evidence, however, indicates that glial cells are intimately involved in many of the brain's functions, including memory formation. The goal of this project is to understand a key epigenetic mechanism that contributes to gene transcription in astrocytes while considering the potential of manipulating this process to increase resiliency in aging populations including Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Mutations in the polycystin genes lead to one of the most common human genetic disorders, Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease. Here we propose to uncover the molecular role and the regulation of polycystin during the last stage of cell division cytokinesis using the model organism fission yeast.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The majority of breast cancer deaths result from metastatic disease. Accumulated evidence indicates that breast tumor cells invade as complex, heterogeneous clusters rather than single cells and to do so they are led by cells called leader cells. How these leader cells develop to lead directed collective migration, and whether this phenomenon is necessary and sufficient to effect directed collective migration is largely unknown. This is a focus of the current proposal.

PHR: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) can be transmitted from mother to fetus causing significant disabilities. It is important to find strategies that will either prevent or lessen the risk of virus acquisition for women, thus reducing the risk of damaging congenital CMV infection in their infants. The proposed project seeks to prevent maternal CMV infections by increasing CMV risk-reduction behaviors in urban pregnant women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Pain is currently the most common cause of long-term disability in the United States, affecting over 70 million Americans and 1.5 billion people worldwide. The first line of treatment for pain has been opioids, however their use is associated with addiction, dependence and overdose. The objective of this proposal is to rigorously and mechanistically explore the role of an important motivational circuit in inflammatory pain driven changes in behavior, with the long term goal of identifying a novel circuit target for treatment of inflammatory pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The incidence of type 1 diabetes (T1D), an autoimmune disease which affects millions of people worldwide, has been rising for the past half century. While both genetic and environmental factors contribute to the risk of developing T1D, recent studies indicate that early-life microbial interactions with the developing immune system offer a critical window of opportunity to influence the immune system’s development to prevent disease. Our study uses an innovative approach that leverages a community of early life microbes to identify microbial products and immune system pathways that may lead to therapies to prevent the development of T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative  Uveal melanoma (UM) is the most common malignant eye tumor in adults. In approximately half of the patients, the cancer cells metastasize to the liver despite using either surgery or radiation to control tumors in the eye, and this tumor spread leads to patient demise. This SBIR focuses on advancing a safe and effective drug called 64B that inhibits the function of hypoxia inducible factors (HIFs) and improves tumor control in preclinical models of UM. Based on its novel mechanism of action and pre-clinical demonstrations of stand-alone therapeutic efficacy and synergy with other oncologic therapeutics, our goal is to advance 64B into clinical trials for use in humans in combination with another oncologic therapeutic drug to improve quality of life and longevity in patients with high risk and metastatic UM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetes is known to be highly heterogeneous with various phenotypes, causes and outcomes. Current effective subtyp- ing of diabetes is limited due to the inability of modeling complex disease variables potentially interconnected across multiple modalities of patient data. This project develops a novel and practical analytic tool to understand the hetero- geneity of diabetes to enhance its precise detection, in-depth analysis and personalized treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma (GBM) is an incurable primary brain cancer with a median age at diagnosis of 65 years old and the mechanisms through which advanced age suppress cell intrinsic and extrinsic factors allowing for maintenance and outgrowth of GBM cancer stem cells (CSCs) is unexplored. We recently discovered that the redox gasotransmitter, hydrogen sulfide (H2S), which decreases during advanced age and is suppressed by thyroid hormone activity, enhances immune surveillance and functions as a tumor suppressor in subjects with GBM. By integrating our team’s collective expertise in GBM, CSCs, and H2S, we will interrogate how advanced age changes the brain microenvironment to favor CSC survival and outgrowth through deficiencies in H2S signaling while also leveraging anti-thyroid hormone approaches to reverse H2S declines and improve GBM outcomes in pre-clinical models.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High stress during pregnancy has tremendously negative consequences for women’s ability to sensitively care for their infants, as well as derails maternal mental health. Very little is known about how stress is processed by the maternal brain to cause these negative effects, but it may do so through the stress-signaling molecule, corticotropin releasing factor (CRF), interacting with the brain’s serotonin system. Greater knowledge about CRF-serotonin interactions in the maternal brain will greatly improve our ability to understand the mechanisms underlying peripartum stress, thus helping the millions of mothers struggling to care for their infants and suffering from poor mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementias are heritable, severe, and complex brain disorders character- ized by substantial clinical and biological heterogeneity. Thus far, we haven’t been able to fully leverage the whole spectrum of multi-omics datasets that have been generated from molecular profiling efforts to identify genetically driven gene dysregulation for dementias. This project will use cell-type and area specific imputed transcriptomes, proteomes and epigenomes for Alzheimer’s disease, frontotemporal lobar degeneration and dementia with Lewy bodies which will be integrated with a novel data-driven correlation-aware approach to- wards identifying key associated genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep-wake disturbances are a major factor associated with reduced quality of life of individuals with Parkinson's disease (PD), a progressive neurological disorder affecting millions of people in the U.S and worldwide. The brain mechanisms underlying these sleep disorders, and the effects of therapeutic interventions such as deep brain stimulation on sleep-related neuronal activity and sleep behavior, are not well understood. Results from this study will provide a better understanding of the brain circuitry involved in disordered sleep in PD and inform the development of targeted therapeutic interventions to treat sleep disorders in people with neurodegenerative disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibodies are proteins in the blood that protect against - and indicate past exposure to - pathogens, however the number of possible antibody targets is vast, making it difficult to develop a comprehensive view from a single blood sample. This project aims to develop a technology that enables antibodies against 100,000s of custom targets to be measured simultaneously using a small drop of blood, with an initial focus on antibodies that recognize any of the >300 viruses capable of infecting humans. Success in this project will provide a new and powerful tool for monitoring the immune response that will be broadly applicable for basic and clinical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Pancreatic cancer claims the lives of 47,000 Americans annually; therefore, understanding the mechanisms that contribute to the initiation and progression of this disease is of great significance. Previous work has demonstrated that MTOR signaling play an important role during pancreatic tumorigenesis and that inhibition of MTOR can prolong survival in model systems. The proposed project will assess the impact of inhibiting MTOR in established pancreatic tumors, thus potentially leading to the development of novel therapeutic strategies and thereby reducing the impact of this disease on public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol abuse is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide and recent data indicate that alcoholic liver disease affects over 10 million Americans. The overall goal of the Northern Ohio Alcohol Center (NOAC) is to identify specific molecular targets of ethanol-induced damage, as well as understand the complex adaptive and maladaptive responses of cells and systems to that damage. This information will enable us to target therapeutic interventions that will either slow and/or reverse the progression of disease in patients suffering from injury due to excessive alcohol consumption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE This research is relevant to public health and the mission of NIH, because it will evaluate the therapeutic potential of the transcription factor DFosB for combatting the effects of substance use disorder. To this end, we will delineate and then specifically target molecular features in DFosB in order to define the mechanisms by which they regulate drug addictive behaviors. The genetic models and chemical probes targeting DFosB developed in this proposal will also enable us to validate a dramatically novel strategy to mitigate drug addictive behaviors, which is important for addressing the opioid epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Human babesiosis is an emerging and potentially lethal infectious disease caused by eukaryotic pathogens of the genus Babesia. In our search for more potent and safer antibabesial drugs, we discovered that the clinically approved and safe antihypertensive drug fosinopril is a potent inhibitor of Babesia parasites in vitro and in animal models of babesiosis infection. Our proposed studies aim to develop analogs of this drug, determine their mode of action, and conduct efficacy studies to identify candidate drugs that could be advanced toward future clinical evaluation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE American Indian adults have a high burden of Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias- related comorbidities, however, bilingualism—also common among American Indian peoples and communities—may improve cognition and reduce risk. This project will build on the Strong Heart Study, a 30-year cohort of American Indian adults, in coordination with ongoing efforts funded by NHLBI, to assess the broad and heterogeneous continuum of bilingualism in American Indian peoples by culturally adapting the Language History Questionnaire; examine bilingualism in an estimated 2,500 American Indians in association with measures of fluid and crystallized cognition from the NIH Toolbox Cognition Battery, physical and mental status, and cultural factors; and construct conceptual models of intervariable relationships of bilingualism with cognition, including moderation by crystallized cognition. This study will illuminate a major public health concern in an understudied population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interstitial cystitis/bladder pain syndrome (IC/BPS) represents a potentially life-long chronic pain disorder that is challenging to diagnose, difficult to treat, and often results in a severely diminished quality-of-life. In this pilot and feasibility clinical trial, we will evaluate the safety and efficacy of a non-invasive therapeutic strategy, pulsed electromagnetic field (PEMF) therapy, for pain management in IC/BPS patient subgroups. The goal is to provide preliminary data that will lead to large, hypothesis-driven, multi-center clinical trials.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of this application is to leverage the exceptional clinician-scientists, research infrastructure, NICU Follow-up Program and diverse patient population of the Women and Infants Hospital of Rhode Island (WIH) to make important contributions to the Neonatal Research Network (NRN). Our current application highlights the significant contributions we have made to improving the outcomes of critically ill newborns since we joined the Network in 1991, and important changes we have made to our program and team of investigators to best invigorate and innovate our site. We aim to perform rigorous, systematic, multicenter studies to expand the evidence base for treatment of preterm and term infants and look forward to collaborating and data sharing with a broad range of centers across the Unites States as we work towards achieving the shared goal of improving healthcare and outcomes for newborns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE These studies will determine the extent to which macropinocytosis drives tumor growth and therapeutic resistance using pre-clinical metastatic breast cancer models. Completing these studies will clarify whether agents that limit macropinocytosis could have value as single agents or should be deployed in combination with other therapies. This work will also fill critical gaps in our knowledge of the signals that regulate macropinocytosis in solid tumor cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This study addresses gaps in knowledge and care delivery related to implementation of shared decision making for lung cancer screening with low-dose CT (LDCT) consistent with national guidelines. The research team will conduct a randomized trial to evaluate whether a workflow aware, telemedicine decision coaching and nurse navigation intervention improves quality decision making, adherence with screening and diagnostic testing, and referrals for smoking cessation. With well over 10 million US adults eligible for LDCT, there is a high potential for reducing the burden of lung cancer among heavy smokers by supporting high-quality decision making about LDCT and smoking cessation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Maternal alcohol abuse during pregnancy can result in a range of physical, mental, behavioral and learning disabilities termed as Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders. Efforts to successfully prevent or ameliorate the deleterious effects of maternal alcohol consumption have been impeded in part by a limited understanding of alcohol’s complex mechanisms of action involving multiple organ systems. The proposed R01 studies are designed to identify novel etiological molecular pathway(s) for FASD cardinal outcomes using integrative physiologic approaches.

PHR: Relevance Maternal birth injury clearly contributes to the development of pelvic floor disorders, yet we possess an incomplete understanding of the impact of maternal pelvic support adaptations, birth injury, and injury recovery on pelvic floor support. Using the novel approach of magnetomyography, our project will combine clinical, anatomic, and physiologic endpoints to improve our knowledge of maternal pelvic muscular adaptations and injury recovery patterns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are ~1,500 patients in the United States with autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD), a hepatorenal fibrocystic disorder due to mutations in PKHD1. Our proposed studies aim to understand how mice with Pkhd1 mutations have minimal kidney disease, while human patients with either missense or truncating PKHD1 mutations have severe renal cystic disease. This research has the potential to reveal novel, therapeutic strategies that can attenuate human PKHD1-related renal cystic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative All cells dynamically excrete into circulation nano-sized packages called extracellular vesicles (EVs), but this pathway can be hijacked by cancer cells for means of immune system suppression and metastasis. Innovative cross-disciplinary engineering methods are urgently needed to realize the diagnostic application of circulating cancer EVs to improve early detection of diseases like ovarian cancer, which do not have effective early screening tests. This project encompasses the design of highly multiplexed new nanoplasmonic probes for sensitive chemical fingerprinting of targeted circulating EVs, to ultimately improve the limit of detection for diagnosing ovarian cancer compared to conventional methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVES This project will prepare a new generation of Native Hawaiians and Pacific Islanders in the 7 US State and US- affiliated territories for careers in health and sciences under the One Health umbrella. In doing so, it will also expand and strengthen the science education capacity of Pacific high schools, and research and training at Pacific colleges. Importantly, It will raise community awareness of the intimate connections between the well beings of humans, animals and eco-environment where solutions to improve health for all can be found.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative/Relevance  This research is relevant to public health because it addresses the basic molecular mechanisms of how mutations in a brain-specific enzyme, protein kinase C gamma, result in aberrant function to cause the disease spinocerebellar ataxia. This enzyme transduces Ca2+ signals in the brain and understanding the structural basis for how mutations alter its structure and function will inform on potential therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Inadequate health literacy costs the U.S. economy $100-$200 billion annually, while Justice-involved African American, Black (AAB) and Hispanic adults (JIA) experience inadequate health literacy and structural racism that contributes to disparities in healthcare access and higher rates of acute and chronic conditions. The proposed project uses a longitudinal mixed-methods randomized clinical trial design to test the effectiveness of a coach-guided health literacy intervention (versus a self-study Control Group) to improve JIA’s health literacy and reduce their disparities in healthcare access. The proposed intervention has significant potential for increasing health literacy among JIA and thus improving the well-being of this sizeable and underserved community of >20 million U.S. persons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative: The benefits of cancer screening are uncertain for adults >75 years and there are known harms (e.g., anxiety due to false alarms and diagnosis and treatment of cancers that otherwise would never have caused problems in an older adult's lifetime); therefore, guidelines recommend that cancer screening decisions consider older adults' risk for cancer, 10-year life expectancy, and value and preferences. Yet, many adults >75 years are screened for cancer without being informed of the harms and with little chance of benefit; therefore, Dr. Schonberg's research and mentoring program aims to improve shared decision making around cancer screening among clinicians, older adults, and their involved family members. A NIA K24 would allow Dr. Schonberg to continue to build her patient oriented research program in shared decision making around cancer screening for older adults, to expand her mentorship program to prepare the next generation of aging researchers in shared decision making, and would help ensure broad implementation of her decision support tools thereby improving the care of older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The role of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-delta (PPAR-d) protein in cancer development needs to be defined to generate drugs to either inhibit or stimulate its function. Our proposed research will explore for the first time the role and molecular mechanisms of PPAR-d in gastric tumor development, as well as translational significance of molecular targeting PPAR-d signaling for gastric tumor intervention. The results of this proposal will provide much-needed information for developing new drugs to target this protein for cancer prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endothelial disease is a leading indication for corneal transplantation in the United States and around the world. Corneal transplantation techniques have evolved and improved rapidly in recent years, but there is no consensus on the best technique; additionally, endothelial cell loss after endothelial keratoplasty remains a concern. Here we propose a randomized clinical trial to evaluate two common selective endothelial keratoplasty techniques and determine the utility of topical rho-kinase inhibitors in preventing endothelial cell loss after corneal transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Both coding and noncoding RNAs can affect regulatory processes that go awry in Alzheimer’s disease (AD), though until now the focus has been on coding RNAs. Through isolation of synapses in the form of synaptosomes from in AD versus control frontal cortex tissue, we have identified a series of circular RNAs that are differentially expressed in genes critical for AD etiology including in GSK3B and PSEN2. We propose to interrogate the consequences of these circular RNAs to disease pathogenesis and their mechanism of action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative All physiological processes (including aging) involve processes across different time scales, but how the dynamics relate to the outcome is poorly understood. Without such understanding, it is difficult to engineer strategies of intervention, e.g., to slow age-related diseases. This project aims to build a fundamental understanding of the aging trajectory in an experimental system C. elegans; the approach and insights are likely applicable to aging and other long-term physiological processes in other systems including human.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Nucleic acids exhibit inherently unfavorable biopharmaceutical properties due to specific and non-specific interactions with proteins (enzyme stability, immunostimulation, coagulopathy, etc.), which hamper their development as therapeutic agents. Herein, we will investigate a novel mechanism for nucleic acid delivery based upon entropic protection (termed pacDNA), which facilitates duplex formation but disfavors protein binding (generally the first step leading to undesirable non-hybridization side effects). We will investigate and understand the molecular parameters that give rise to the unique properties of the pacDNA, probe its in vivo characteristics in mouse and non-human primates, and demonstrate improved efficacy in preclinical models for Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome over the state-of-the-art.

The Yale Liver Center's mission is to enhance knowledge of the etiology, diagnosis and treatment of liver diseases and other related disorders of the digestive system, thereby advancing the nation's public health. It does so by simulating both basic, translational and clinical research in this discipline at the University and by establishing core research facilities for use by multiple liver investigators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE PZQ monotherapy is used to treat schistosome infection, and so evolution of PZQ resistance is a major concern, and new drugs are urgently needed. We have developed a unique platform that I will use to examine drug response in individual field derived schistosomes. This will allow us to (i) examine the prevalence of PZQ resistance in the field and their contribution to treatment failure, (ii) to determine the genome regions underlying resistance, (iii) to determine the genes underlying resistance to other schistosome drugs under development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Teams of clinicians (physicians, nurses, physical therapists, etc.) provide care for the sickest patients in the hospital in intensive care units, but there is little consistency nationwide about who should be part of the team caring for these patients or how many patients an individual physician, nurse, or other ICU clinician can safely care for. Using survey data coupled with existing data on patients in intensive care units (ICUs), this study will describe current staffing patterns in ICUs in the US, identify the best team structures, and make workforce projections through 2050 to achieve optimal patient outcomes. This study has large public health implications as the demand for intensive care is expected to increase with an aging population; this study’s findings will aid in resource planning and policy initiatives to ensure patient safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Urolithiasis (or commonly known as urinary stone disease) is a benign but severely painful genitourinary disease that is on the rise and is the second most costly urologic condition in the US at over $2 billion per year. Despite the technology and technical advances in ureteroscopy (URS) with laser lithotripsy, shock wave lithotripsy (SWL) remains to be the only non-invasive modality for stone patients, easy to use, cost effective, and can often produce stone free rates comparable to URS. We propose to further advance the technology innovations in SWL by creating SAFE (Steerable and Adjustable Focusing Electrohydraulic) shock wave generators, 3D-DCM (3D- Dynamic Cavitation Monitoring) technology, and a miniature wet coupling (MiniCouple) device, applicable to most clinical shock wave lithotripters, to ensure the quality of shockwave source-patient interface for effective acoustic transmission, and to improve the overall treatment outcome while reducing tissue injury and procedure time .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative To understand the mechanism underlying seizures and mental deficits associated with alcohol withdrawal, we propose to investigate the novel hypothesis that altered structure and function of hippocampal newborn neurons underlies alcohol withdrawal seizures and mental deficits. Using state- of-the art methods to map synaptic, neuronal, and functional connectivity as well as to manipulate function of hippocampal neural circuits, we will unveil the direct role of newborn neurons in alcohol withdrawal-associated seizures, cognition, and emotion. Outcomes of this proposal will provide a foundation for understanding and treating alcohol withdrawal syndromes by specifically targeting altered neural circuits. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The rising incidence of obesity and associated metabolic diseases has increased the urgency of understanding the fundamental mechanisms controlling energy homeostasis, including those that drive healthy vs unhealthy fat tissue expansion in adults. The experiments described in this proposal will advance our understanding of the mechanisms controlling the activation and suppression of fat cell precursors in adults, and highlight the importance of previously unappreciated cell types that dictate fat tissue health and metabolic health in obesity. This knowledge will facilitate our attempts to derive novel therapeutic strategies to uncouple metabolic disease from obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Actinic keratoses are common pre-cancerous skin lesions that can transform into cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma and whose presence may also be associated with increased risk for other types of skin cancer (melanoma and basal cell carcinoma). In this project, we will determine the absolute risks of skin cancer over time in patients with actinic keratosis, which are unknown; assess what skin cancer related follow-up care is currently being provided to patients with actinic keratosis, which is uncharacterized; and develop a skin cancer risk prediction model for patients with actinic keratosis, which has not previously been done. Completion of this project will directly inform recommendations for skin cancer surveillance and early detection in patients with actinic keratosis, a high-risk group comprised of tens of millions of patients each year in the United States that has not been well-studied.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The scientific understanding of how genomes encode information is being revolutionized by a diverse class of experimental methods known as multiplex assays of variant effect (MAVEs). This proposal will develop a unified computational framework for analyzing the large datasets that MAVEs produce. Our methods will provide unprecedented quantitative insight into how genomic DNA encodes biologically critical information, thus advancing the clinical understanding of human genetic variation and accelerating the development of treatments for a wide range of diseases.

PHR: Predictive modeling is expected to become a cornerstone on the path to achieving precision/personalized medicine, as one of the key tasks here will be making individualized predictions of disease characteristics/phenotypes like subtype and risk of progression and/or recurrence. Successful accomplishment of the proposed work will contribute to the advancement of personalized/precision medicine through more accurate individualized prediction of disease characteristics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The landscape of biomedical research in the United States is changing, as are the composition and activities of the biomedical research workforce. With this evolution comes an increasing need to encourage talented medical students to pursue careers that will contribute to a better understanding of the factors that promote the diseases under investigation, the development of methodologies to predict and/or prevent disease progression, and the discovery of therapies that will help cure patients. The Summer Medical Research Internship (SMRI) at the University of Virginia addresses this need by providing medical student trainees with an immersive research experience within a rich allergy and infectious diseases research community that boasts strong and diverse basic science and opportunities for exposure to the practice and challenges of providing clinical care to patients. The overall goal of the SMRI is to provide our summer trainees with the knowledge, tools and motivation to consider how they might contribute to the discoveries of the future as physician-scientists and/or members of collaborative research teams.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The NICHD Neonatal Research Network (NRN) conducts randomized clinical trials and large-scale observational studies in critically ill newborns. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Our multidisciplinary team will leverage our collection of existing biospecimens from pregnant women and their neonates exposed to natural SARS-CoV-2 infection or COVID-19 mRNA vaccines to characterize the functional impact of maternal-fetal antibody transfer. We will investigate the fetal immunostimulatory activity by SARS-CoV-2 immune complexes, map the breadth of transfer of antiviral and autoreactive antibody epitopes, and identify placental biomarkers of differential antibody transfer. This project will generate data of immediate relevance to vaccine development to optimize protection for both the mother and fetus against SARS-CoV-2 and other emerging infections. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative - Relevance to Public Health  Otitis media (OM) is the most common childhood bacterial infection, accounting for 24.5 million visits and costing over $5 billion annually, and is also the leading cause of conductive hearing loss in children mainly caused by mucus overproduction, the hallmark of OM. Currently available vaccines have limited serotype coverage and inappropriate antibiotic treatment increased antibiotic resistance substantially, and there is thus an urgent need for developing novel therapeutic strategies to suppress mucus overproduction. The currently proposed studies will lead to the identification of novel therapeutic targets, leading to new therapeutic strategy for inhibiting mucus overproduction in OM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative State of the art methods for the early detection and monitoring of cancer are either invasive, time-consuming, expensive, or frequently inaccurate, which hinders the routine screening of at risk-patients to improve survival rates. Here, we propose a portable neural network enabled spectroscopy platform to diagnose cancer in patient biofluids (saliva, blood plasma, and sweat). The expected outcome is to deliver a novel point of care liquid biopsy platform to better classify, monitor, and improve diagnostic sensitivity of a broad range of diseases and conditions, with focus on early/late-stage head and neck cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increasingly, prevention-minded gerontologists and geroscientists look to midlife as the life stage offering a terrific opportunity to prevent or delay the multiple diseases that shrink older adults’ health span, and they call for more knowledge about aging during midlife. We propose to follow up at age 52 a cohort of 1037 infants studied since birth, the Dunedin Study, to quantify how fast or slowly each cohort member is aging in each of 8 different life domains: the pace of biological aging, functional aging, facial aging, social aging, sexual aging, inflammatory aging, microvascular aging, and cognitive aging (Aim 1). We will generate new knowledge about the early-life antecedents of each of the 8 kinds of aging (Aim 2), and about the risk each kind of aging poses for late-life disease (Aim 3), and we will export to the field DNAmethylation blood-test measures of 8 kinds of aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The mission of the Rochester EHSC is to improve health through the creation of knowledge and discovery of mechanisms by which environmental exposures, singly and in combination, contribute to health risk across the life span, and translating findings into strategies to mitigate risks and improve human health. This mission is achieved by supporting scientific research and translating this research through community engagement and education. Thus, the EHSC provides the framework for the generation of novel research discoveries and their conversion into effective resources for scientists, public health officials, medical professionals, and communities.
