IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project examines how young people's experiences multiple forms of discrimination contribute to the initiation and persistence of substance use from late childhood to middle adolescence, exploring moderating mechanisms at biobehavioral (i.e., sleep) and environmental (i.e., neighborhood) levels. By investigating discrimination and substance use as early as late childhood, the project prospectively disentangles directionality and reciprocal associations between discrimination and substance use, identifies sensitive periods when discrimination is particularly harmful, explores sleep and neighborhood environment as modifiers for targeted interventions, and highlights critical developmental periods when interventions may be most effective in mitigating health disparities. The proposed project advances developmental and health disparities science by elucidating biobehavioral and environmental mechanisms linking social experiences of discrimination to health inequity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death of females in the United States, and females experience a steep increase in cardiovascular disease risk after menopause; females who complete menopause early (before age 46 yrs.) have a higher risk of cardiovascular disease and hypertension than those who complete menopause at a typical age (~ 51 yrs.) The proposed study will investigate autonomic mechanisms underlying dysregulation of blood pressure in early- and typical-age-menopausal females of diverse backgrounds, thereby elucidating factors that contribute to adverse cardiovascular health outcomes associated with early menopause. Findings from this research will lay the groundwork for development of prophylactic and therapeutic approaches to reduce cardiovascular disease risk in postmenopausal females and specifically in early-menopausal females.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The U-RISE Program at Clark Atlanta University is designed to foster a STEM-focused cohort of academically promising undergraduate students via a well-designed series of preparatory activities, curricular enhancements, and intensive research immersions. Together, with guidance from highly experienced faculty mentors, a collection of assets and capabilities already in place at Clark Atlanta University, and commitment from University administration, U-RISE trainees will be prepared to pursue and complete advanced biomedical research degrees. The proposed program holds great promise for generating a cohort of competitively trained scientists who represent the beneficiaries of national efforts to reduce historical trends of underrepresented minority participation in America’s biomedical research enterprise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project offers a brand-new paradigm on Crohn’s disease (CD)-associated intestinal strictures that will on the short term delve into novel cellular and molecular mechanisms of intestinal stricture formation and on the long-term will eventually foster the development of specific new drugs. Thus, this proposal is directly relevant to IBD and the goals of the National Institute of Health by benefitting more than half of Crohn’s disease (CD) patients and having a tangible impact on ways to prevent intestinal obstruction and avoid surgical resections. By investigating a previously unidentified role of creeping fat-derived factors promoting smooth muscle hyperplasia via increasing smooth muscle cell proliferation, we will deviate from the traditional notion of immune cell-driven ECM deposition, and instead focus on extraluminal factors responsible for fibrosis and stricture formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Rett syndrome (RTT), is a severe neurodevelopmental disorder caused by loss-of function mutations in the X- linked gene Methyl-CpG-binding Protein 2 (MECP2) and characterized by loss of speech and hand skills, problems walking, and repetitive hand movements. Genetic restoration of MECP2 in symptomatic mice can reverse symptoms providing hope that disease-modifying therapies can be created but a lack of biomarkers of treatment-response will impede the development of curative therapies. To address this need, we propose to develop neurophysiological biomarkers that can fulfil a primary Context of Use (COU), an early treatment response biomarker, to facilitate and speed both preclinical and clinical trials of novel therapies in RTT.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The long-term goal of this project is a socket that maintains fit without requiring continual attention and adjustment by the user. The project brings novel socket sensing elements, a versatile fob, and electro- mechanical control system strategies to prosthetics to automate socket adjustment during everyday activities. Rigorous testing of the auto-adjusting socket in user free-living environments of comfort, satisfaction, convenience, fatigue, residual limb health, prosthesis use, activities, socket fit and number of manual socket size adjustments provide key insight towards integration of this technology in clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Diet can affect cancer cell metabolism and nutritional requirements to as large a degree as the oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes. Our preliminary data show that a specific dietary methionine restriction has anti-tumor properties alone or in adjuvant therapy in several cancer models. In this proposal I will dissect the nature of methionine restriction mediated anti-cancer effects for its therapeutic application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because it focuses on evaluating the role of psychosocial stress on the cognitive health of Latinx adults, who have a 50% greater risk of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias compared to non-Latinx White adults. This research will characterize the daily linkages between experiences with discrimination and cognitive performance in Latinx adults. Results from the proposed research will inform on mechanisms of cognitive health inequities and uncover protective factors in these processes to inform future prevention and intervention efforts aimed at reducing cognitive health inequities in Latinx adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is a highly lethal malignancy with no available effective therapies. In this project, we identify and validate novel metabolic dependencies that pancreatic tumors rely on, including unconventional means for producing small, nitrogen-enriched metabolites termed “polyamines” that are essential for cellular growth. We aim at demonstrating that pancreatic tumors produce these metabolites in a very distinct manner than normal cells, thus providing a therapeutic window for intervention to suppress pancreatic cancer growth with minimal toxicity to normal tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative The intestine is a highly dynamic tissue with stem cells supporting the ability to grow and adapt. We propose to use the Drosophila midgut and mouse intestine as complementary genetic models to study the conserved mechanisms involving sensing of mechanical signals by the Tao kinases to regulate stem cells for adaptive growth. The result obtained should provide insights into therapeutic strategies for treatment of gastrointestinal disorders such as inflammatory bowel disease and cancer that requires adaptive growth as a repair mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Mosquitoes transmit deadly diseases. The research proposed in this application will provide information of potential importance for development of insecticides for vector control. The proposed studies will reveal functions and mechanisms of action of epigenetic marks, which will help in understanding epigenetics of human diseases such as cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In response to RFA-AI-19-015, the purpose of this application is to establish an Atopic Dermatitis Research Network - Clinical Research Center (ADRN-CRC) at National Jewish Health (NJH) to conduct ADRN network-wide clinical research projects under the leadership of the ADRN-Leadership Center (ADRN- LC). In parallel, single-center clinical and mechanistic research at NJH will evaluate mechanisms underlying children with atopic dermatitis (AD) and food allergy as well as AD associated with eczema herpeticum. Our central hypothesis is that different phenotypes and endotypes of AD are associated with distinct defects in their skin barrier and cutaneous immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The global COVID-19 pandemic caused by SARS-CoV-2 has highlighted the extent to which social determinants and inequities impact healthcare received and health outcomes. This project will evaluate maternal and infant effects following the COVID-19 pandemic and SARS-CoV-2 infection during pregnancy including pregnancy complications, adverse birth outcomes, maternal and infant mortality, and maternal one-year post pregnancy cardiovascular and mortality outcomes with a focus on social determinants of health and racial/ethnic differences. Better understanding of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and SARS-CoV-2 infection during pregnancy on maternal and infant morbidity and mortality is needed to guide clinical practice and public health prevention efforts for at-risk populations.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emory University, in partnership with Children's Healthcare of Atlanta, is nationally recognized as a leader in pediatric healthcare and has received continuous funding and made significant contributions to the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development Neonatal Research Network (NRN) since 1991. Our site brings a large available patient population with high follow-up rates, state-of-the-art clinical and research facilities and clinical research infrastructure, strong investigators with extensive clinical research expertise, and excellent research support staff. Emory will continue to contribute to the scientific missions of the NRN through development of innovative research protocols and conduct of clinical trials and observational studies to address important unanswered clinical questions in neonatal medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Adaptive genome evolution has produced the remarkable diversity of life on Earth, yet it is also the process by which pathogens and cancers resist drug treatments and evade the immune system. High- throughput experimental evolution is a powerful and versatile technique that provides a way to test evolutionary theory in the laboratory with exquisite control over experimental parameters. By identifying the genes and pathways that respond to selective pressures, the proposed experiments will not only advance our understanding of the process of adaptive evolution but will lead to new mechanistic insights into how genetic variation produces the phenotypes on which selection acts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common and aggressive type of brain cancer in adults, and effective treatment for GBM remains an unmet need. Therefore, it is critical to evaluate novel therapeutic approaches that will be beneficial for individuals afflicted with this debilitating disease. To develop protective antitumor immunity and improve GBM patient survival, we propose to simultaneously destroy tumor cells and activate microglia/macrophages, specialized immune cells in the tumor microenvironment. This study should result in the development of a novel therapeutic combination that will improve GBM patient survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE This application proposes an approach consistent with precision medicine for the study of autism. It will do so through the identification of homogenous brain connectome-based subtypes (i.e., neurosubtypes) that are reproducible and clinically relevant. This will be accomplished through the creation of a large-scale, aggregate data resource to support mega-analysis of the connectome in autism during childhood; the resource will be shared to maximize impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The molecular mechanisms involved in maintaining mitochondrial redox homeostasis and the role of mitochondrial antioxidants in tumor progression are poorly understood. To address this, we will test the hypothesis that mitochondrial GSH maintenance is essential for breast cancer progression and metastasis. Our work will provide unprecedented insight into the role of mitochondrial GSH homeostasis in cancer progression and may identify therapeutic strategies to prevent breast cancer metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioids are highly effective for pain management, yet the respiratory depression that they induce has massive health consequences. Despite its significance, the mechanisms underlying opioid-induced respiratory depression (OIRD) are not well understood. This project combines computational and experimental approaches to unravel how opioid-sensitive interactions between brainstem respiratory and pain circuits contribute to OIRD and explores strategies to dissociate analgesia and respiratory depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The central nervous system, including the visual system, of humans and other mammals has very limited capacity to regenerate following injury or degeneration. We are studying an animal, zebrafish, that successfully regenerates and recovers lost vision following optic nerve injury. The focus of this project is to study signaling and metabolic pathways that regulate successful optic nerve regeneration in zebrafish and then test them in a preclinical mouse model of optic nerve injury with the hope that they can be translated to enhance regeneration in human patients in the future.

PHR: Program Narrative Many people living in tropical regions of the world are infected by multiple viruses transmitted by mosquitos and other blood feeding arthropods. With currently available laboratory methods, it is difficult to detect specific antibodies induced by arbovirus infections or candidate vaccines. We will develop a new assay that will be able to accurately detect specific antibodies to different arboviruses and arbovirus vaccines in a single drop of blood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Capillaries are the smallest vessels in circulatory system, yet make up majority of the vascular network and is the site of O2 and nutrients delivery and waste removal. The proposed work will test the hypothesis that amyloid-β (Aβ)—the major constituent of amyloid plaques in cerebral amyloid angiopathy and the brain of Alzheimer's patients— disrupts pericyte's control of local and regional capillary blood flow. As we gain a better understanding on of how blood flow is regulated within the microvasculature, pericytes represent a novel therapeutic target for cardiovascular and neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative This grant will support 5 postdocs (4 NIH-sponsored and 1 UCSC-sponsored) at UC Santa Cruz’ Institute for the Biology of Stem Cells to undergo rigorous research training and targeted career skill development in order to succeed in careers spanning from academic research to biotechnology and advocacy. An important aspect of our program is structured mentoring which has been shown to improve career outcomes and increase the motivation of postdoctoral fellows to enter the academic job market, especially for women and minority postdoctoral fellows. The unifying research focus is on stem cell-based models of pre-and postnatal development.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Some of the most important clinical advances in the field of neonatology have been derived from the research studies of the Neonatal Research Network and other similar collaborative clinical research. The impressive gains in survival and handicap-free survival for very premature infants over recent decades are directly the result of clinical research and its translation into clinical practice. The Neonatal Research Network will continue to advance the understanding of the complex needs of preterm infants and their families and to design interventions to optimize their health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Early glaucoma detection with high sensitivity and specificity is greatly needed to prevent blindness and develop new therapies. This proposal aims to develop and validate novel imaging methods and quantitative markers, uniquely enabled by visible light optical coherence tomography, to detect glaucoma at its early stages. The success of this proposal would significantly improve the detection of early glaucoma damage, and benefit glaucoma management, treatment, and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our study seeks to provide fundamental insights into the role of different subpopulations of dopamine neurons for reward learning and motivated behavior. To do this, we will conduct pharmacological manipulations, fiber photometry recordings, optogenetics and electrophysiological measurements in behaving mice. Because many neuropsychiatric diseases, including substance use disorder, involve maladaptive changes in reward and motivation brain circuits, the proposed study may lead to the identification of circuit-level targets that can guide the development of novel treatments in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Depression, non-suicidal self-injury (NSSI) and suicidal thoughts and behaviors (STB) commonly emerge in youth and each represent important risk factors for death by suicide. The current proposal seeks to delineate the neurodevelopmental trajectories of strength and flexibility in fronto-limbic, cortico-striatal and default mode networks associated with the risk, onset and early course of depression, NSSI and STB in children and adolescents in the ABCD study using novel analytic strategies. New insights from this study will provide the foundation for designing personalized interventions to facilitate early detection of depression and suicide risk, and to guide interventions capable of restoring healthy brain development and averting serious negative outcomes including suicide.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Eunice Kennedy Shriver NICHD Neonatal Research Network (NRN) has been established to conduct multicenter, interventional, and observational clinical studies in neonates, including those who are preterm and of low birth weight. The Division of Neonatology at The Abigail Wexner Research Institute at Nationwide Children’s Hospital (NCH) in collaboration with The Ohio State University (OSU) and its affiliated noenatal intensive care units has demonstrated a strong commitment to the NRN and remain committed to serve as one the network centers and enhance its productivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The University of Virginia (UVA) and West Virginia University (WVU) are partnering to form a Linked Clinical Research Center to conduct heart and vascular clinical research trials with the goal of serving the vulnerable Appalachian community. This partnership has been designed to increase the capability of WVU to conduct clinical research trials using UVA’s excellent experience in heart and vascular research. Partnering these two universities will provide excellent teaching and support for trainees at both sites who are interested in working in the field of clinical research. The end result of this research will be improved health care to people in the underserved Appalachian community and the general population. Investigators at each institution are committed to the success of the network both in trial enrollment and in leadership roles.

PHR: Project Narrative Blood platelets play a critical role in stimulating clot formation and repairing vascular injury. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Today’s biomedical researchers represent the backbone of innovation that improves public health nationwide. However, they have little resemblance to the overall diverse populations they are part of, causing increases in disparities in health access and outcomes. The proposed project to establish a U-RISE site at Delaware State University (DSU) will promote diversity of the new workforce in biomedical research. Being a Historically Black University, DSU is well positioned to significantly contribute towards this goal as its undergraduate student population is about 80% minority, mostly underrepresented in diverse STEM fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic stress-induced changes in cerebral blood flow and oxygen supply affect brain physiology, but molecular and cellular mechanisms are not fully understood. We will investigate neuronal hemoglobin, an oxygen-carrying protein, and hemoglobin-regulated pathways in a specific type of neurons as an immediate target of chronic stress-affected cerebrovascular dysfunction. The proposed research could yield a high impact outcome by uncovering a novel stress mechanism potentially relevant to mental health and brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to use a 2x2 factorial design to test an acceptable and feasible peer support evidence-based intervention (EBI)—peer health coaching—to determine the preliminary effectiveness of different implementation strategies, as well as the overall EBI, at promoting self-care behaviors and improving glycemic control among older adults with type 2 diabetes living in Appalachian Kentucky. The main components of the factorial design will be how peer coaches are selected for participants (self-selected vs matched) and frequency of contact with coach (once per week vs every 2 weeks). Guided by the Practical, Robust Implementation and Sustainability Model (PRISM), we will collect quantitative and qualitative data to assess PRISM domains and give context to both anticipated and unanticipated EBI adaptations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Sarcoidosis is a multi-organ granulomatous disease of unknown etiology, most commonly affecting the lungs, which may progress to pulmonary fibrosis. This project will use biospecimens from the NHLBI biorepository (BioLINCC) to test the hypothesis that PLA2R loss-of-function is a monogenic cause of sarcoidosis among African-Americans from the “ACCESS” (A Case Controlled Etiologic Study of Sarcoidosis) cohort.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Mild traumatic brain injuries (mTBI) were commonly sustained among those who served in the recent conflicts and are associated with increased rates of mental health disorders, including posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Symptom overlap between mTBI and mental health conditions can result in diagnostic challenges and impact understanding of long-term prognosis. To remedy this, we along with our collaborators will create a unified longitudinal dataset to examine associations between physiologic biosignals/functional measures and mental health outcomes/conditions (e.g., symptoms, suicidal thoughts and behaviors). This dataset will include combined measures from the existing Long-Term Impact of Military Brain Injury (LIMBIC) and Translational Research Center for TBI and Stress Disorders (TRACTS) protocols. Initial findings from this proposed effort will be foundational for subsequent inquiry focused on enhancing diagnostic and prognostic efforts to improve brain health and psychosocial functioning among Veterans living with mTBI and mental health conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE: KEEP: Kentucky Environmental Education Pipeline program will recruit and train undergraduate student researchers from historically marginalized populations for careers within the field of environmental health sciences. Key to the mentorship associated with this summer research opportunity program, we will offer access to specialized skills training sessions via ‘boot camps’ including a community-embedded air/soil sampling field trip with integrated report back organized and administered via the NIEHS funded Center for Integrative Environmental Health Sciences Community Outreach core. Faculty mentors and/or program directors will continue to provide career coaching and personalized mentorship until matriculation so that participants are fully integrated into an ongoing supportive community focused on degree completion, timely application to competitive graduate and professional school programs, and ultimately biomedical careers in environmental health sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Eye injuries are common, and the cornea in the eye is very painful when injured. Nevertheless, there are currently no approved treatments specifically for corneal pain, and those treatment options that are used are associated with significant side effects. The goal of this study is to develop a safe and effective treatment for acute corneal pain that can be administered as eye drops.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/ PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT This quasi-experimental, longitudinal study will (a) examine the influence of state and federal nutrition policy interventions for schools on child obesity prevalence and related disparities among diverse Asian/PI subgroups; and (b) determine the extent to which community food environments modify the policy influences on obesity. The study will generate new evidence on the effectiveness of current nutrition policy interventions to prevent obesity among population groups who have been severely understudied in obesity prevention research. Findings from this study will inform population-wide strategies to prevent obesity and promote children’s healthy body weight among diverse Asian/PI populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative An abnormal number of chromosomes and associated copy number variations of the genetic material are hallmarks of cancer. However, how chromosome segregation errors and the resulting aneuploidy contribute to cancer initiation, malignancy, evolution, and heterogeneity is poorly understood. The goal of this project is to develop innovative imaging and optogenetics technology to observe and manipulate chromosome segregation dynamics with high spatial and temporal accuracy in patient-derived cancer organoids to ask fundamental questions about the complex relationship between aneuploidy and cancer and inform development of new and personalized therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The Gordon Research Conference (GRC) and accompanying Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) Barriers of the CNS will provide a platform for senior and junior, academic and non-academic, and basic and clinical researchers from around the world to improve their understanding of the complex cellular and molecular mechanisms regulating neural barrier integrity in health and disease. The brain/neural barriers, in their function to protect the central nervous system (CNS) from neurotoxic compounds and to regulate the CNS immune privilege, also block delivery of drugs to the CNS, thus hindering diagnosis and treatment of neurological disorders. The Barriers of the CNS 2024 GRS and GRC are dedicated to providing a unique trans-disciplinary environment giving attendees the opportunity to discuss broadly to bridge knowledge gaps in the field that will help overcome the unmet need for the development of diagnostic or therapeutic tools for diseases in the CNS.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human labor is a highly inflammatory event, but what causes it to start is unclear. We have found that cell-free fetal DNA (cffDNA) can activate the mother’s immune system and promote the transition towards labor. This proposal aims to understand what about cffDNA makes it activate immune cells and whether we can block the inflammation caused by cffDNA, which is particularly important for preventing preterm birth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients suffering from the progressive, currently incurable genetic disorder Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2), which causes tumor growth throughout the nervous system, face a shortened lifespan and a lifetime of devastating neurological symptoms that remain unaddressed by current treatment technologies. Merlin Therapeutics is developing a unique gene therapy allowing NF2 deficient cells to produce a healthy version of the lacking NF2 protein in all cell types affected by the disease, thereby addressing the underlying disease cause. The proposed project will confirm existing preliminary data and establish dose-response, safety, and biodistribution data for our lead gene therapy candidate to bridge the gap to the next steps to a future clinical trial and position this vector as a potential preventive and/or treatment for NF2.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with substance use disorder have difficulty quitting and are susceptible to relapse even after long periods of abstinence. Recent findings have suggested that a single dose of psychedelic drugs can lead to both decreases in smoking and reduce the chance of relapse. This project will use a rat model of nicotine addiction to determine the conditions under which the psychedelic drug psilocybin can promote abstinence and prevent relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Klebsiella pneumoniae are major causes of antibiotic resistant infections worldwide. We hypothesize that K. pneumoniae bloodstream infections are caused by mixed populations of genetically and phenotypically distinct strains, rather than a single strain as long believed. In this project, we will characterize genetic and phenotypic diversity of K. pneumoniae strains recovered from blood cultures, determine if genetic diversity correlates with antibiotic treatment failure, and implicate specific genes in antibiotic resistance, antibiotic tolerance, and virulence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The 3q29 deletion is associated with a high risk of neurodevelopmental and neuropsychiatric disorders. We propose to use a novel approach to investigate the function of genes in the 3q29 deletion in the developing brain. Our central goal is to understand how genes in chromosomal regions that are highly associated with neuropsychiatric disorders, including the 3q29 deletion, affect brain development, which will advance our understanding of the biological mechanisms underlying these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Simple and sensitive detection of viral load in patient blood samples at home is highly desired for detection of early and rebound HIV infections, especially in individuals undergoing PrEP. The goal of this project is to develop a novel electrochemical diagnostic platform we call HIV-eCaDI (HIV Capillary Driven Immunoassay) that can be used by PrEP patients to detect HIV p24 antigen at ~10 pg/ml concentrations at home in a rapid, sensitive, and user friendly format. HIV-eCaDI will be a valuable diagnostic platform for detecting acute HIV infections and help patients closely monitor their HIV status in the privacy of their own homes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The overall goal of this project is to understand the principles that underlie epithelial immunity against viruses. By identifying how intestinal epithelial cells detect viruses and respond to infection, the proposed studies will provide fundamental knowledge about the role of epithelial cells in infectious diseases. This work will uncover novel defense mechanisms that may inform the basic biological processes underlying viral infections and autoimmune diseases in humans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The TBI literature provides preliminary evidence supporting associations between TBI exposures and poor health and functional outcomes, and extant longitudinal cohort studies of service members and Veterans with military combat and training exposures offer researchers access to extant data addressing factors that modify risks for developing and/or recovering from a range of brain disorders, including TBI, PTSD, pain, depression, and suicidality. Pooling individual participant level data from longitudinal TBI research studies will result in a large enough dataset to consider relevant moderators, mediators, and confounders in analyses and allow for more impactful and clinically meaningful findings. We have developed a model data harmonization system to combine data from multiple heterogenous studies and facilitate the analysis of a single pooled dataset. The research team will develop a 2-year plan to define a standardized approach and create a crosswalk for the modalities and domains of LIMBIC and TRACTS longitudinal cohort to create a unified assessment profile that can be analyzed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The tumor microenvironment overpowers the human immune system by repeatedly engaging cytotoxic T cells with inhibitory immune checkpoint molecules, rendering the T cells dysfunctional. Immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) therapy works to overcome these suppressive interactions in hopes of inducing durable tumor regression in cancer patients who have limited therapeutic alternatives, however therapeutic response rates are quite low and vary on an individual basis. Our preliminary data links overexpression of Dual Specificity Phosphatase 2 (DUSP2) within human CD8+ T cells to dampened responses to ICB and this proposal will aim to elucidate the network controlling response and allow for the identification of therapeutic targets that may improve ICB responses in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Remodeling of the esophagus is a serious issue driven by a variety of food- and aero-allergens that affects the wellbeing of up to 1 in 1000 people and with an estimated healthcare cost of $1 billion. Defining proteins that drive or contribute to esophagus remodeling, fibrosis, and esophageal smooth muscle dysmotility, may lead to new treatment options for these patients. This proposal will test the hypothesis that the extracellular proteins LIGHT/TNFSF14 and TWEAK/TNFSF12 interact with one another as well as IFN and IL-13 to promote structural changes in the esophagus that result in rigidity and strictures which in turn cause issues with swallowing and food consumption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative. Hereditary angioedema (HAE), a potentially life-threatening hereditary disorder associated with recurrent attacks of swelling of cutaneous tissues, intestinal tract and airways, is caused by mutations in the SERPING1 gene coding for C1 esterase inhibitor (C1EI). In a mouse model of HAE, gene therapy with an adeno-associated virus coding for C1EI (AAVrh.10hC1EI) reversed the swelling phenotype. This study focuses on assessing the safety of AAVrh.10hC1EI in nonhuman primates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) accounts for about 20% of all breast cancer cases and is associated with poor prognosis and non-responsiveness to hormone and other targeted therapies. There is no standard care plan for TNBC and thus there is a critical need to find new and effective targeted therapies for TNBC. Weatherwax is proposing to develop bifunctional molecules to restore p53 activity, a tumor suppressor found mutated in the vast majority of TNBC cases, as a novel therapeutic opportunity for this aggressive breast cancer subtype, affecting approximately 200,000 individuals every year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative: Surgical perforations in the dura, the thick membrane of dense connective tissue surrounding the brain and spinal cord, require repair and sealing to prevent leakage of cerebrospinal fluid associated with serious complications such as infection, intractable headaches, or wound breakdown. Current dura repair methods such as suturing, stapling, grafts, and tissue adhesives are often ineffective at providing an immediate watertight clo- sure, resulting in poor outcomes and appreciable loss of time and money, including additional procedures and inpatient care to re-establish dural integrity. We address this problem with the PatchClamp surgical device to enable immediate watertight closure of the dura in either open or minimally invasive surgery, enabling the sur- geon ease and flexibility of application within restricted working space and access vectors, thereby reducing operating room time and expense and complications, substantial morbidity, and costs related to postoperative cerebrospinal fluid leakage.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE OVERALL The UCSD Learning Health Systems Science Center Core Grant will provide core services and resources to enhance the career development of embedded LHS Scientists to conduct research that will advance the field. These resources will be used to provide didactic and experiential education to LHS Scientists recruited broadly from UCSD and federally qualified health center community partners including the El Centro Regional Medical Center and the Family Health Centers of San Diego. The Center will foster collaboration among faculty from 8 academic departments in the School of Medicine, Economics, Biostatistics, the Altman Clinical and Translational Research Institute, Jacobs Center for Health Innovation, and Population Health Services to bring us closer to our goal of enhancing diversity of the LHS workforce and improving health and equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is characterized by beta cell destruction in the pancreas where there currently are no preventions or cures. A wealth of data has been generated on the human pancreas by the Human Islet Research Network (HIRN) and other sources that can be used to understand T1D and identify biomarkers and therapies; however, these data are currently under-utilized by researchers. The proposed project will address this gap by creating a knowledge base ‘PanKBase’ consisting of a database of harmonized data in the pancreas and high- value summary resources created from these data, an analytical library of tools to extract knowledge from data and resources using statistical modeling and machine learning, an open science platform enabling all users to perform analyses and access data, and a robust engagement and outreach program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) and allergic rhinitis (AR) are the two most prevalent sinonasal diseases and have immense economic impact exceeding $35B/year. Overlooked as a source of morbidity, the disease burden of CRS and AR is comparable to congestive heart failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and Parkinson's disease. In this proposal, we will develop an imaging modality that establishes an objective means to gauge sinus health and the response to treatment, which in turn will aid scientists, clinicians, and industry professionals to better develop drugs, devices, and other therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Principal Investigator: Lim, Kian, H PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims at targeting a key regulatory switch of the innate immune pathway, the Interleukin-1 Receptor- Associated Kinase 4 (or IRAK4) as a novel therapeutic strategy in pancreatic cancer, based on recent findings from our lab. We will explore how signaling emanating from IRAK4 intersect with oncogenic KRAS signaling, investigate the global and immune-related role of IRAK4 in pancreatic cancer, and develop IRAK4 inhibitor- based immunotherapeutic regimen that can be translated into clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Public Health Relevance: The aggregate incidence of GI cancers across the whole digestive tract is the highest of any organ system; re-imagining the GI tract as a single target organ provides the rationale to screen the most lethal GI cancers simultaneously. Biomarkers that discriminate GI cancers by anatomic site make this approach practical by efficiently directing the diagnostic evaluation of positive test results. The project is relevant to NIH mission by applying knowledge that might extend healthy life and reduce the burden of illness due to GI cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Clinical Pharmacology is the scientific discipline that addresses all aspects of human-drug interactions, including mechanisms of drug action and the mechanistic basis for individual variation in drug response. Clinical Pharmacology is undergoing rapid change with the integration of “multiple omics” science and modern computational techniques such as artificial intelligence and machine learning. The long-standing Mayo Clinic Clinical Pharmacology Training Program has embraced these advances and incorporated them into a Training Program designed to prepare healthcare professionals to contribute to our understanding of human drug interactions by the application of all of the tools of modern biomedical and computational science.
PROJECT_TERMS: Clinical Pharmacology;Grant;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training Grant in Clinical Pharmacology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Heterochromatin is a tightly packed form of DNA, mainly consists of genetically inactive satellite sequences and mobile element, and is associated with several important cell functions, including gene regulation, silencing of repetitive DNA or the protection of the integrity of chromosomes. Large fractions of the human genome consist of heterochromatin, including the Y chromosomes, centromeres, telomeres, or the Barr body, and altered heterochromatic states can impair normal gene expression patterns, leading to the development of different diseases. Competition between the opposing mechanisms of heterochromatin formation and active transcription can result in dysregulation of host genes and silenced repeats. We will use the model species Drosophila to investigate epigenetic conflicts on different Y chromosomes, which will help to understand how repressive chromatin states may interact with actively transcribed genes, and will help to develop therapeutic strategies that aim toward resetting the epigenetic state of dysregulated genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most studies of fear learning have focused on the excitatory connections involved in fear circuits and/or local inhibitory interactions, with no attention to the role of long-range GABAergic connections across regions. This proposal investigates the physiological and functional role of a novel inhibitory pathway from auditory cortex to the lateral amygdala. Elucidating the contribution of long-range cortical inhibition will provide new therapeutic targets for the treatment of anxiety disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE A dietary assessment approach that reduces participant and researcher burden and improves recall accuracy and ecological validity is needed to move the field forward. In response, we propose to develop and test a low cost mobile app that uses ecological momentary assessment to collect dietary data with limited burden and notable accuracy. Our approach will be additionally unique from traditional dietary assessment approaches in that it can be easily adapted for use as a dietary behavior change tool.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The indications for glaucoma drainage device (GDD) implantation have expanded over time due to its excellent intraocular pressure (IOP) control. However, one of the major long-term complications associated with GDDs is progressive corneal endothelial cell loss (ECL) leading to corneal decompensation. Here we propose a multi-center randomized clinical trial to evaluate two tube placements in preventing ECL after GDD implantation, with the goal of the study to identify better surgical approaches to decrease postoperative corneal complications while preserving control of IOP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Repeated exercise has beneficial effects on the brain and body and has been shown to reduce the progression of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease (AD). We have found that artificial stimulation of a specific set of exercise-responsive neurons in the mouse hypothalamus modulates subsequent exercise endurance, but whether such stimulation can also generate the beneficial effects of exercise in the brain remains unknown. By leveraging new technologies that permit a detailed structural and functional deconstruction of this exercise-responsive circuit, our goal is to determine whether generating activity within this circuit promotes enhanced cognition and neuroprotection during aging and in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE AIRE is critical for maintaining central and peripheral tolerance to prevent autoimmune diseases but can also play a detrimental role in inhibiting immune responses against cancer. While deletion of thymic AIRE expression has been shown to improve immunotherapy response in certain cancers by allowing the development of autoreactive T cells, whether AIRE expression outside of the thymus is involved in regulating anti-tumor immune responses remains unknown. This proposal investigates the role of peripheral AIRE expression and AIRE-expressing tumor-associated macrophages in tumor progression and immunity with the ultimate goal of improving immunotherapy approaches for cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Anthracycline chemotherapeutic agents are commonly used in cancer treatment but can cause heart failure (HF), with older adults at increased risk. HF after anthracycline therapy has a poor prognosis and thus strategies to prevent anthracycline cardiotoxicity are needed. The proposed research will develop and externally validate a multivariable risk prediction model for HF in older adults with lymphoma, determine the utilization patterns of cardioprotective medications in routine clinical practice and elicit patient and provider preferences for cardioprotective strategies to support future clinical trials of cardioprotection in older adults with lymphoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-transcriptional regulation of gene expression by microRNAs is a critical contributor to neuronal development but identifying precise molecular mechanism has been challenging. In this proposal, we describe two novel ap- proaches that will permit investigating the functional consequences of de-repressing either an individual miRNA- target interaction or all interactions on a single target. We apply these approaches to understand how miRNAs instruct the developmental trajectory of cortical excitatory neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Narrative  The proposed research is relevant for patients with cancer because it will investigate how intra-tumor mitochondrial heterogeneity influences the response to chemotherapy. The project is relevant to the NIH/NCI mission because will improve patient outcomes, as it addresses fundamental questions about the mechanisms that underlie the poor response of pancreatic cancer to current treatments. Specifically, we anticipate that our research will have an immediate translational impact through the identification of new biomarkers that can be used to select patients who can benefit from targeting mitochondrial respiration preventing tumor relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE  The proposed research explores the possibility of precisely estimating change in specific brain structures in individuals at early stages of neurodegeneration. Anchoring from recent developments in fast brain scanning techniques, we use a novel methodological approach that permits a tremendous increase in the precision of measuring change within a single person by repeatedly, safety, and efficiently scanning the brain over time. Demonstrating successful precision measurement within the individual will open opportunities to track therapeutic effects in small samples during early phases of development as well as allow for individualized estimates of neurodegeneration to be made dynamically within the same person. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: We will use invasive electrical stimulation in neurosurgical patient volunteers to manipulate phrase-structure building neural activity in language areas of the brain while subjects are trying to comprehend a sentence. By observing the resulting effect on behavior and neural activity recorded elsewhere in the brain, we hope to better understand how the brain comprehends grammatical relations in sentences, and use this to develop better treatments for language disorder patients who have grammatical difficulties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative / Public Health Relevance Few interventions have proven to be successful in promoting medication adherence and impacting short- and long-term posttransplant outcomes in adolescent heart transplant recipients. In the proposed SBIR Direct to Phase II (R44) project, we will examine several newly implemented technological and practical innovations within emocha Health Inc.’s DOT app (and intervention) designed to help adolescent patients track their medication-taking and feel supported by their transplant care team. Together with emocha, the proposed study will examine differences in patient- and caregiver-reported measures, factors related to scalability and potential of translation of the DOT intervention into routine clinical care, and long-term health and adherence patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The proposed work will investigate changes in brain signaling and cognitive functioning that support recovery from addiction, as well as use of pretreatment neurocognitive functioning to inform substance use treatment planning. Substance use disorders are prevalent amongst Veterans. Cocaine addiction, in particular, has been shown to complicate treatment of other high priority behavioral health problems in the Veteran population (e.g., PTSD, opioid addiction). While there are currently no approved medications to support recovery from cocaine addiction, research indicates that Contingency Management (CM) – a behavioral intervention for cocaine users – can be effective. However, individual responses are variable and long-term benefits are limited. This CDA will test a new model of how CM works by examining brain-based predictors and indicators of treatment response. Results will have immediate implications for measurement-based implementation of existing CM variants within the VA, supporting access to the version of CM that is best aligned with each Veteran's needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A novel class of oral nicotine pouches that contain a crystalized nicotine powder instead of tobacco leaves (so- called “tobacco-free” pouches) have rapidly increased in popularity, yet there is virtually no research to inform their regulation. The proposed project will utilize controlled human lab studies, web-based experiments, and advertisement surveillance methods to gain a holistic understanding of these novel oral nicotine pouches. Results will reveal product features and marketing tactics of novel oral nicotine pouches that influence perceptions, abuse liability, and use behavior among smokers and non-nicotine users (including youth) in order to inform FDA regulations of these emergent products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The goals of this research are to characterize short-term versus long-term progressive biochemical and molecular indices of ethanol-induced cerebral white matter (WM) degeneration in relation to oligodendrocyte dysfunction. We propose that early abstinence-reversible adverse effects of ethanol on WM myelin are mediated by inflammatory and stress-induced increases in ceramide whereas more sustained chronic degeneration is due to impairments in insulin/IGF signaling through PI3K-Akt-mTOR with attendant compromises to oligodendroglial maturation, leading to pathogenic declines in sulfatide and increases in ceramide. We plan to assess therapeutic responses to abstinence, insulin sensitizers and inhibitors of ceramide biosynthesis in relation to stage of WM degeneration and cognitive impairment, and explore the degree to which co-existent PBMC membrane lipid abnormalities correlate with those present in WM as a potential non-invasive means of monitoring CNS WM degeneration and treatment responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Pre-clinical Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) is a period in which systemic autoimmunity develops in the years prior to onset of clinically apparent disease, which provides a window to intervene. While intestinal dysbiosis and altered tryptophan metabolism have been observed both in murine models of autoimmunity and in patients with rheumatic diseases, the mechanisms by which the microbiome and tryptophan metabolites may contribute to immune dysregulation have not been defined. Elucidating these mechanisms may therefore inform the development of future therapies to precisely target and/or modulate these pathways during pre-clinical RA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: TEAM-BASED INTERDISCIPLINARY CANCER RESEARCH TRAINING PROGRAM  PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer is a major public health concern and training the next generation of cancer researchers is critical to the success of our national effort to improve cancer outcomes. We propose to develop a novel Team-based Interdisciplinary Cancer Research Training Program that will provide comprehensive training for both pre- doctoral and post-doctoral candidates by expert faculty members drawn from various scientific disciplines focused on cancer research. The Program is designed to build a group of rigorously trained, scientifically competent, and innovative young scientists who are qualified to lead interdisciplinary team-based research initiatives and have the skills to make a difference in the lives of individuals with cancer, population health, and cancer health policy through cutting edge research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative My recent publication demonstrated that caloric restriction significantly enhanced the function of memory T cells to provide protection against melanoma. While the molecular determinants and mechanisms remain unclear, my preliminary data suggests a direct role for acetate producing members of the intestinal microbiota. To determine factors and mechanisms that enhance the quality of memory T cells during CR could allow for the rational design and implementation of nutritional interventions to improve cancer immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative We have recently demonstrated a new concept, the use of oxygen-generating biomaterials to overcome hypoxia- driven immunosuppression in tumor cell vaccines and improve therapeutic efficacy. This proposal will optimize these vaccines to enhance antitumor immune responses and test their ability to prevent the growth of and treat metastatic prostate cancer in relevant mouse models. Successful completion of these studies may have a sustained impact on the field by defining a new avenue of cancer immunotherapy that operates independently but synergizes with other existing therapies for the treatment of human cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Many patients with blood cancers (leukemias) are treated with a blood stem cell transplant from another person. Much of the benefit of such transplants are from donor immune cells that attack the leukemia cells. However, some types of leukemias benefit more so than other types from this immune effect. In prior work we discovered that leukemias that benefit less need a substance called interferon-gamma in order for them to be killed by the immune cells. In this proposal we test whether this is true for a broader range of leukemias and investigate exactly how interferon-gamma works to sensitize leukemias to immune cell killing. This knowledge could make blood stem cell transplants more effective.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Humans and mice have very limited potential for scar-free repair or regeneration of adult tissues. Recent work in mice has identified components of the immune system as negative regulators of regeneration that can restrict adult regeneration. This project will identify the critical biological pathways required to develop new strategies to transiently modify components of the immune system with the goal of inducing the latent regenerative potential in mammals and thereby significantly improving human health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study aims to develop an Automated RIsk Assessment (ARIA) system to analyze participant interviews, detect students at elevated risk of school violence, and provide risk characteristics to assist prevention. The proposed research is relevant to public health because developing an ARIA system will help establish a nationwide solution for detecting and preventing school violence. The objectives of this proposal are consistent with NICHD's high-priority research areas that aim to develop new knowledge about the identification, etiology, early intervention, and mechanisms of violence from childhood through early adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The transcriptional reactivation of endogenous retroviruses and retrotransposons beyond a threshold level of tolerance in cancer cells stimulates intracellular viral defense pathways that can promote antitumor effects and augment the effectiveness of certain cancer therapies. This therapeutic approach, termed viral mimicry, could hold promise for the treatment of advanced estrogen receptor (ER)+ breast tumors that often develop resistance to hormone-based therapies and recur years or even decades post-diagnosis. Understanding how SUV39H1 targeting induces viral mimicry selectively in ER+ breast cancer cells could lead to a safe and effective therapeutic approach to prevent metastatic recurrences and extend the utility of immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) and PARP inhibitor therapies to this tumor subtype, undoubtedly leading to a significant reduction in disease mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Most patients with late-life onset Alzheimer's disease (AD) have cerebral small vessel ischemic disease; currently, there is no treatment or effective prevention strategies. We will focus on a specific endocrine hormone, which when hypersecreted, causes diabetes and interaction with AD pathology. If our study demonstrates that the specific hormone we are studying causes cerebral small vessel disease, then new inhibitors of this hormone should help protect the brain in aging and diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Radon is a colorless, odorless, toxic radioactive gas and radon exposure is rising steadily within the modern North American residential environment. The proposed study aims to examine the association between radon exposure and stroke risk and to investigate whether the distribution of radon concentration is a reason for the racial and geographic variations of stroke rate in the US. Since randomized clinical trials on radon exposure is not feasible, findings from this study will provide crucial information to help identify a potential modifiable common risk factor for stroke.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is the most common form of annovulatory infertility of reproductive age women affecting 5-10% of reproductive age women and contributing >$5 billion to the healthcare burden in the US annually. We have identified functional variants in the AMH and AMHR2 genes that are very strongly associated with PCOS and identify a PCOS sub-phenotypic. The goal of this proposal is to identify the function of PCOS causal variants in the broader AMH signaling pathway which will explain the molecular basis and phenotypic heterogeneity of PCOS and the successful implementation of Precision Medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Transgender and nonbinary (TNB) people are highly vulnerable to HIV and have lower use of pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) for HIV prevention. This project will optimize and test a flexible trans-friendly clinic model for delivering long-acting injectable PrEP with CAB-LA, a recently approved medication that could greatly increase continued use of PrEP in TNB people. This study will also test for drug interactions between gender affirming hormones and CAB-LA, an important question that needs to be addressed for the TNB community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Select organisms are capable of regenerating an entirely new body during adulthood. This research program aims to reveal the pathways and principles controlling whole body regeneration in the planarian flatworm Schmidtea mediterranea and the distantly related acoel Hofstenia miamia. These strategies seek to understand the conserved and uniquely evolved spatial information systems and regulatory mechanisms that can enable regenerative growth.

PHR: This work represents a novel exploration of individual differences in reading ability in both children and adults, with the goal of understanding which factors lead to poor comprehension. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Relative to other racial/ethnic groups, Southeast Asian (SEA) children (specifically Hmong, Cambodian, Vietnamese and Laotian) experience higher rates of diet-related chronic diseases like type 2 diabetes risk factors. We will leverage our a longstanding partnership with the Center for SEA to test the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of an innovative multilevel, multicomponent, multigenerational dietary intervention with SEA families with children ages 6 to 11. This intervention integrates family-based nutrition education, motivational interviewing, descriptive dietary norms messaging, and healthy eating financial incentive coupons to improve children’s diet quality (primary) and body mass index and HbA1c (secondary).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The Expanding the Pipeline to Graduate Research in Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (EPGRAD) Program is an intensive two-month summer training experience for undergraduates from diverse backgrounds that will encourage students to pursue graduate study and careers in research on aging and Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) – thus increasing the diversity and inclusivity of the research workforce in these areas. The program will blend didactic training in epidemiological research methods and introductory data science methods with hands-on mentored research experiences in the area of ADRD. In addition to these experiences, trainees will participate in graduate school and career counselling sessions, journal club meetings, cutting-edge research seminars, and social activities that will serve to foster skills development and interest in aging and ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There are currently over 12 million Americans suffering from diseases affecting the retina, for which therapeutic attempts at repair or regeneration have been met with limited success. The zebrafish is an organism that exhibits remarkable capacity for retinal regeneration upon significant injury with no evidence of scarring, however many of the mechanisms behind this process remain poorly understood. With the experiments outlined in this proposal, we aim to determine the role of DNA methyltransferases in regulating the epigenetic control of retinal regeneration in the zebrafish as well as develop a targeted epigenetic modulation tool that may open new avenues for therapeutic approaches in mammalian retinal injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Parkinson disease (PD) is a progressive, disabling neurological disorder, but the impact of the disease on Black patients with PD is unclear due to less research in this population. This study investigates racial disparities by studying symptoms and signs, management, and genotype relationships in Black PD participants in comparison to a group of White PD participants. This study will result in new scientific knowledge regarding PD in the Black population by characterizing the basis for racial disparities, raising awareness of differences in PD recognition and management, and educating patients in this underserved and understudied population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Next-generation sequencing studies have begun to unveil that RNA modifications are present in mRNAs, suggesting the intriguing potential of fine-tuning gene expression; however, identifying the precise location and occupancy has been a challenge. The low copy number of individual mRNA species, and difficulties in detecting RNA modifications in general, precludes the use of existing methods such as mass spectrometry and chemical labeling for transcriptome-wide identification. We propose to develop a nanopore/computational pipeline for discovery and quantification of the pseudouridine modification in order to facilitate the discovery of RNA modification sites important in disease and development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Blood is designed to improve oxygen delivery and is essential for life yet, remarkably, stored blood has not been shown to improve tissue oxygenation and may actually worsen tissue perfusion. Close to 85 million units of red blood cells are administered worldwide each year so transfusion-related adverse events (including heart attack, organ injury, and death) are a major public health concern. An effective therapy to improve transfusion efficacy could have a major impact on the well-being of millions of patients.

PHR: Narrative  XX and XY sex chromosomes cause sex difference in disease, because of genes that protect or harm one sex more than the other. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative We have discovered two unanticipated roles for telomeres, one in controlling nuclear envelope breakdown during meiosis, and another in providing a nuclear microdomain that promotes the reassembly of centromeres, which have a surprising tendency to become dismantled upon meiotic entry. In this proposal we define the molecular underpinnings and implications of these two noncanonical telomere functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Babesia microti and Babesia duncani, the primary causative agents of human babesiosis in the United States, are naturally tolerant to current therapies and no vaccines are available to protect against these parasites. This proposal aims to characterize a unique set of secreted antigens exported by these parasites into the host, and to identify among them those that could be used to develop the first human babesiosis vaccines. The proposed research combines techniques in the fields of proteomics, cell biology and immunobiology; and its success will set the stage for future studies to evaluate the protective efficacy of these vaccines in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In 2014 there were an estimated 20,000 new cases of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) resulting in over 10,000 deaths. 20-25% of AML have very high expression of a gene called Meningioma-1 (MN1), and most of these patients have a very poor prognosis. We propose that MN1 causes leukemia by interfering with appropriate gene regulation, and that identifying critical mechanisms involved in this process may generate a path towards developing specific inhibitors that could help treat AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Machine learning (ML) is poised to enable faster and more accurate interpretation of medical images by augmenting the capabilities of experts. Success of ML techniques for medical image interpretation may reduce the burden on radiologists, reducing errors arising from fatigue or interruption, while simultaneously reducing costs and increasing speed and accuracy for patients. The cost and difficulty of generating expert quality labelled image data is the primary limitation preventing faster progress and deployment in more domains. We propose to address this problem by creating innovative algorithms that will construct reference quality labelled data with little input from domain experts, thus dramatically reducing the cost of labelling. These fundamental advances in informatics algorithms will reduce the cost and increase the rate of obtaining quality labels, which will in turn facilitate the widespread adoption and deployment of machine learning algorithms for image interpretation. Ultimately, this will stimulate the development of new imaging biomarkers that hold the potential to dramatically improve clinical decision-making and patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary fibrosis (PF) is a destructive interstitial lung disease with no known cure and leads to death within 3-5 years in severe cases. Substantial heterogeneity in PF phenotypes limits the utility of current classification criteria in prognostication and treatment. This proposal is critical to improving PF classification and prognostic accuracy, by incorporating critical genomic factors from diverse races into a new classification scheme using cutting-edge statistical tools, thereby guiding personalized therapy in PF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The NHGRI Centers for Mendelian Genomics (CMGs) have contributed substantial knowledge to the genetic basis of thousands of Mendelian diseases over the past decade, but diagnostic rates across the full set of conditions remain low. The NHGRI Mendelian Genomics Research Consortium will build on the CMGs' success by applying technological and data-sharing innovations to accelerate the further discovery and genetic characterization of Mendelian conditions. As the Data Coordinating Center for the Consortium, we will lead efforts to establish Consortium-wide data standards, utilize cloud-based resources to enable rapid data sharing among Consortium members and timely release to the broader scientific community, manage the opportunity fund supporting scalable functional studies of candidate genes and variants, and coordinate program logistics and outreach.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ABCD Study consortium uses multimodal brain imaging, cognitive and clinical assessments, bioassays, mobile monitoring, and careful assessment of substance use, environment, psychopathological symptoms, and social functioning in 11,878 9-10 year-olds to be followed over 10 years, to determine the effects of substance use on adolescent brain and cognitive development. These data will be shared with the scientific community to address a comprehensive range of questions concerning youth development.

PHR: Narrative. Despite the plethora of ways that developmental experience influences long-term patterns of behavior, our mechanistic understanding of how this occurs is limited. Here, we apply state-of-the-art sequencing technologies to identify the epigenetic and molecular signatures of select cells recruited for developmental learning in juveniles. The proposed research thus begins to fill a void in developmental neurobiology by applying an unprecedented level of detail to the structural organization of functional networks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is the etiological agent responsible for COVID19 disease in the current pandemic. RNA recombination is required during normal replication to generate subgenomic mRNAs required for protein expression, gives rise defective viral RNAs and generates numerous structural variants that facilitate adaption and evolution of SARS-CoV-2. We will characterize the molecular mechanisms that determine the sites and rates of RNA recombination and learn how selection in different physiological environments results in the selection and emergence of novel variants of SARS-CoV-2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Olfactory hallucinations can be symptomatic of various psychiatric or neurological disorders, including schizophrenia, Parkinson’s disease, epilepsy, and migraines. This project will determine olfactory-based behavioral and neural changes induced by hallucinogens in mice. These studies will further our understanding of sensory processing during perceptual disturbances, a necessary component for the advancement of diagnosis and treatment of several disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is a lethal disease that is projected to become the leading cause of cancer-related death in the United States by 2030. The bulk of the pancreatic tumor volume is composed of a reactive and immunosuppressive fibroinflammatory stroma that hinders the efficacy of checkpoint-based immunotherapy in the treatment of these tumors. The goal of this proposal is to define the role of interleukin-33 in maintaining this immunosuppressive milieu through its regulation of macrophages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria affects over two billion people, killing over 400,000 individuals each year mostly children in Africa. A powerful tool is needed for eliminating Plasmodium falciparum malaria from defined geographical areas. The ideal tool would be a highly effective, long-acting vaccine that prevents infection, disease and parasite transmission. This proposal describes our attempt to create designer PfSPZ candidates that possess superior breadth, magnitude and durable protective efficacy over the currently available strategies. The deliverables at the conclusion of the project would be improved PfSPZ vaccine candidate(s) poised for further downstream process development and future clinical evaluation in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Type 1 and type 2 diabetes (T1D and T2D), gestational diabetes (GDM) and related complications are excellent disease models to study the utility of polygenic risk scores (PRS) for predicting heterogenous and complex health outcomes in a setting where dramatic racial/ethnic and socioeconomic disparities exist. To address the disparities in PRS across ancestries, we have assembled a multi-disciplinary team to aggregate and analyze the largest existing genetic data from more than 1.8 M individuals (35% non-European) with T1D, T2D, GDM and glycemia-related complications and quantitative traits to improve the PRS prediction of diabetes and progression across the lifespan in diverse ancestries. Accomplishing the aims of this proposal will demonstrate how genomic data can inform more efficient and targeted preventive strategies within healthcare systems and across ethnically diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This work will determine how the enzymes that mediate short chain fatty acid metabolism limit colon cancer progression, and demonstrate that their reduced expression drives tumorigenesis. We will test the possibility that lower enzyme expression specifically in colon tumor cells creates a therapeutic vulnerability by altering both metabolic and gene expression programs. We will exploit this vulnerability in colon cancer to develop novel combinatorial therapeutic approaches that target metabolism and gene expression.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Tens of thousands of veterans have heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF), and suffer poor quality of life, frequent hospitalizations, and high death rates. Older veterans and those with high blood pressure, obesity, and the metabolic syndrome (abnormal cholesterol and resistance to insulin's effects) are particularly at risk for HFpEF. However, it is not clear why only some veterans in this risk group eventually develop HFpEF. Extensive information from experimental animal models and some human studies suggests that dietary patterns in vulnerable `salt-sensitive' people could contribute to the risk for HFpEF. Reducing salt intake and increasing overall dietary quality in at-risk veterans could prevent heart and blood vessel damage that ultimately leads to HFpEF. Reducing the development of HFpEF, which currently has no definitive treatment, is highly relevant to the VA's mission to emphasize prevention of disease and population health.
