IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Graft versus host disease (GVHD) of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract is one of the major complications associated with allogeneic hematopoietic stem marrow transplantation (HSCT), and leads to significant morbidity and mortality. The goal of this project is to critically examine the role of an inflammatory cytokine, termed interleukin 23, in the pathophysiology of GVHD in the GI tract. The ultimate objective of this proposal is to demonstrate that blocking the action of this cytokine reduces the severity of this complication in patients undergoing allogeneic HSCT for the treatment of hematological malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is highly heritable and marked by aberrant brain and behavioral development as early as 6 months of age, however it is unknown how genetic liability for ASD impacts infant development. This study aims to characterize how quantitative measures of genetic liability for ASD – including heritable autistic traits in first degree relatives and polygenic risk scores in infants – relate to trajectories of brain and behavioral development from 6 months of age through the period of early diagnosis at 24 months. Understanding the impact of genetic liability for ASD on neural and behavioral development reveals important mechanistic insight into the pathogenesis of ASD, and potentially identifies targets and timing for early intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE EGFR mutations are the most common targetable mutations in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and there are highly effective FDA-approved drugs for patients who have the “typical” EGFR mutations (exon 19 deletion or exon 21 L858R), but there are no effective FDA-approved drugs for the vast majority of patients with “atypical” mutations in EGFR exon 18 or 20. We recently reported the structural features of exon 20 mutations that cause steric hindrance and prevent FDA-approved drugs from inhibiting the receptor effectively, and identified poziotinib as a drug with activity in exon 20 mutant patients (43% objective response rate) but with several limitations including lower potency for mutations in the “far loop” region of exon 20 and toxicity due to inhibition of wild-type EGFR. In order to improve upon these limitations, this proposal we will investigate the structure- activity relationship of exon 18 and 20 EGFR inhibitors and use this information to develop inhibitors with greater potency and specificity for atypical mutants, thereby addressing a major unmet need for these patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This award supports the career development of Courtney J. Stevens, PhD, a clinical psychologist at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center whose long-term career goal is to become a leading investigator in behavioral oncology and health behavior intervention science. The training and mentoring plan is designed to provide knowledge and skills in early-phase intervention development, intensive longitudinal data collection and analysis methods, randomized clinical trial design, and professional development. The research component follows the Obesity-Related Behavioral Intervention Trials (ORBIT) Model in systematically developing an intervention that will be used in subsequent research to test the hypothesis that the affect-regulated exercise prescription can promote clinically meaningful increases in moderate-vigorous physical activity among physically inactive breast cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This research project is directed toward an understanding of how genes encoding cell surface molecules determine the structures of synaptic circuits in the brain. Although most of our work is conducted in Drosophila, many of the genes we are studying have human counterparts. We hope to reveal general principles that will illuminate the mechanisms by which human brain wiring is controlled before and after birth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Unlike breast, cervical, or colon cancer, there is no reliable screening test to detect ovarian cancer, which requires invasive surgery and removal of the ovaries in order to make a definitive diagnosis. Currently, neither CA125 nor transvaginal sonography alone yield adequate sensitivity or specificity for early detection and the U.S. Prevention Services Task Force does not recommend routine screening for ovarian cancer using any method. The proposed studies will develop new tools to detect epithelial ovarian cancer at earlier stages when existing therapies are curative and when potentially preventative.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current systematic prostate biopsies use a one-size-fits-all biopsy plan that is still being used even in conjunction with modern MRI-guided fusion biopsy devices, and the biopsy remains freehanded making the results variable among urologists. We have developed novel software that optimizes the biopsy plan for each patient and a robot that handles the ultrasound probe and automatically orients the needle-guide to follow the plan, making the biopsy procedure hands-free and independent of physician’s skills. We have successfully completed a safety and feasibility clinical trial, and propose a larger randomized clinical trial to investigate if our robot increases the detection rate of clinically significant prostate cancer relative to that of a modern commercial biopsy device.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Relevance to Public Health SIGNIFICANCE:  Cancer incidence and mortaility trends show therapeutic progress against multiple liquid and solid tumors, but some solid tumor types such as liver cancer remain exceptions [Siegel 2020], which motivates a deeper understanding of solid tumors.  We hypothesize a causal biophysical link between two aspects of solid tumors that are widely considered unrelated, namely (1) stiffness of the tissue which is a major risk factor for liver cancer – as it is for other maliganancies such as breast cancer, and (2) genetic changes – that are a hallmark of cancer and that are increasingly being targeted in therapy but are also most abundant in solid tumors.  We propose a mechano-genetics process in which genetic changes are caused by tissue stiffness including compression in mitosis, and to test our hypothesis and clarify aspects of mechanism, we will develop and apply a novel approach with gene editing that allows us to see genetic changes in real-time, in single cells under physical duress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a progressive and often fatal disease with marked individual disease heterogeneity as some patients progress rapidly while others have a disease course marked by periods of relative stability. The ability to distinguish what patients are most likely to progress quickly represents an urgent and unmet need for both IPF patient care and research. The purpose of this study is to use novel imaging techniques and molecular biomarkers of lung injury to assess IPF disease activity with the ultimate goal of developing the ability to predict disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The gradual loss of hearing is a common manifestation of aging, ultimately affecting communication and leading to social exclusion and cognitive decline. The genetics of age-related hearing loss is multifactorial, with more than 50 genetic variations being associated with this impairment. To dissect this complexity, in this project we will replicate one human genetic variant in a mouse model to better study its function, connection to other genes, and sensitivity to noise damage, which will allow us to understand how it leads to age-related hearing loss and how we can delay or prevent this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Despite effective antiretroviral treatment, nearly half of HIV+ patients suffer from persistent mild neurocognitive disorder which is exacerbated by opioid use. HIV-transactivator of transcription (Tat) protein is persistently secreted by infected cells, impairing mitochondrial function, BDNF levels, and recapitulating several aspects of HIV infection and HAND. As Tat and opioids convergently activate pathways that impair mitochondrial function, which in turn impairs behavior, this basic science program aims to characterize morphine- and Tat-induced behavioral and molecular abnormalities related to mitochondrial function and BDNF, and to evaluate whether oral dimethylfumarate attenuates morphine- and Tat-induced mitochondrial, BDNF and behavioral deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will evaluate the effect on HIV viral suppression of expanding community ART delivery to individuals newly diagnosed with HIV through the Head StART intervention in refugee settlements in Uganda. We will use the RE-AIM implementation science framework to evaluate the Reach, Effectiveness, Adoption, Implementation, and Maintenance of Head StART across study sites, and conduct a cost and budget impact analysis of the intervention. The project is responsive to PA-20-144 aims of improving HIV treatment outcomes and its results will provide crucial evidence for policymakers regarding effective, feasible, and low-cost strategies to strengthen the HIV care cascade among refugees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondria, the powerhouse of heart cells, could send signals to nucleus to promote energy producing genes expression to further boost the powerhouse. The proposed study is to investigate how GCN5L1, an enzyme to regulate mitochondrial proteins activity through adding chemical modification, sends signals to nucleus to turn on energy producing genes expression. Understanding the process will potentially provide novel therapeutic targets for heart failure, a leading cause of death and hospital admission in United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Over 25 million people per year are treated emergently for injuries and more than 5 million people are admitted annually for critical illness. This Interdisciplinary Training in Injury and Critical Illness will help contribute to the next generation of trauma surgeon-scientists who can tackle the basic, translational, and clinical aspects of research spanning the bench to bedside. This research will center on the broad-expertise of our 16 faculty across 6 Departments at Vanderbilt covering the domains of 1) Injury and 2) Critical Illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Heart failure affects 6.5 million individuals in the US and recent cardiovascular outcome trials (CVOTs) have demonstrated that SGLT2 inhibitors reduce hospitalization for heart failure (HHF) and cardiovascular mortality. SGLT2 inhibitors consistently increase the plasma ketone concentration and ketones are avidly taken up and metabolized by muscle to generate ATP. In the present grant we will examine the effect of exogenous ketone infusion, as well as the SGLT2i-induced rise in plasma ketone concentration, on skeletal and cardiac metabolism and on myocardial function and blood flow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic pain is common among individuals treated with opioid agonist therapies (OAT; buprenorphine or methadone) and is associated with poorer opioid use disorder (OUD) outcomes, including higher attrition and higher levels of other drug use. The goal of this project is to develop and pilot test an integrated, web-based cognitive behavioral approach (R61 phase), and then conduct a randomized clinical trial evaluating its efficacy relative to standard care in a large and diverse sample of individuals with chronic pain treated with buprenorphine or methadone (R33 phase).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This application seeks funding to implement the enhanced Interdisciplinary Research Training Institute (eIRTI) that seeks to promote the career development of underrepresented pre-doctoral, postdoctoral and early career Hispanic scientists in drug and alcohol abuse and addiction research. Hispanics face unique health challenges and efforts to increase the number of well-qualified researchers prepared to conduct biomedical, behavioral and clinical research are vital to reducing health disparities among this underserved population. The complex and technical nature of contemporary substance abuse research and the growing demands for addiction-related knowledge across disciplines requires that competitive investigators develop a broad-based set of scientific knowledge and scientific research skills that will strengthen the NIH research pipeline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative RNA surveillance pathways suppress genetic errors and also regulate normal gene expression to serve essential functions in eukaryotic cells. This work will define functions of the essential and non-essential components of the vertebrate RNA surveillance apparatus and investigate why mutations in these ubiquitous machineries lead to defects in neuronal and muscular tissues. The knowledge gained will be key to understand human diseases such as autism and intellectual disability and to devise new therapies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The brain is an especially sensitive target for a variety of insults. New organoid culture technology allows for these insults to be studied separately and together to understand their impact on cell function for the different cell types in the brain. HIV-1, with its associated inflammation and treatment, opioids, and amyloid fibril disease are all interesting, especially in our aging population. Important aspects of their intersection on brain cell functions can now be studied.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research will increase our understanding of the basic mechanisms that promote and ensure the faithful inheritance of chromosomes. The work is highly relevant to human health, as errors in chromosome inheritance are one of the leading causes of miscarriages and birth defects and are also a major factor contributing to the development and progression of cancer. Some aspects of our program will address how repair of DNA breaks is organized and regulated, which is important for maintaining intact chromosomes and for inheriting the correct number of chromosomes. Other aspects will address the physical organization of chromosomes, the spatial relationships between chromosomes, how key events are coordinated during the meiotic program, and how these features contribute to successful inheritance of genomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative In this work, we are studying the cellular machinery that controls actin polymerization. Bacteria and viruses use this machinery to infect human cells and cancerous cells depend on it to spread. Therefore, improving our understanding of the molecules that constitute this machinery will contribute to our understanding of diseased states in humans and how to treat them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: We have discovered novel non-image forming vision mechanisms in flies and mosquitoes that control light avoidance/attraction behavioral responses and other light evoked behaviors. Using a combination of physiological and behavioral approaches combined with molecular genetics and precision programmable custom designed LED light devices, we will determine how non-imaging forming and image forming visual mechanisms coordinate to control insect light responses in a species specific fashion. This research will lead to more effective light based devices for species-specific harmful insect control to combat vector-borne human diseases.

PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of the UT Southwestern Integrative Immunology Training Program (IITP) is to prepare graduate students, medical scientist trainees, and post-doctoral fellows for cutting-edge careers in immunology and related fields. The IITP leverages the outstanding educational and research environment at UT Southwestern Medical Center to provide an understanding of the basic, public health, and clinical problems related to immunology, and to foster the intellectual, technical, and communication skills required to succeed in the biomedical workforce. Such training is essential for resolving pressing global health issues such as emerging infectious diseases and an aging population suffering from metabolic and autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative: Around two thirds of overdose deaths involved illicit synthetic opioids like fentanyl, which is the primary driver of the opioid epidemic today. Current opioid antidotes (naloxone and nalmefene) are not very effective in situation involving synthetic opioids. The overall goal of this project is to develop a fundamentally novel drug delivery approach for extending the duration of action and efficacy of currently FDA-approved opioid overdose antidotes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Antibiotic resistance (AR) is a substantial threat to public health. By utilizing advances in sequencing technology and machine learning, we propose novel deep learning models to 1) predict AR for many combinations of bacteria and antibiotics; 2) provide personalized performance AR prediction models for chronic infections; 3) disseminate cloud-ready, scalable, and user-friendly online resource. This work can potentially lead to rapid, precise antibiotic prescriptions leading to effective treatments for infectious diseases and integrate the latest advances in data science for the AR research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Functional abdominal pain disorders (FAPD), one of the most common chronic pain conditions are associated with significant disability, school absenteeism and suboptimal outcomes. Improved treatment strategies are urgently needed but hampered by an incomplete understanding of contributing factors like sleep disturbances. Objectively characterizing sleep architecture through polysomnography in relation to gastrointestinal symptoms will pave the way for newer treatment targets modulating sleep or optimize existing treatments like percutaneous electrical nerve field stimulation to improve clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Many individuals with autism spectrum disorder exhibit larger brain volumes early in life. We will generate and study cortical organoids from individuals with ASD and matched controls who have been profiled with behavioral assessments and neuroimaging since infancy in order to identify cellular and molecular mechanisms leading to early brain overgrowth. Insight into these mechanisms will enable further understanding of disease pathogenesis, delineate convergent biological pathways within a heterogeneous disorder, and will identify therapeutic targets for early personalized treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The ubiquitous ZIP metal transporters play central roles in transition metal homeostasis of living organisms with an emerging role in cell signaling. The fourteen ZIPs encoded in human genome participate in numerous physiological processes and are also associated with many diseases, including cancers. This proposal aims to clarify the structural and molecular basis of transport, substrate specificity and post-translational regulation mechanisms of the ZIPs, which will ultimately improve human health and environmental protection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ideal antibacterial and hemocompatible surface would prevent platelet adhesion and activation, thrombosis, and microbial biofilm formation. This research project will develop and evaluate the synergistic effects of S- nitrosothiol based nitric oxide (NO) release along with a surface immobilized catalyst that can extend the therapeutic levels of NO for longer periods at the polymer interface to prevent platelet activation/adhesion and provide antimicrobial activity, thereby solving major clinical problems associated with extracorporeal circuit (ECC) applications and enabling successful ECC without heparinization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE Building on a rich bank of population and clinical studies, the Harvard Chan School-NIEHS Center for Environmental Health is applying the best available technologies and methods to re-envision the complex lived environment exposure landscape, assess it, and address related health effects in our population studies. This includes new opportunities offered by the “‘omics” era, with a particular new emphasis on the microbiome, to reveal the mechanisms of emerging environmental threats. We aim to work with the local community to guide the understanding and analysis of the lived environment and to make our research results immediately translatable to community concerns through public policy and other prevention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The work conducted under this proposal will provide further insight into the regulative role of senescent cells within microenvironments in vivo. Leveraging the tools already developed and acquiring new state of the art techniques, we will identify the SASP factors of p16INK4a+ lung fibroblasts at homeostasis and during acute alveolar injury. The knowledge gained through this study will provide clarity on the role SASP from p16INK4a+ plays in regulating epithelial alveolar regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE ChicAgo Center for Health and EnvironmenT (CACHET)”, the first NIEHS P30 environmental health sciences core center in the Chicago area, was established in 2017 as a collaboration between the University of Chicago and University of Illinois at Chicago. Leveraging the experience and progress made over the past 3.5 years, CACHET will continue to promote multidisciplinary environmental health research among clinician, laboratory and population scientists from two Chicago area universities with complementary strengths and structure to understand, evaluate and ultimately reduce environmental health related disparities among residents of the region and beyond.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the discovery of mechanisms by prevalent bacterial members of the human gut microbiome colonize the gut and regulate intestinal inflammation is expected to lead to new approaches for modifying microbiome composition and new treatments for the human inflammatory bowel diseases and other inflammatory disorders. The proposed research is therefore relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental new knowledge that will enhance health and reduce the burdens of illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study leverages available data from four randomized controlled trials (RCTs) that tested interventions to promote HIV care continuum engagement among some of the most socially and medically vulnerable populations in the world, specifically people living with HIV with co-occurring drug use in the U.S., Asia, and Eastern Europe. We will maximize the data to their full potential by analyzing mediators and moderators of efficacy in affecting biological HIV care continuum outcomes (viral suppression, CD4, mortality). The study will improve evaluation methods and measures in future RCTs testing interventions among vulnerable populations.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding the mechanism behind transcriptional regulation of mammary development is essential for lactation. In addition, this will serve to elucidate the role of the repressor E2Fs in mammary development and function. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH mission of understanding growth and development by understanding how E2F transcription factors regulate development of the mammary gland.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent advances in technology are opening the door to exciting new therapeutic strategies for treating diabetes and its complications. Despite a need for a new generation of technologically-skilled translational research leaders, individuals with rigorous analytical science backgrounds who are cross-trained in diabetes research and drug development are rare. The PROMT T32 training program addresses this need by providing a unique predoctoral learning experience focused on leading-edge training in state-of-the-art technologies, translational diabetes research and therapeutic development with an emphasis on providing students from underrepresented groups the structured support needed to thrive as scientific leaders.
PROJECT_TERMS: Diabetes prevention;Metabolism;Risk;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: DIABETES PREVENTION / RISK / OMICS / METABOLISM / THERAPY (PROMT) INTERDISCIPLINARY TRAINING
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Diabetes, Endocrinology and Metabolic Diseases B Study Section[DDK-B]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Clonal hematopoiesis (CH) is an aging associated condition characterized by the clonal outgrowth of mutated pre-leukemic cells. Individuals with CH are at an increased risk of developing hematopoietic malignancies, however the genetic and molecular alterations that cooperate to induce myeloid malignancies in individuals harboring CH-associated mutations remain largely uncharacterized. The impact of this grant application is highly significant, as it (1) provides critical insight into the progression of pre-leukemic states to overt myeloid malignancies, (2) describes a novel tumor suppressor, and (3) has translational implications and fills an unmet clinical need for genetically and phenotypically defined subtypes of AML and MPN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - OVERALL The Environmental Health Sciences Research Center (EHSRC) is the primary environmental health sciences resource for improving the health of rural residents by stimulating and translating innovative environmental health sciences research. This is accomplished by supporting original research addressing rural exposures; population health; susceptibilities; and pathways of toxicity, disease, and repair to enhance environmental health literacy, public health practice, regulatory policy, new clinical treatments, and precision environmental health. The EHSRC supports five Thematic Areas which serve as intellectual hubs, three research facility cores, a Pilot Grant Program, a Career Enhancement Program and a Community Engagement Core that collectively develop fundamental knowledge about living systems to enhance health and reduce the burden of human disease, with an emphasis on rural populations.

PHR: Project Narrative Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) as a cytoprotective-signaling molecule. However, there are still questions regarding how the endogenous production of H2S is regulated and the identification of physiologically relevant protein targets and signaling pathways regulated by H2S. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In recent years, the integration of electrochemical biosensors with microelectronics has opened the avenue for miniaturized, low-cost systems that integrate biomolecular sensing with digital computing, programming, and communication. Here we propose to integrate electrochemical aptamer-based sensors (“aptasensors”) into a microfluidic multi-well platform to enable the recording of cell death and cytokine secretion data from human, intact tumor biopsies in a multiplexed, parallelized format.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: We hypothesize that older subjects with COVID-19, in particular those with new post-COVID subjective or objective cognitive abnormalities, will have increased plasma and radiographic AD/ADRD biomarkers, and a greater likelihood of abnormal cognitive testing and progression to Alzheimer’s disease or related dementias over time. Our proposed studies will elucidate predisposing risk factors and biomarkers for COVID-related cognitive abnormalities, provide mechanistic insights into underlying pathogenesis, and provide data on long- term outcomes, including the development of AD/ADRD-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the regulation of the intestinal epithelial cell’s ability to secret antimicrobial peptides and protect itself from invasion by bacteria in health and diseases such as exposures to enteropathogens and inflammatory bowel disease plays a central role in defense of the body. The proposed studies are relevant to the mission of the NIDDK because they are expected to show a role for carcinoembryonic antigen cell adhesion molecule 1 in these processes and provide a tractable means to enhance the protection of the intestinal epithelium and thus the host from diseases involving intestinal bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The life-threatening diseases Brugada Syndrome and Arrhythmogenic Cardiomyopathy are associated with mutations in proteins with high expression in the intercalated disc: for example, sodium channels and plakoglobin, respectively. Despite that these mutations are thought to be functionally expressed throughout an organism’s lifetime, the disease can be “concealed,” and specifically, patients do not always exhibit a diagnostic ECG, which suggests that mechanisms for treating the disease are in fact tied to the mechanisms that conceal the disease. We hypothesize that a form of cell-to-cell coupling, called ephaptic coupling, can conceal the disease independent of sodium channel or structural protein remodeling, and promoting ephaptic coupling should reduce the risk of lethal arrhythmias in patients with these disease-causing mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Genetic variation impacts gene expression via complex gene regulatory mechanisms that  involve enhancer activation and chromatin folding. However, how genetic variation influences  enhancer activity and chromatin folding has not been fully understood in the developing human  cortex. The work proposed in this application will help delineate genetic influences on enhancer  activity and chromatin folding during human cortical development, which will improve our  understanding of regulatory mechanisms impacting human brain development and risk for  neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative  Multiple distinct epigenetic pathways collaboratively regulate gene expression and play key roles in various biological processes and human diseases. However, the functional interplays between these epigenetic mechanisms remain elusive due to the lack of tools to dissect their relationships. This proposal is to establish a comprehensive toolset that enables the simultaneous but independent control multiple epigenetic mechanisms at defined genome locations. This new toolkit will allow the interrogation of crosstalk between distinct epigenetic pathways and the consequences on gene activities. We expect the results from this research will advance our understanding of gene regulation and lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposed research is relevant to public health because triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most lethal breast cancer with limited treatment options. The goal is to develop nano-formulations based on oligo(lactic acid)n-prodrugs, based on paclitaxel, rapamycin (mTOR) and selumetinib (MEK), focusing on scale-up of GMP- grade material, physicochemical properties, toxicity, pharmacokinetics and biodistribution and evaluation in murine tumor models of TNBC. Nano-formulations based on oligo(lactic acid)n-prodrugs, safely injected as 2- or 3-drug combinations, will prolong, elevate and overlap tumor exposure and potentially exceed antitumor efficacy of standard-of-care (Taxol), oral everolimus and oral selumetinib, which have been tested in clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 90% of breast cancer-related deaths are due to the metastatic relapse of tumors in distant vital organs such as the lung. In the past decade, significant advances in lung metastasis research have revealed intricate tumor-lung microenvironment interactions which are essential for the development of metastatic lung lesions. The studies proposed here will provide novel insights into the poorly understood lung microenvironment at the pre-metastatic stage of breast cancer progression, and establish a foundation for the development of innovative targeting strategies to prevent and cure lung metastases in breast cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: Preschool-age children (3-5 years) from low socioeconomic environments have lower performance in cognition (executive functions, memory) and gross motor skills, which places them at an increased risk for poor academic achievement and low physical activity levels. This proposal will examine the implementation and preliminary efficacy of a provider taught gross motor skill-based physical activity intervention on cognition in children from low socioeconomic environments. Neural changes that occur with improved gross motor skills may have beneficial effects on cognition as well as gross motor skills and, therefore, may provide a feasible approach to support cognitive and motor development of children from low socioeconomic environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Simultaneous alcohol and cannabis consumption is an increasingly common form of drug use among young adults of child-bearing age, and likely contributes to higher rates of polysubstance exposure for fetuses developing in-utero. Prenatal drug exposure not only contributes to lifelong health risks and a shorter lifespan, but also imposes economic and psychosocial burdens on society. By investigating the specific genetic and behavioral consequences of this combined drug exposure, we aim to inform targeted treatments for individuals with a history of prenatal polysubstance exposure and improve their overall quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative According to the American Sleep Association, 50-70 million US adults have a sleep disorder, insomnia being the most common specific sleep disorder with 30% of adults reporting short term issues and 10% reporting chronic insomnia. Meanwhile, 37.9% US adults reported unintentionally falling asleep during the day at least once in the preceding month, while 4.7% reported nodding off or falling asleep while driving at least once in the preceding month. Given that drowsy driving is responsible for 1,550 fatalities and 40,000 nonfatal injuries annually in the US, this remains a serious public health crisis requiring serious attention. Meanwhile, neuropathic pain estimated in the general population to range between 3% and 17%, lacks an effective treatment as most of the available treatments have only moderate efficacy and present significant side effects that limit their use. Therefore, other therapeutic approaches, such as the development of biased 5- HT7R agonists which have been demonstrated to have therapeutic advantages for treating certain sleep disorders and neuropathic pain and are proposed in this application, are urgently needed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY LAS CRUCES
PHR: Project Narrative Anti-mitotic drugs have been used as cancer chemotherapeutics for decades. However, our understanding of cellular responses to mitotic delay is incomplete, possibly precluding the use of less toxic approaches. In this proposal, we will employ a combination of biochemical and live cell imaging approaches to examine how a signaling pathway that regulates growth, survival and metabolism determines the fate of cells arrested in mitosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Using intracranial recording in humans undergoing epilepsy surgery, we study how prefrontal cortex dependent brain networks support attention, memory, learning and interpersonal communication. Prefrontal dysfunction is linked to a host of disabling neurological, developmental and psychiatric. This work is core to the NIH mission providing insights into prefrontal control of human behavior with implications for the understanding of normal cognition applicable to the diagnosis and treatment of clinical disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: In mood disorders, such as depression or schizophrenia, patients may lose positive hedonic capacity for normal pleasures in life, or develop pathologically excessive negative affective reactions, with devastating consequences for their well-being and psychological function. The proposed research will identify how brain circuitry generates positive hedonic ‘liking’ reactions to pleasant stimuli, and how pathological dysfunctions in those hedonic brain mechanisms causes excessive negative dysphoric reactions. Better understanding of how brain circuitry generates positive hedonic ‘liking’, and how neural dysfunction in that circuitry causes intense negative dysphoria, will help lead eventually to improved science-based treatments for depression and other mood disorders.

PHR: Center Overview - Project Narrative Gastrointestinal diseases place a tremendous burden on US and South Carolina healthcare. The vision for the Medical University of South Carolina (MUSC) Digestive Disease Research Core Center (DDRCC) is to improve gastrointestinal health by providing support for existing digestive and liver disease research at MUSC via development of new opportunities for collaboration and research programs. The MUSC DDRCC Biomedical Research Cores (Analytical Cell Models, Advanced Imaging, and Proteomics), Clinical Component, and Pilot & Feasibility and Enrichment Programs will create a multifaceted foundation that will support this mission.

PHR: NARRATIVE Over the past 22 years as an active member of the Maternal Fetal Medicine Unit (MFMU), the University of North Carolina (UNC) MFMU has proven its commitment by conducting clinical trials with efficiency, excellent subject recruitment and retention, and high data quality. Our solid infrastructure, large diverse patient population, and experienced, committed team members will ensure our success in the upcoming cycle In this proposal we describe our plans to continue our substantive contribution to the research in the MFMU Network by drawing on strengths that are directly aligned to support the MFMU Congressional and public health goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need to develop novel therapies in small cell lung cancer (SCLC), a disease for which treatment has stagnated for three decades. We previously discovered that targeting replication stress response (RSR) proteins is a therapeutic opportunity in SCLC. We will (1) characterize the cell-intrinsic and immune- related changes following RSR exacerbation, and (2) develop combinatorial approaches of RSR inhibitors with immune checkpoint blockade to develop potentially revolutionary personalized immunotherapies for SCLC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative It is well established that children with mild-to-severe hearing loss are at risk for significant language delays compared to children with normal hearing, and language deficits are exacerbated by poor hearing aid fitting and inconsistent hearing aid use. However, the underlying neural mechanisms remain unknown, as very few studies have examined how such hearing loss affects the brain dynamics serving language processing in these children. The proposed study will determine the impact of mild-to-severe hearing loss and the role of hearing aid use and fit on multiple facets of language processing in children using a cutting-edge multimodal neuroimaging approach coupled with advanced behavioral and neuropsychological measures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most common cause of disability among aging adults and is a significant clinical challenge and public health burden as there is currently no treatment to prevent disease progression or induce cartilage regeneration. Chronic, low-grade inflammation in the joint is now recognized as a key contributor to OA pathogenesis, however, the source of this inflammation and its role in joint degeneration is currently unclear. The experiments outlined in this proposal are designed to examine whether aging chondrocytes are the initial source of pro-inflammatory factors due to DNA double-strand breaks and elevated activity of a protein known to initiate pro-inflammatory signaling in response to damaged DNA. Whether inhibition of this protein could be a viable therapeutic approach to preventing the onset or progression of disease will be investigated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ongoing opioid epidemic has forced the medical community to examine how it uses opioids for pain man-agement. Spinal anesthetics are able to provide analgesia without opioids while further inducing a sedated brain state, unlike in adults and older children, but the neurological basis underlying this clinical observation is not fully understood. The research project and career development activities in this K23 application, led by an anesthe-siologist-investigator at Montefiore-Einstein, will clarify neurophysiological correlates of general anesthesia and opioid-sparing spinal anesthesia with the long-term goal of improving anesthesia care in children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the large number of persons living with disabling hearing loss worldwide, medical therapies for hearing loss have remained limited. To target treatments and provide better therapies, we require a basic understanding of how the auditory system functions. In this study, I will investigate the importance of the lipid membrane in regulating the sensitivity of the auditory hair cell mechanotransduction process, a site for where multiple human genetic mutations occur, and a target of noise and age induced hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Generation of induced neuronal (iN) cells from human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs) offers great potential for central nervous system (CNS) disease modeling and drug screening, however, current differentiation methods are often laborious, time-consuming, and inefficient. It is increasing clear that mechanical forces provide overarching signals for cell fate choice, but how the mechanochemical signaling transmit to the nucleus and alters the chromatin structure is unclear. Here, I propose to investigate a novel intrinsically-regulated mechano- signaling pathway impact on the nuclear organization of the genome to promote neuronal differentiation, which besides advancing fundamental understanding of neuronal lineage specification, this project will establish a new ‘force-based’ method for the generation of iNs, thus facilitating hPSC-based strategies to model and potentially to treat CNS diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Loss of neurons that produce the neuromodulatory neurotransmitter acetylcholine in the basal forebrain are correlated with cognitive decline in Lewy Body Dementia, and loss of these neurons is predictive of patients with Parkinson’s Disease developing Parkinson’s Disease Dementia. This project aims to understand how loss of acetylcholine release or signaling in mouse models of Lewy Body Dementia lead to cortical dysfunction and subsequent cognitive decline. The successful completion of this project will not only lead to a better understanding of how cortical dysfunction leads to cognitive decline, but will also lead to a better understanding of how to leverage cholinergic signaling for novel therapeutics in Lewy Body Dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) for the treatment of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), an under- recognized but common disorder after stroke, holds promise to improve stroke outcomes but is severely limited by poor post-stroke adherence. We propose to adapt and refine a multicomponent CPAP adherence intervention for stroke patients and then test it among stroke patients. Optimization of CPAP use among stroke patients will allow for the conduct of rigorous clinical trials of OSA treatment after stroke and ultimately to advance the care of stroke patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Tumor cells and the microenvironment are rewired in response to targeted therapeutics, resulting in adaptive responses, including compensatory oncogenic pathway activation and changes in tumor ecosystem heterogeneity, leading to drug resistance and relapse. Blocking therapy-induced adaptive responses with rational drug combinations that are designed to interdict the emergence of resistance is predicted to yield more durable responses, and significantly improve patient benefits; however, the discovery of effective combinations is highly challenging due to the complexity and diversity of adaptive mechanisms within the tumor ecosystem. We will discover combination therapies that interdict adaptive responses in the tumor ecosystem through comprehensive drug response profiling from single cells and bulk tissues, data-driven mathematical modeling to predict responses to untested perturbations, subsequent in vitro/in vivo validation, and data-guided clinical trials.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obstetric admissions are the leading cause of hospitalization in the United States, and a significant portion of the obstetric population experiences adverse outcomes that may adversely affect the short- and long-term health of both birthing individuals and their infants. In addition, disparities in maternal and infant morbidity and mortality are profound, and coordinated, rigorous, and definitive scientific efforts are required to improve obstetric outcomes and reduce inequity. The Northwestern Study Center, as part of the Maternal-Fetal Medicine Units (MFMU) Network, will substantively contribute to the MFMU Network’s large-scale clinical trials and observational studies that are needed to improve obstetric outcomes, reduce disparities, and thereby enhance public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Waterpipe tobacco smoking is common among young adults in the U.S. There are significant health effects associated with waterpipe tobacco smoking, but young adults erroneously believe it to be less harmful and addictive than cigarette smoking. This project will develop and test health warnings to increase young adults' accurate perceptions of harm and decrease use, which will lead to reductions in tobacco-related diseases, including cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are persistent “forever chemicals” associated with developmental toxicity, but data are lacking in older adults in whom altered metabolism, decreased clearance, and hormonal changes may heighten PFAS vulnerability. This study will investigate the impact of PFAS exposure across midlife and older age on (1) musculoskeletal health and (2) cardiovascular disease in older adults, and (3) the potential for lifestyle behaviors to mitigate these health impacts. Our findings will inform PFAS legislation and health guidance for exposed individuals, with implications for musculoskeletal and cardiovascular risk reduction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitophagy is a critical mechanism to preserve cardiovascular homeostasis by selectively eliminating dysfunctional mitochondria. This project aims to delineate novel molecular mechanisms connecting mitophagy to neddylation, and to assess the physiological implications of mitophagy in cardiac aging. These studies will lead to a greater understanding of how neddylation is linked to mitochondrial quality control, and provide the groundwork for the development of novel therapeutic approaches to combat age-related cardiac dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ABCD Study consortium uses multimodal brain imaging, cognitive and clinical assessments, bioassays, mobile monitoring, and careful assessment of substance use, environment, psychopathological symptoms, and social functioning in 11,878 9-10 year-olds to be followed over 10 years, to determine the effects of substance use on adolescent brain and cognitive development. This ABCD Research Project Site will follow and assess participants enrolled in the study. These data will be shared with the scientific community to address a comprehensive range of questions concerning youth development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE After a sexual assault, peers often express confusion about how to best support survivors and may encourage drinking to cope, which can exacerbate the wide range of physical and mental health problems survivors experience, contributing to persistent distress, long-term healthcare costs, and loss of productivity. The current project involves the design and feasibility testing of a novel web-based intervention to increase effective peer support of survivors by focusing on behaviors incompatible with heavy drinking, which will in turn reduce alcohol use and related consequences within high-risk social networks of sororities. If feasibility and preliminary intervention effects are supported, this intervention could be widely disseminated and facilitate change in drinking norms among social networks of young adults, as well as mitigate distress after sexual assaults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research will develop and evaluate an implementation strategy that targets the balance between intervention fidelity and flexibility (i.e., co-production) in order to enhance caregiver engagement within a parent-mediated intervention (PMI) for Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) when delivered in a state-funded Early Intervention system. This is a critical need given high attrition when PMIs have been delivered in diverse community settings, which may reflect an emphasis on implementing and adapting PMIs in a manner that maintains fidelity while also conflicting with the complex needs of underrepresented families. This proposal and my long-term goals are aligned with NIMH’s objective [4.3a to adapt evidence-based models to account for moderators, including social determinants of health, that impact intervention effectiveness among underrepresented groups], as this project will develop and provide evidence on the feasibility of an implementation strategy aimed at enhancing caregiver engagement by blancing fidelity to an evidence-based PMI with the needs and priorities of caregivers who have been historically underrepresented in ASD early intervention research.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Through renewal and active participation in this multicenter collaborative research program, UAB clinical center researchers will assist the MFMU Network in conceiving and designing new innovative studies and complete ongoing projects intended to improve obstetric care, pregnancy health, and outcomes for pregnant and lactating people and their babies. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The NICHD MFMU Network is the premier obstetric research network in the world. Clinical investigations of the causes of maternal, perinatal, and infant mortality and morbidity and their ultimate prevention require large and diverse numbers of participants who are recruited from multiple collaborating centers. The Ohio State University Center has been a leading member of the MFMU Network since 1992 and has an energized research team committed to building upon our tradition of excellence in order to achieve the goals of the Network in conducting clinical trials and observational studies in a collaborative approach across all Network centers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Drugs that activate opioid receptors are widely used as analgesics, but they can cause serious problems such as opioid use disorder and respiratory depression. The vast majority of studies on opioid receptors have used exogenous ligands, and only a few studies have investigated the biological peptides that normally activate the receptors in the body. We will study the signaling induced by endogenous opioid peptides versus representative opioid drugs, in order to identify potential target mechanisms for developing better analgesics with fewer unwanted side-effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oncogenic long noncoding RNAs (LncRNAs) contribute to many mechanisms of cancer biology. This project investigates how a single chemical modification to a breast-cancer associated LncRNA can potentiate its oncogenic activity, whereas disruption of this modification can switch the LncRNA to an anti-tumor mechanism. Proof-of-principle experiments to manipulate this switch for novel therapeutic intervention will guide a long-term goal of clinical application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Ataxia telangiectasia (A-T) is a genetic disorder characterized by cerebellar neurodegeneration, progressive pulmonary dysfunction, immunodeficiencies, insulin resistance, sterility, and cancer predisposition. Data from the Kastan lab suggests that ATM, the gene which is mutated in A-T, plays an essential role in regulating metabolic function, mitochondrial quality control, and redox homeostasis through interactions with the autophagy regulator Beclin-1 and novel, as of yet uncharacterized cytoplasmic proteins. The experiments outlined in this proposal will explore validate these interactions and explore their functional impacts on mitochondrial, metabolic, and redox homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Though survivors of adolescent and young adult cancer (AYAs) are at high risk for obesity and related comorbidities, to date there are no behavioral weight management interventions specifically designed to meet the unique needs of this population. Building on our previous trials and pilot data, the proposed study will test the efficacy of digital tools (wireless scales, activity trackers, social networking website) paired with a novel 6- month mHealth weight management intervention adapted for both developmental stage and cancer context, compared to a self-guided arm. If efficacious, this approach to weight management for AYAs has high potential to improve health outcomes, reduce the burden of morbidity in AYAs, and be widely disseminated to AYA survivors across the country.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major impediment to spinal cord regeneration is the failure to clear cellular debris at the injury site, which creates a very unique lipid-dense environment due to abundance of myelin debris. Excessive uptake of lipid in phagocytic cells transforms them into inflammatory cells that contribute to the pathogenesis of SCI. Thus, we propose to investigate the molecular mechanisms the lead to lipid accumulation in foamy macrophages and how they contribute to a fibrotic environment at the injury site.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Early clinical trials have demonstrated the potential for bNAbs to treat and prevent HIV infection; however, in clinical trials, participants are enrolled without knowledge of their viral susceptibility to bNAbs, which in turn adversely affects bNAb clinical evaluation. We aim to develop accurate assays that measure viral susceptibility to bNAbs at the point-of-care with fast turnaround so that pre-existing and emerging resistance can be identified timely. Such information will greatly impact and improve trials to determine the true efficacy and cutoffs for clinical use of bNAbs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE T cells and B cells are the two crucial components of the adaptive immune system. Next generation sequencing of the T and B cell receptors can be used to profile the T and B cell repertoire (Rep-seq). We hypothesize that understanding the network architecture of the immune repertoire will reveal the role of adaptive immune response to cancer immunotherapy and viral infections. We propose to apply network analysis with advanced statistical approaches and computational techniques on Rep-seq data to unravel how the adaptive immune system is altered by immunotherapy within clinical responders and non-responders and how the adaptive immune system reacts to SARs-Cov-2 virus infection.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Research Narrative  In this submission, we have conveyed our 20-year history as an active and productive Clinical Center within the Eunice Kennedy Shriver NICHD Maternal Fetal Medicine Units Research Network, our potential for growth, and our commitment to full participation in all current and future MFMU Network studies. Our Case Western Reserve University site joined the MFMU Network in 2001 and now offers all obstetric hospital systems in Cleveland where we will continue our efficient staffing model for recruitment and reproducible data, utilize our knowledge of informatics and the integrated medical records systems across the three sites, and share a collaborative leadership model for region-wide research. The affiliation of all three systems with Case Western Reserve University provides economy of scale in infrastructure, facilitates cross-institutional collaboration locally and within the MFMU Network, and allows us to represent a diverse population with high rates of preterm birth and infant and maternal morbidity to support the NICHD efforts to reduce disparities and answer some of the most pertinent questions in Obstetrics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Rare genetic variants of the essential sarcomere protein titin (TTN) is the most common genetic cause of dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), a disease characterized by enlargement and weakening of one or both of main chambers of the heart. DCM often progresses to heart failure, a devastating disorder with high morbidity and early mortality, but only limited options are currently available to treat DCM. This proposal aims to determine how TTN gene expression is regulated, augment the amount of TTN expression via genome editing, assess effects of increased TTN protein level on cardiomyocytes with pathogenic TTN variants, and ultimately establish therapeutic strategies for DCM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Somatic mutations (genomic variants that occur after conception) have long been known to be an important cause of cancer, but recent research has found that they are also responsible for a range of other human disorders as well as phenotypic variations between individuals. The overall goal of the Somatic Mosaicism across Human Tissues (SMaHT) Network is to gain a better understanding of how somatic mutations influences biology and disease. As part of the SMaHT network, the goal of our project is to develop better and cheaper methods of detecting somatic mutations that are likely to influence human biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The protected time and resources provided through this K24 mid-career mentoring award will enhance my ability to recruit and train patient-oriented researchers focused on addressing obesity-related health disparities and improving care of vulnerable patients with obesity. The research aims, focused on evaluating the impact of social determinants of health on weight management, will provide additional opportunities for me and my trainees to obtain additional expertise in health equity, social determinants of health, and community-engaged research. With guidance from my K24 Advisory Committee and hands-on training, I will enhance my skills in recruiting and mentoring under-represented minority trainees to enhance their training, support their individual research, and improve the care of vulnerable patients with obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The pressing need to distinguish potentially lethal from indolent prostate cancer is usually approached by attempting to identify genomic predictors in the malignant epithelial tissue. However, from extensive cell biology research, it is known that the microenvironment plays a critical role in cancer progression, though a deeper understanding of the mechanism is needed. In this proposal, we will study gene expression of the prostate microenvironment to improve the understanding of its impact on the biology of the tumor and to augment previously proposed genomic predictors of lethal prostate cancer by developing a gene expression signature from the stromal tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: DNA methylation patterns are dysregulated in many human diseases, suggesting that elements of disease initiation may be common across diseases. The proposed research aims to characterize pan-disease patterns of methylation dysregulation and to identify genes and regulators that lead to methylation dysregulation. This will contribute to fundamental knowledge of disease initiation and identify potential targets for disease diagnosis and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity-associated asthma affects approximately 8 million adults in the United States. Obese adults with late- onset, nonatopic asthma experience more severe symptoms and fewer days of asthma control, resulting in increased asthma-related hospitalizations and reduced quality of life. This proposal will improve treatment options for obesity-associated asthma by developing the microbiome-metabolome and its involvement in inflammatory signaling along the gut-lung axis as a novel targeted therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The escalating frequency of osteoporosis, fractures, and cartilage defects are a major health burden of our modern society. Loss of skeletal integrity and regeneration capacity through aging underlies a detrimental shift of bone formation and resorption dynamics originating from the skeletal stem cell (SSC) compartment. This proposal aims to mechanistically investigate age-related changes of SSC heterogeneity as well as the role of an unexplored age-related stem cell-regulating factor which, if properly understood, could be instrumental to provide new therapeutic avenues for the alleviation of these emerging medical challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: The most common cause of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (Lou Gehrig’s disease, ALS) and Frontotemporal Dementia is a repetitive element within the gene C9orf72. This repeat causes disease at least in part by producing toxic proteins through an unusual process known as RAN translation. This proposal will use biochemical techniques, neurons, and multiple model systems- including patient derived induced pluripotent stem cell models, to understand how RAN translation works and how it might be selectively targeted in patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The incidence of infertility is on the rise, affecting nearly 20% of the couples in the reproductive age group. Male infertility contributes to approximately half the number of cases, yet, the reasons for male infertility are not known. This project will develop a novel mouse line that enables researchers to probe the mechanisms of male infertility; it will also reveal whether TDP-43, known to cause human pathology, plays a role in the proper formation of spermatozoa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In disease, the heart is unable to pump a sufficient amount of blood to meet the metabolic demands of the body. We have identified a novel signaling mediated phosphorylation to increase cardiac contraction that this study will establish as beneficial to improve heart function in disease and that is without long-term detrimental effects. The data generated from this proposal will be critical towards informing future novel therapeutic approaches to improve cardiac contraction and the insufficient heart function that is at the root of heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative. The validation and implementation of efficient, cost-effective screening tools that can accurately detect the earliest stages of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) in primary care settings is of paramount importance for the advancement of AD clinical care and prevention research. The objective of this study is to assess the feasibility, reliability and validity of novel digital cognitive screening tools for remote and in-clinic assessment. Our goal is to advance new technologies that are sensitive to detect subtle AD-associated cognitive decline, require minimal training to administer, have low patient burden, and are acceptable and accurate in diverse older adult populations.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The Maternal Fetal Medicine Units (MFMU) Network performs clinical trials that provide for improved care and treatment of pregnant people and their fetuses; thus, allowing for improved outcomes in maternal and child health. The clinical research environment in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Penn is exciting and continually growing, and the outstanding leadership team of the MFMU Network clinical center at Penn reflects a strong commitment for ongoing engagement by the department in the MFMU Network. The investigative team at Penn has built a highly successful MFMU Network clinical site that will support the NICHD's guiding principles shaping the 21st century landscape for multi-site clinical research, including enhanced rigor for selecting studies, availability of Network infrastructure to a wider range of investigators, data sharing and access to biospecimens, and inclusion of diverse populations in Network studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This is a small clinical trial of a new brain stimulation intervention for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). We will use implanted electrodes to stimulate two brain areas related to OCD in a way that should specifically de-synchronize them, while also recording the electrical activity of the brain in response to stimulation. If successful, we will have both a new treatment for OCD and will also learn how the brain's electrical activity changes when stimulation is applied, which should help design better treatments for OCD and other psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Microbial keratitis, or infectious corneal ulceration, is a leading cause of corneal blindness but is difficult to objectively measure. Developing objective, reproducible, and clinically relevant outcome metrics for microbial keratitis would improve the clinical applicability and statistical power of future studies. This study uses multimodal imaging on a cohort of patients with microbial keratitis to compare different modalities’ measurements of corneal thinning, assess evolution of corneal scar density in microbial keratitis, and evaluate whether certain early clinical and anatomic features can improve prediction of visual outcomes in microbial keratitis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it involves experiments pertinent to the question of whether 1.5 million infants and toddlers who receive general anesthetics as part of early procedures may be at risk for developing mood and addiction disorders as adults, and identifies a pharmacologically-targetable molecular substrate for the observed circuit-level and behavioral changes in exposed populations. The project is relevant to NIH's mission because it 1) identifies basic processes in terms of the long-lasting effects of a specific class of drugs on the body that have implications for multiple disease areas, 2) delineates the consequences of these effects for circuit function and behavior as an output of the activity of this specific circuit, providing a path for early intervention strategies for mental illness and drug addiction resulting from the identified disruptions in the studied molecules, circuits and behaviors.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research education meets the need for training in methods of statistical genetics for mental health researchers working with genome wide association studies, next generation sequencing studies, and twin and family studies of genetic and environmental influences on mental illnesses. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative All-trans Retinoic acid (atRA), the biologically active form of Vitamin A, acts to regulate genome program by activating RA receptors, known as canonical activity, and to elicits non-canonical activities recently identified in multiple physiological processes via CRABP1. The long-term goal of this project is to comprehensively understand how vitamin A (atRA) affects health and diseases. The current proposal focuses on the non- canonical atRA signaling mediated by Crabp1 to modulate CaMKII signaling in excitable cells such as motor neurons, which is essential to the health of neural muscular junction and motor function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Osteocalcin is proposed, based on studying one knockout mouse strain, to be a potent, bone-expressed, hormone that affects glucose metabolism, fat storage, muscle mass, cognition, and fertility. However, the robustness and reproducibility of these effects is now questioned by their absence in 2 other osteocalcin knockout mouse strains. Because of osteocalcin’s potential importance as a therapeutic agent, drug target, and biomarker in human health and disease, it is essential to understand the basis for discrepant phenotypes among different osteocalcin knockout mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Older adults with opioid use disorder who receive care in opioid treatment programs are at heightened risk of being socially isolated, reporting loneliness, and experiencing everyday stigma. Measuring the lack of social connectedness and its relationship to intersectional stigma is important given their possible influence on treatment and health outcomes. The information learned from this project will inform providers and policymakers across the spectrum of clinical care on improving social connectedness among a growing yet often overlooked population made vulnerable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Doxorubicin (Adriamycin®) is a highly effective cancer treatment, but it causes heart toxicity in 10 to 20 percent of patients who receive it. This proposal seeks to understand how the heme-binding protein hemopexin could serve as a blood biomarker as well as a protective treatment for patients at risk of doxorubicin heart toxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Failure of proper cell cycle control results in chromosome instability which is a hallmark of tumorigenesis. It has been extensively studied how Cyclin Dependent Kinase (Cdk1) promotes cell cycle progression, but little is known how the Cdk1-dependent phosphorylation events are reversed by phosphatase. In this study, we identify and investigate targets of the PP2A phosphatase during cell cycle progression.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative: Chemotherapy-induced premature menopause and infertility are major sources of health problems. If the mechanisms of chemotherapy-induced oocyte death as well the pathways to repair and prevent such damage are understood, quality of life of cancer survivors can be greatly enhanced. The same knowledge would also enable us to moderate reproductive aging for all women and can also provide insights into the prevention of overall aging.

PHR: Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in individuals receiving allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-HSCT). Plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) are known potent suppressor of alloreactive T cell responses and can be potentially used to reduce GVHD. The proposed studies will investigate the role of Dot1l in regulating the dynamics of the interaction between pDCs and GVHD in the setting of allo-HSCT and the impact of pDCs on controlling GVHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related death in the United States and is in grave need of new therapeutic strategies. This proposal examines the intersection of the field of cancer neurogenesis and cancer immunology by studying the role of Spon1+ inflammatory monocytes on the progression of lung cancer. I incorporate in vitro and in vivo techniques to answer how nerves are recruited into tumors by inflammatory monocytes and to determine their role in lung cancer tumor progression and metastasis with a long term goal of providing patients with more effective treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Ocular pathologies and vision loss are understudied sequelae of numerous autoimmune diseases despite being prevalent in multiple sclerosis (MS), neuromyelitis optica (NMO), uveitis, and Sjogren’s syndrome. The proposed studies using a mouse model of MS are designed to advance a readily-implementable nutritional approach to mitigate autoimmune demyelinating optic neuritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Youth-onset type 2 diabetes is increasingly common and parallels the obesity epidemic, yet effective treatment and prevention strategies for high-risk children are extremely limited. It remains unclear why some high-risk youth experience normal pubertal progression, while others do not, despite similar physical and metabolic characteristics. The Biostatistics Research Center will provide the framework and infrastructure for the Understanding and Targeting the Pathophysiology of Youth-onset Type 2 Diabetes Consortium though effective and collaborative organization, communication, and support, to successfully recruit a cohort of pubertal youth at risk for developing prediabetes and type 2 diabetes, deeply phenotype them through puberty, and contribute to a better understanding of the pathophysiology of youth-onset type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Triple negative breast cancer is a lethal cancer subtype that lacks targeted therapies and patients have a grim prognosis. Taking advantage of TNBC’s dependency on sterol uptake, removal of misfolded proteins and altered redox homeostasis, this application seeks to investigate ergosterol peroxide, a natural product sterol with promising cancer cell death inducing properties. Herein, we propose to demonstrate the mechanism of action by which EP suppresses cancer progression, as well as EPs safety and bioavailability to develop a promising therapeutic strategy for this intractable disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The neural circuit that controls mammalian reproduction feeds information on circadian rhythms from the suprachiasmatic nucleus via the neuropeptides arginine vasopressin and vasoactive intestinal peptide to the kisspeptin and gonadotropin-releasing hormone neurons, respectively, and the kisspeptin neurons detect sex steroid hormone status to integrate these signals to the gonadotropin-releasing hormone neurons. All of these hypothalamic neuronal populations depend on homeodomain proteins for development and function, in particular, Ventral Anterior Homeobox 1 (Vax1), Six3, and Six6. Defects in this hypothalamic neuronal circuit cause infertility and subfertility and alter circadian rhythms; thus, elucidation of the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying development, migration, network formation, and responses to circadian cues of this hypothalamic circuit, are critical for our understanding of hypothalamic development and reproductive function.
