PHR: Mental illness characterized by dysregulated behaviors contribute to emotional and physical suffering and are associated with high healthcare costs and increased risk of death to the self and others. The proposed training program will train the next generation of investigators pursuing translational research to reveal the underlying mechanisms contributing to mental illness and reduce disorder-related suffering, economic burden, and mortality through identifying novel targets for prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Cell fate recommitment underlies the pathogenesis of multiple esophageal diseases including Barrett’s esophagus and small cell carcinoma in the esophagus. This proposal will identify the mechanism by which the transcription factor p63 safeguards esophageal basal progenitor cells from neuroendocrine cell differentiation. The knowledge gained will be used for comprehensively identifying new therapeutic targets for treating esophageal diseases involving cell fate switch.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Narrative Proper microglia functioning is necessary for a healthy brain; disruption of microglia can alter behavior and lead to neurological pathologies. We will study how microglia are regulated by sensory experience and in turn how they may impact the perineuronal net, a neuron specific form of the extracellular matrix. The perineuronal net protects cells from oxidate stress and constrains neural alterations in adulthood. How microglia and the perineuronal net interact is unknown and will be the focus of the present study using a synthesis of anatomical, physiological and behavioral experiments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A better understanding of factors contributing to sustainability of evidence-based interventions is urgently needed to improve childhood cancer survival in low-resource settings. This project studies the ability of low- resource hospitals in Latin American to sustain an evidence-based intervention, a Pediatric Early Warning System (PEWS), that improves outcomes among hospitalized children with cancer. Upon completion, this study will identify components of clinical capacity that contribute to long-term sustainability of interventions in low-resource hospitals and develop strategies to promote sustainability, thus advancing the science of implementation and improving survival for children with cancer globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE Mendelian conditions, particularly those presenting during childhood, are a major disease burden causing suffering and taxing the healthcare system, yet are difficult to diagnose. To improve the rate of diagnosis, we propose a Pediatric Mendelian Genomics Research Center, leveraging the pediatric clinical and research expertise of Children’s National Hospital and Research Institute in a partnership with Invitae, a world leader in affordable and comprehensive genetic testing, and incorporating innovative sequencing and variant evaluation strategies to better discover disease-causing variants. Our center, in collaboration with the other Mendelian Genomic Research Centers, will draw from a large and diverse population to identify the underlying causes of Mendelian disease and translate the findings into clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative When cancer cells sustain deletion of a tumor suppressor gene, neighboring genes are invariably co-deleted. When the passenger deleted gene is a member of a gene family that encodes a cell essential function, the redundant gene (co-expressed paralog) residing elsewhere in the genome represents a cancer-specific vulnerability that would spare normal cells with intact genomes. We believe that this proposed research study will identify multiple novel drug targets for cancer treatment, thereby improving outcomes and prolonging patients’ lives.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The NICHD MFMU Network conducts randomized clinical trials and large-scale observational studies designed to improve maternal and perinatal outcomes. For the past 27 years, the Utah Network Center has been a major contributor of research protocols and high-quality research data derived from a large, community-based population in the Intermountain West. The Utah Center’s impressive past performance and it’s stable long-term capabilities make it an ideal candidate to continue its work on MFMU Network protocols through 2030.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is the leading cause of irreversible blindness in African Americans. This proposal will identify and investigate genetic variants of biologic importance to this disease using genotypic and phenotypic data from the Primary Open- Angle African American Glaucoma Genetics study cohort. Our findings will contribute to the development of more targeted screening and precise therapeutic interventions for this blinding disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance to public health statement The NIA/AA for Institute on Methods and Protocols for Advancement of Clinical Trials in ADRD (NIA/AA IMPACT-AD Course) is a 4.5-day multidisciplinary in-person clinical trial training course providing focused instruction on the design, conduct and analysis of ADRD clinical trials, ranging from mechanistic studies to large, community-based interventions. Multidisciplinary training that combines traditional clinical trials education with specialized skills in biostatistics, study recruitment, study organization, neuropsychology, ethics and informatics will accelerate the establishment of a new, diverse and well-trained cadre of investigators to lead the development of therapies for ADRD, a key priority for improving public health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of individuals take hormonal contraceptives (HC) often starting at adolescence when ovarian hormones have important effects on maturation of the prefrontal cortex (PFC). Yet, there is a fundamental lack of information about the consequences of hormonal alterations with adolescent HC use on PFC development. Considering that HC usage among adolescents has been associated with greater depression risk in adulthood, understanding how HC influence mood regulating brain regions like the PFC is critical and will better inform the use of HC among teens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: Genomic integrity is challenged by spontaneous DNA damage that results from endogenous and exogenous sources. This proposal focuses on elucidating the molecular mechanisms by which cells detect and repair the most common forms of DNA damage, especially single strand breaks and damaged bases. This information is critical to understanding the impact of genetic deficiencies, exposure to carcinogens, and to improving cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The events of developmental programming are thought to contribute to an increased prevalence of metabolic disorders, but the physiological events driving the programming of key neural inputs linked to the homeostatic processes of drinking and feeding remain poorly understood. This proposal will be the first step in defining the developmental integration of drinking and feeding states during the neonatal period in the hypothalamus. The results of this proposal will provide new insight into unappreciated developmental events that impact metabolic phenotypes throughout life, which could ultimately lead to new therapeutic targets for metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Numerous reports link socioeconomic and ethnic disparities to the frequency, lack of care, and severity of chronic disorders and disabilities in US minority and low-income populations compared with majority, more affluent groups. Training a diverse research workforce to address these disparities is increasingly critical when considering the burden on society of unequal health care. The aim of Brooklyn College’s U-RISE proposal is to increase the impact of research produced by individuals from diverse backgrounds to avoid even greater health disparities in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Melanocyte regeneration is important for the homeostasis and repair of pigmented skin. This proposal seeks to identify and characterize genetic and cellular factors that guide melanocyte regeneration, both by identifying and characterizing human melanocyte stem cells and utilizing the advantages of functional analyses available in the zebrafish system. The knowledge gained from these studies aims to positively impact treatment of individuals with pigmentary disorders, including the 0.2-1.8% of the world’s population with vitiligo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Spontaneous brain activity drives dramatic variability in both neural and perceptual responses to identical sensory stimuli. Although this finding has sparked myriad resting state fMRI studies searching for links between spontaneous brain states and psychiatric diagnoses, little is understood about the fundamental neurocognitive processes underlying spontaneous brain states. My proposal applies cutting-edge technologies to reveal the predictive functions and basic circuit mechanisms underlying spontaneous cortical states, with the ultimate goal of generating novel insights into how resting state activity contributes to psychiatric illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative MEG has an excellent spatiotemporal resolution and it is an excellent tool for non-invasive study of normal brain functions as well as diagnosis of a large variety of neurological conditions including epilepsy, autism spectrum disorders, Parkinson’s disease, and Alzheimer’s disease. The spatial resolution of MEG is limited by the signal-to-noise ratio of brain-related magnetic fields but also the fact that the spatially smooth features of the brain signals dominate the measurements over the more fine-detailed components. This research will provide novel mathematical methods to extract and emphasize the fine-detailed field components, both in terms of mathematical modeling and design of novel MEG sensor array geometries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cadmium is a toxic metal that is a major public health concern, due to its ubiquity in the human environment. If successful, our work will show that exposure to cadmium during development causes non-alcoholic fatty liver disease in later life through activating a specific set of genes, identifying these genes as potential markers of disease susceptibility and novel targets for treatment. Given that NAFLD affects 30-40 % of the US adult population, and has been linked to metabolic impairments and a shorter lifespan, findings from our work have the potential to improve disease prediction and management for a large number of people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Enzymes turn atmospheric nitrogen into ammonia, and turn carbon dioxide into reduced products; in both cases, they use clusters of iron and sulfur atoms. The mechanisms of these clusters are unclear, and we propose to prepare new chemical compounds with iron-sulfur environments that resemble those in the clusters. Using these synthetic clusters, we will illuminate the fundamental chemistry underlying their reactions in nature.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  “Immunotherapeutic targeting of MIF-dependent chaperone activity”  Despite some very encouraging improvements in response rates and overall survival in late-stage melanoma patients receiving anti-PD-1/anti-CTLA-4 immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) immunotherapies, an unacceptably high percentage of treated patients remain unresponsive to these therapies. Studies proposed in this project application will investigate a unique metabolic transcriptional programming pathway that is governed by MIF-dependent chaperone activity. When therapeutically inhibited with a suicide antagonist discovered by our laboratory, highly immune suppressive myeloid lineage cells are converted to highly immune stimulatory myeloid cells in the tumor microenvironment which is sufficient to induce tumor rejection and increased survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE To our knowledge, this is the first study prospectively designed to directly compare effectiveness and acceptability of menthol EC versus tobacco EC in menthol smokers transitioning to EC. We expect that both products will be acceptable and result in high rates of switching and improvements in tobacco-related health effects. Impact on the field will be significant. The study will provide critical data to the FDA to support restrictions on menthol EC that could slow youth and young adult initiation with no resulting negative impact on switching in adult combustible cigarette smokers transitioning to EC and no unintended consequences in a priority population of predominately African American and Latinx smokers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myocardial infarction is the most prevalent sequela of ischemic heart disease and is the leading cause of mortality in the world. Although progress has been made in understanding the endogenous regenerative potential of cardiomyocytes, the function of extracellular milieu in cardiac repair has yet to be unraveled. We will dissect the Nkx2.5 transcriptional pathway to uncover novel matrix proteins in zebrafish and will exploit innate pro-regenerative mechanisms to augment cell-based transplantation therapies for patients suffering from coronary artery disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Drug abuse is an enormous public health challenge; human genetics studies have identified a significant genetic contribution to the risk of developing drug abuse. Rodent genetic studies are vital to understanding the molecular genetic basis of drug abuse, but are hampered by an incomplete catalogue of potentially causative genetic variants. In this project, we will examine two important but understudied sources of genetic variation: structural variants and tandem repeats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: The proteins known as KV7.1, KCNE1 and NaVβ1 are found in different types of cells, including those in the heart and neurons in the brain. We have recently discovered that NaVβ1 exerts an inhibitory effect on the activity of KV7.1 counterbalancing the well-known positive modulatory effect of KCNE1. This study will investigate how alteration in the balance of the actions of KCNE1 and NaVβ1 can lead to faulty KV7.1 activity potentially causing in encephalopathies and cardiac arrhythmias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE The opioid crisis (e.g., overdose deaths) has worsened significantly during the COVID-19 pandemic, despite a decrease in the number of prescriptions for opioids and relaxation of prescribing practices for medication assisted treatment (e.g., buprenorphine). However, the number of prescriptions for (and the off-label use of) gabapentinoids (pregabalin [Lyrica®] and gabapentin [Neurontin®]) is soaring with gabapentinoids increasingly detected in drug overdose victims, raising serious concerns about the health risks of this class of drugs. By characterizing the contribution of gabapentinoids to the abuse-related and toxic effects of opioids, these studies will help guide regulatory agencies and practitioners confront this unexplored and underappreciated misuse of FDA-approved medications that is contributing to the opioid crisis. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Deep within the human brain lies a reservoir of stem cells capable of generating new neurons throughout life. We will build a molecular map of all cell types within this reservoir, which will allow us to understand how increased presence of immune cells in schizophrenia support or hinder the development of new neurons. This work will bring us closer to unlocking the potential of these stem cells to treat both psychiatric and neurological brain diseases in the future. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Despite the absence of supporting evidence, treatment guidelines and prescription drug insurance formularies typically assume that individual drugs within medication classes are equally effective and equally safe. Yet, when incorrect, these assumptions expose patients to suboptimal treatments and clinical harms, particularly older adults, who are disproportionately affected by chronic conditions and take more prescription medications than any other population. Taking advantage of natural experiments created by the design of the Medicare prescription drug benefit, the proposed study will use existing data on more than 22 million Medicare beneficiaries to answer key questions about the comparative benefits and harms among drugs within each of four therapeutic classes widely-used among older adults.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parents and caregivers of children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) have reported that repetitive behaviors (e.g., lining up cars) and unusual interests (e.g., child’s fascination with ceiling fans) are among the most challenging aspects of their child’s behavior they have to deal with on a day-to-day basis. Existing early behavioral interventions for children with ASD have been found to be helpful, but they primarily focus on social- communication symptoms and can neglect the consequences of repetitive behaviors on the daily activities of children and families. The overall goal of this project is to determine whether a new form of family-based treatment for repetitive behaviors, delivered using videoconferencing technology, can counter any negative effects of repetitive behavior, but also improve positive outcomes for young children with ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: Project Narrative: The search for novel strategies to promote both healthspan and lifespan, and identification of validated and effective biomarkers for aging research, are important efforts in geroscience research. As a saliva-enriched novel secretory protein, J18 has the potential to be a biomarker for the aging process. In addition, increasing J18 levels may be a novel strategy to promote both healthspan and lifespan. A new aging biomarker and a novel strategy to promote both healthspan and lifespan will be beneficial in many aspects of geroscience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As we age, accurate pain assessment becomes even more important due to more chronic painful medical conditions and changes in how we experience pain. For autistic adults, communicating about pain may be difficult and result in barriers to adequate pain management and medical care. This project aims to understand how pain may differ for autistic adults to reduce suffering and minimize the effects of mismanaged pain on their lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Program Narrative To develop a cadre of talented physician and non-physician investigators devoted to the study of skin biology and skin diseases, we propose a novel training program with a customized curriculum of basic, translational and clinical experiences, individually tailored to each trainee and focused on a specialized skin disease or process; specifically, each curriculum will comprise 1) laboratory-based research, guided by a mentor and committee with diverse strengths and expertise; 2) didactic translational aspects for that research project; and 3) for physician trainees, focused clinical involvement relevant to the disease or process targeted by the research project. In addition to providing our trainees with rigorous scientific instruction in the specific area of their choosing, we shall mentor and guide them to ensure a successful transition to productive academic careers, preparing them for independent dermatology-oriented biomedical research. We propose to engage two trainees trained as physicians or non-physicians into a two-year postdoctoral training program, with a third optional year, for which we have assembled a stellar team of mentors in broad areas relevant to dermatology, and an innovative guidance program to unite the lab-bench, translational and clinical aspects of the training.
PROJECT_TERMS: Biology;Cutaneous;skin disorder;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Cutaneous Biology and Skin Disease Training Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Molecular Metabolism Training Program (MMTP) at the University of Chicago will train the next generation of researchers specializing in metabolism, who by advancing their scientific skills, knowledge, teaching abilities, innovative ideas and biomedical entrepreneurship will develop new translational approaches for the understanding, prevention, treatment and even cures for metabolic disease. The MMTP is an integrative program that spans departments and includes faculty trainers from throughout the Biological Sciences Division with an active research interest in the study of metabolic diseases and mentoring of pre-doctoral students. Considering the current and ever-increasing worldwide diabetes and obesity epidemics, the MMTP will clearly contribute to public health by supporting the training of highly and broadly skilled junior researchers who will join the national biomedical research workforce to combat metabolic diseases in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Monitoring the progression of multiple sclerosis (MS) has been challenging due to the inconsistency and variability of both clinical and magnetic resonance imaging assessments. This project will develop methods and software for analysis of both optical coherence tomography (OCT) and OCT angiography (OCTA) scans of the retina, both of which show correlation to disability in MS. At the conclusion of the grant, software implementing the methods will be made available to the research community in a highly portable computer language.

PHR: Project Narrative Sub-Saharan Africa is home to 90% of the 300,000 children born worldwide with Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) annually and SCD in Sickle Cell Anemia SSA is associated with 16% of childhood mortality . The proposed program will seek to enhance the SCD associated NCD human resource for research capacity in Uganda. It is anticipated that by the end of the 5-years support, a critical mass of local research scientists will have been created to support the further growth of a high quality SCD associated NCDs research and clinical care portfolio, focused on low-cost sustainable interventions for SCD affected populations. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Maintaining proper ion transport is a vital function of the airway epithelium, as it is a necessity for proper moistening and protection of the airways through airway surface liquid and mucociliary clearance. Dysregulated ion transport and impaired mucociliary clearance underlie cystic fibrosis and, to some extent, COPD and asthma. We will define the contribution of different unique rare airway epithelial cell types to overall ion transport of the epithelium, examine alterations in their function during modeling of disease states, and clarify the potential of targeting ion transport in specific cells for the treatment of airway diseases.

PHR: Narrative This project will develop new tools to assess contributions of the LINE-1 (L1) retrotransposon to somatic mosaicism in normal human tissues. Advances here will allow investigators to characterize L1 insertions genome-wide using state-of-the-art long-read and single cell technologies. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abnormal fetal growth affects ~15% of all babies and increases the risk for injuries at delivery and to develop obesity, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease in childhood and later in life. Unfortunately, the understanding of the causes of these conditions is limited and no effective treatments are available. We will develop novel experimental models to determine the role of changes in placental transport of amino acids in regulating placental function and determining fetal growth, which will help us better understand the causes of abnormal fetal growth and may lead to novel treatments for these pregnancy complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT SUMMARY/ABSTRACT Malaria continues to kill more than 400,000 people yearly. Recently a group of viruses, the Matryoshka RNA viruses (MaRNAV), has been identified that is associated with the human pathogen Plasmodium vivax, and also the distantly related avian pathogen Leucocytozoon. Thus, it is clear that these viruses are ancient in their origin, but nearly nothing is known about their affects on malaria- infected hosts. We will test the hypothesis that the Matryoshka RNA viruses have a deep evolutionary history, and can affect the pathogenicity of malaria parasites. Using a bioinformatics approach, we will compare the transcriptomes of avian malaria pathogens and identify the prevalence and diversity of these viruses. We will also seek to understand how malaria infections affect specific components of the avian immune response. The proposed research is timely and significant in that it will advance the field of malaria research by providing important information about the evolution of the immune response to this common parasite. This work is innovative because birds provide the only model system where the MaRNAV viruses can be easily studied in natural populations infected by a diverse group of haemosporidian parasites. The long-term and cross-disciplinary goal of this research agenda is to elucidate the evolution of malaria pathogenicity and identify conserved viruses and immune responses that may be overlooked using mammalian model systems. The aims of the proposal are to: 1. Sequence the complete transcriptomes of select birds to determine the prevalence and diversity of malaria-associated viruses. 2. Characterize differences in immune responses between malaria- infected and non-infected avian hosts. 3. Determine whether malaria-associated viruses alter the host immune response to parasite infection. The project will support the education of future scientists through an integrative approach to research and education. It will train students in cutting edge technologies associated with infectious disease research, and provide valuable experiences for graduate and undergraduate students at an urban university serving large numbers of students traditionally underrepresented in the sciences. The developmental objectives of the PI will be met by working with outstanding collaborators, which will further his training in the molecular genetics of malaria.

PHR: Drug-Excipient nanoparticles have unprecedented drug loading and are rapidly synthesized and designed using machine learning but cannot yet be functionalized to enable active targeting. Here, we will invent computational and experimental protocols to design and characterize novel Antibody-Drug- Excipient nanoparticles with designer tissue targeting in vivo. The developed platform will enable the efficient creation of highly loaded nanoparticles for various indications and tissues and serve as a blueprint for future research and development into machine learning-assisted drug delivery and biomaterial design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The persistent activation of the androgen receptor signaling pathway has been observed in primary prostate cancer (PCa) as well as aggressive prostate cancer including castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC) or drug-resistant prostate cancer. Methylation of adenosine at nitrogen-6 position (m6A) on RNA molecules have been implicated to the pathogenesis of PCa through abnormal alteration of m6A levels deposited by METTL3, which is m6A methyltransferase. Our proposed studies aim to understand how the m6A modification and nuclear m6A reader YTHFC1 mediate the transcriptional activation of androgen receptor (AR), which is critical to the pathogenesis of PCa, and how the persistent activation of AR signaling in castration- or drug-resistant prostate cancer is associated with biomolecular condensation. This study will evaluate and propose the clinical potential of pharmacological inhibition on m6A deposition in the PCa pathogenesis-associated transcriptional regulation through AR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With the COVD-19 pandemic, we are keenly aware of the impact of airway inflammation, which is mediated by pro-inflammatory cytokines such as TNFα. Inflammation is a key aspect of airways diseases such as asthma that affect more than 20 million people in the USA and 300 million people worldwide. The proposed studies will focus on human airway smooth muscle (hASM) and the effects of pro-inflammatory cytokines in inducing stress on the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). In hASM cells, we will explore the involvement of TNFα in selectively activating an ER stress signaling cascade, and how this affects the downstream expression of proteins that regulate mitochondrial structure and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Cancers consist of a mixture of cell types that together promote tumor growth and disease progression; nerves are a newly recognized component of cancers. In this application, we show that intra-tumoral nerves are transcriptionally and functionally different from normal nerves, that disease-associated oncogenes influence these differences and will identify how these differences contribute to cancer pain. In addition, we will define whether drugs that block pain also inhibit tumor growth and improve survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The molecular mechanisms underlying mammalian tissue aging remains largely unknown. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE- Cambridge Health Alliance ALACRITY for Early Screening and Treatment of High Risk Youth (eSToRY)  Barriers to quality mental health care for youth at risk of mental illness are well recognized but persistent, especially among racial, ethnic, and language (REL)-minority youth. The proposed Center for Early Screening and Treatment of at-Risk Youth (the eSToRY Center) is dedicated to research and training to improve early detection of mental illness, to prevent adverse outcomes, to improve quality of care, and to foster equity in treatment for REL-minority youth. We leverage a sophisticated health data infrastructure and an interdisciplinary team of experts to adapt, test, and implement evidence-based practices to accelerate mental health care improvements for REL-minority youth populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Myelination has recently been identified as a common pathological hallmark of numerous neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative diseases that present with cognitive symptoms, but how myelin impacts neuronal circuits to influence cognition and behavior remains an open question. This proposal will use novel mouse genetic tools to investigate how myelination influences neuronal circuit function and plasticity in the mammalian cortex. These studies will advance our understanding of circuit modulation by myelination and lay the groundwork for identifying, and eventually developing ways to rectify, the consequences of myelin dysfunction in neurological disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To address increasing skin cancer rates in the US, particularly among young people, we propose to use the Multiphase Optimization Strategy (MOST) to evaluate individual and combined effects of action planning, personalized ultraviolet (UV) photographs, and MC1R genetic testing on preventing sunburn, motivating sun protection, and discouraging tanning in young adults. This project addresses the critical need for efficacious skin cancer preventive interventions for young adults in the college setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evidence suggests banning menthol flavor in cigarettes would have a positive benefit on public health. However, it is currently unknown how such a ban might be impacted by the availability of menthol flavor in e- cigarettes, an alternative tobacco product that people might switch to from cigarettes. The current project will study the impact of menthol flavor bans in cigarettes and e-cigarettes to inform tobacco policy to protect public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Blockade of CD154 is a highly effective method of inducing transplantation tolerance (a state in which transplant recipients would no longer require toxic immunosuppression), however clinical translation of CD154 blockers has met with many challenges, and as an alternative reagents that block CD40 (the receptor for CD154) are now in the clinical pipeline. However, CD40 blockers are not as effective as CD154 blockers, and here we have identified a novel molecular interaction that explains this discrepancy. Mechanistic understanding of this new molecular interaction is of the utmost importance in order to devise innovative strategies to block these residual interactions and thus optimize the use of CD40 blockers in the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Chromatin-bound regulators are aberrantly activated in cancer cells to promote transcriptional programs important for driving tumor initiation and progression. However, despite identification of oncogenic regulators in multiple tumor types, a gap in this rapidly evolving field is the definition of how those regulators mechanistically operate, which is required to identify interaction surfaces that can be used to target them in cancer. In both the F99 and K00 phases of this award, I will elucidate the underlying molecular mechanisms by which chromatin- bound regulators sustain oncogenic transcriptional programs, and define critical surfaces required for hallmarks of cancer, thereby allowing me to devise novel therapeutic vulnerabilities in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Engineered T cells programmed to recognize and kill tumors have emerged as an extraordinarily powerful tool for combating cancer. Nonetheless, aside from chimeric antigen receptor T cells for the treatment of blood cancers, most engineered cell therapies are often ineffective and potentially highly toxic, particularly those that target solid tumors. This research proposal develops synthetic biology tools to combat three major challenges of engineered T cells: tumor recognition, toxicity and the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lymph nodes are a primary site for immune activation against malignancy, but are also a frequent site of metastasis, the leading cause of cancer related death. During cancer progression the extracellular matrix (ECM) scaffold that organizes immune cell response in the lymph node is altered, and ECM alterations such as lymph node fibrosis are associated with worse prognosis. This study focuses on investigating αvβ3 integrin as a target to reverse ECM remodeling in the lymph node during the F99 phase and whether targeting similar pathways enhance the effectiveness of immunotherapy during the K00 phase.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of youth use e-cigarettes spurred in part by pervasive marketing in brick-and-mortar retail stores. To prevent youth uptake of e-cigarettes and health risks, the proposed project will ask adolescents and young adults to identify appealing and influential characteristics of e- cigarette marketing in the retail environment and address these influences in a counter- marketing lesson. Study findings will also inform e-cigarette-retail-marketing related regulations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Respiratory infections of all types represent a worldwide public health crisis, and many of these microorganisms have potential to cause disruptive pandemics with significant morbidity and mortality. The goal of the Biology of Acute Respiratory Infection Gordon Research Conference (BARI-GRC) and seminar (BARI-GRS) is to assemble a multidisciplinary group of researchers committed to understanding the molecular mechanisms that determine pathogenesis of respiratory microorganisms and host susceptibility. The BARI-GRC and GRS will bring together individuals with a wide range of expertise (including microbiologists, immunologists, infectious disease experts and pulmonary medicine experts) from government, industry and academia who would not normally attend the same conferences, providing unparalleled opportunities to share innovative research and foster cross- disciplinary collaborations and mentorship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nicotine/tobacco dependence is a major health concern, and mechanistic neurobiological research into addiction mechanisms may lead to novel approaches to tobacco cessation. The goal of this project is to leverage our well- qualified research team, our innovative tools, and our incisive methods to produce newer/better tools for studying nicotinic acetylcholine receptor activity in the context of nicotine dependence. We will then validate and leverage these tools to investigate novel aspects of nicotine dependence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Metabolic dysregulation is a known hallmark of cancer progression which promotes the survival and growth of aggressive metastatic cancer. However, how oncogenic signals communicate with mitochondrial enzymes to rewire metabolic pathways and stimulate expression of proliferative genes remains unclear. In this proposal we will investigate that a direct communication between mitochondria and nucleus is vital to reprogram the onco- metabolic pathways promoting adaptation and growth of aggressive metastatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 3 lymphocytes—including group 3 innate lymphoid cells (ILC3), IL-17-producing γδ T cells (Tγδ17), and T helper 17 ( TH17) cells—are crucial for a range of functions from mucosal barrier defenses against extracellular pathogens to secondary lymphoid organ formation. Their dysregulated function has also been implicated in various autoimmune diseases, such as multiple sclerosis and Crohn's disease. The proposed study will further our understanding of the regulatory mechanisms governing the development and differentiation of type 3 lymphocytes.

Current treatments cause toxicity and do not effectively penetrate and accumulate in the tumor due to dense, fibrous stroma tissue. Duo Oncology is developing DUO-207, an ultrasmall nanomedicine, that can penetrate and accumulate in dense pancreatic tumors, co-delivering gemcitabine and paclitaxel directly to the tumor to improve treatment outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wolbachia pipientis is a bacterium that infects insect hosts, where it inhibits virus replication. Our proposed studies aim to identify exactly how Wolbachia manipulates the host to establish an infection. Discoveries made as part of this work will be directly applicable to the use of Wolbachia to control disease vectors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The liver mitochondria function as a vital source of gluconeogenic precursors under a fasted state. We recently identified a liver-specific mitochondrial carrier, SLC25A47, that plays a crucial role in the process. Building upon the discovery, this proposal aims to understand the underlying mechanisms of SLC25A47 action in the regulation of energy expenditure and glucose homeostasis. Successful completion of this study will offer a liver-specific target through which we can restrict hepatic gluconeogenesis, which is often in excess under hyperglycemic and diabetic conditions, while elevating energy expenditure. Importantly, this work will establish a framework to understand the principle of tissue-specific mitochondrial metabolite transport in physiology and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hearing loss affects an estimated 48 million Americans. This project aims to spread information about hearing loss research by supporting the convening of a high quality, communication-accessible Research Symposium at each Hearing Loss of Association of American (HLAA) annual convention and disseminating professionally edited videos of the symposia to the wider community of people with hearing loss and their families, and the general public. This will allow a wide audience will be able to be engaged in the science underlying this key public health issue.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: VA is transforming to Whole Health (WH), health care that is “personalized, proactive, and patient-driven.” Social and cultural factors such as Veteran identity and culture (VIC) and racial identity and culture (RIC) influence patient and provider behaviors, concepts of health, and approaches to power sharing and decision making. This can create partnerships or conflicts and influence WH care. In this study researchers from Howard University (HU), a Minority Serving Institution (MSI), and VA will use narrative inquiry methods to interview 15 Black and 15 White Veterans who participated in a WH education and activation intervention. The interviews will (1) explore perceived barriers and facilitators to Veterans' participation in WH related to their VIC and RIC; (2) understand similarities and distinctions in barriers and facilitators among Black and White Veterans; (3) identify VIC- and RIC-informed guidance about what promotes or prevents participation in WH. This project will also promote partnerships between VA and HU scientists to enhance diversity in VA research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Even after the COVID-19 pandemic, influenza continues to have a significant impact on public heath affecting over 35 million people, causing 710,000 hospitalizations and about 47,000 deaths per year in the United States. The strongest public health response to influenza remains the annual vaccine, the effectiveness of which is calculated each year by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), and while these vaccine effectiveness (VE) estimates are the US gold standard, they have limitations due to the inclusion of only a limited number of regions and subjects, as well as the interim report not being published until late into the flu season. We propose the use of longitudinal social media (SM) data and state of the art Natural Language Processing techniques to develop and evaluate a near real-time VE estimation system that accounts for biases, uncertainty, and missing data in vaccination status or influenza diagnosis which, if successful, will be the first automated approach to near real-time estimation of vaccine effectiveness in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The regulation of hematopoietic stem cells (HSC) during bone marrow regeneration are poorly understood. The functional decline of HSC after bone marrow transplantation is thought to be a degenerative process caused by accumulated damage that leads to cellular dysfunction, tissue failure, and death. Evidence has now proven that there is a measurable changes in HSC metabolism after bone marrow transplantation that drive HSC functional decline. The studies proposed in this application will provide information on cellular factors that become deregulated in hematopoietic stem cells after bone marrow transplantation and cause functional decline of the hematopoietic tissue, and will identify conditions under which HSC can be maintained with full regenerative potential. This could be a first step towards designing treatments to improve HSC function during bone marrow regeneration to improve bone marrow transplant outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will make silicone wristband chemical samplers available in the consumer market and increase the impact of personalized exposure data. The project will lower costs and allow users of silicone wristbands (SWBs) to distinguish chemical sources from the air and skin and facilitate comparisons of SWB data to regulatory exposure limits or other studies. Project results will expand the use of SWBs to motivated consumers, researchers, and risk assessors that can use these data and subsequent personalized chemical reports to reduce or eliminate sources of unwanted exposure.

PHR: Project Narrative Our program is called Promoting Embedded Research in a Learning Health System (PERLHS). We will engage three distinct populations of scholars: learners embedded within the precision-medicine initiative of Johns Hopkins University, learners embedded within the operational entities of the Johns Hopkins Health System, and learners embedded in entities working to advance population health for Maryland residents.

PHR: Narrative The overall goal of this project is to develop PanKbase, a centralized and comprehensive resource of the human pancreas for the diabetes research community, with a focus on type 1 diabetes (T1D) pathogenesis. The project will also foster cross-disciplinary collaborations and promote innovation, with the ultimate aim of improving the lives of people with T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Master transcriptional regulators are critical for the proper function and maintenance of human stem cells. During blood cell production, dysregulation of the transcription factor MECOM can greatly disrupt normal differentiation of hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells and is thus implicated in aggressive forms of blood cancer. Here, I will use biochemical and genomic approaches to define the direct transcriptional targets of MECOM in acute myeloid leukemia and functionally dissect mechanisms by which MECOM exerts control over this gene regulatory network to ultimately elucidate novel therapeutic targets for the treatment of high-risk leukemias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Residual tumor cells that survive oncogene targeted therapies pose a challenge to achieving durable responses since these cells often serve as the reservoir for tumor relapse and progression. We recently found that residual cells evade immune recognition by targeting macrophages of the immune system. In this proposal, we propose a series of mechanism-based approaches to uncover potential targets to engineer the immune-mediated clearance of residual tumor cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Corneal scarring is a major cause of blindness in the world today but its epidemiology is proven to be very complicated and dependent on a variety of factors, including trauma, infections, and inflammation. Currently, and for the last four decades, the only available treatment for corneal scarring is corneal transplantation; however, this therapy has significant side effects and concerns. We propose to determine whether flavonoids, and novel synthetic flavonoids (sFNs) can be developed and utilized as therapeutic agents to mitigate or reverse corneal scarring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Ultrasound technology, which may be the most cost-effective device for the improvement of global health, today requires the operator to see the currently scanned images, guiding acquisition by anatomy mastered by rigorous training. The proposed technology develops low- cost hardware, requires no anatomic training, instead guiding even a lay operator with more easily learned graphical clues, till data acquisition is complete and can be passed to an examining physician in a format familiar to her from other radiological images. This system allows efficient resource management of skilled ultrasonography consultants, who are in short supply not only in rural and battlefield environments, but also in emergency and operating room medicine, and can dramatically increase access to life-saving U/S diagnostics both here in the U.S. and in the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Malaria is caused by a parasite with a complex lifecycle, including a blood stage in which the parasite binds and enters red blood cells: A mosquito acquires malaria from the blood during feeding and transmits the parasite on biting its next victim. Transmission-blocking vaccines induce antibodies that will block parasite passage through the mosquito; both transmission-blocking and blood-stage vaccine antigens have been identified, but, to date, they have only been produced in expensive eukaryotic systems. We propose to produce these antigens as genetic fusions in our engineered E. coli strain, which can make soluble, complex proteins in the cytoplasm at high levels, allowing us to manufacture a low-cost malaria vaccine targeting multiple elements of the malaria parasite lifecycle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The Phase I SBIR objective is to design, develop, & demonstrate feasibility of BioBricks-Env, an artificial intelligence (AI) driven, open-source, modular, composable platform to organize, store, retrieve, extract, and integrate environmental health & risk related data. Data loading is a universal barrier to building data sources, models, and informatics tools that leverage existing sources, as this phase of research is tedious, error prone, costly, and difficult to scale across projects. Therefore, new AI technologies that can rapidly scale and reduce redundancies for storing, retrieving, extracting, and integrating data related to chemical exposure, environmental health, and human health risks could transform the market landscape.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Fear of cancer recurrence (FCR) is arguably the single most commonly shared adverse psychosocial effect of cancer and its treatment across all cancer populations, yet there have been remarkably few systematic, longitudinal investigations of FCR and its health consequences. A long-term objective of the proposed work is to influence the development and refinement of interventions for FCR and health behaviors (i.e., physical activity/sedentary behavior, medication adherence, and sleep), ultimately improving mental and physical well- being of cancer survivors and their spouses/partners. The focus of this proposal echoes the recent Cancer MoonshotSM Blue Ribbon Panel report (Recommendation F: Symptom Management Research) that future research improve symptom monitoring and management with the long-term goal of supporting completion of cancer treatment and reducing cancer recurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Metabolic reprogramming in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is well recognized to support cancer cell growth and proliferation, as well as to resist targeted therapy. The Shaw lab recently demonstrated that key metabolic regulator AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) is required for NSCLC tumor growth. While studies have shown AMPK signaling provides cancer cells with flexibility to adapt to metabolic stresses, this proposed study will examine epigenetic mechanisms by which AMPK promotes metabolic reprogramming and lung tumor growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Nearly one-half of people living with HIV (PLWH) today have left ventricular diastolic dysfunction (DD), which is associated with the progression to heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) but the causes of DD and its progression in PLWH are poorly understood. Our preliminary studies suggest that impaired cardiac energy metabolism may be a critical factor for DD in PLWH and thus we propose to examine, in cross -sectional and longitudinal studies, cardiac metabolism in PLWH using sophisticated non-invasive 31P MRI/MRS technologies, reasons for impairment including cardiac lipid accumulation, systemic inflammation, and insulin resistance, and its relationship with echocardiographic and other indices of DD and cardiovascular performance. The results will provide novel insights into the pathophysiology of DD in PLWH and inform the selection of preventive and therapeutic interventions to decrease the burden and consequences of DD in PLWH. `

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic hematological cancer (CHC) patients are characterized by long term and high symptom burden, including up to 65% reporting chronic sleep disturbances that are also often associated with inflammation, fatigue, and emotional distress (anxiety and depression). Meditation is an effective non-pharmacologic strategy to self-manage and improve cancer-related symptoms and mediation delivered via mobile applications may address cancer patients’ barriers to in-person interventions (i.e., fatigue, pain, transportation, scheduling difficulties) without the time and expertise limitations of cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) and side effect risks from medication. This study is the first to test a commercially available, smartphone-based meditation application to self-manage sleep disturbance, inflammation fatigue, and emotional distress (anxiety, depression), among CHC patients and to explore the sustained effects of meditation compared to a health education podcast control group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Fanconi anemia is the most common inherited cause of low blood counts and 90% of patients will be affected by the age of 40. While deficient repair of DNA damage is the hallmark of Fanconi anemia, there is no available therapy that prevents DNA damage from happening. Our study may identify new targets that may be used to prevent DNA damage and low blood counts in patients with Fanconi anemia and in the general population.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is tightly aligned with the NIH mission by unveiling new epigenetic mechanisms that account for the embryonic heart development, with a focus on the DNA methylation homeostasis and maternal metabolic influence. Our studies will furnish important insights that are immediately relevant to the precise temporal and spatial epigenetic regulation which contributes to the normal heart development. Our discoveries will significantly promote healthy cardiac development and illuminate previously underappreciated epigenetic mechanisms underpinning congenital cardiovascular diseases and cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Large-scale DNA and RNA sequencing, bioinformatics, and computational approaches have greatly advanced addiction neurobiology. Our studies will be the first to use cell-type-specific RNA sequencing to define the brain transcriptome from human alcoholics and alcohol-dependent mice in unprecedented detail. Our overarching hypothesis is that conserved cell-type-induced transcriptome changes will reveal specific neurobiological mechanisms and improved drug targets for excessive alcohol drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative To support the development of novel anti-cancer therapies, we propose continuation of a multidisciplinary, institution-wide cancer biology T32 postdoctoral training program at City of Hope (Duarte, CA) to prepare exceptionally motivated postdoctoral fellows in the fields of DNA damage response and oncogenic signaling (DNADRS). Because cancer disproportionately impacts minority populations in the US, we have implemented a strategy, which is aided by exceptional institutional support for salaries and research funds, to emphasize attracting and training scientists from underrepresented minority (URM) backgrounds. With our collection of outstanding DNADRS researchers and physician collaborators, state of the art facilities, strong curriculum, emphasis on obtaining extramural funding, superb institutional support, and the last 5 year’s successful experience, we request the continued support to DNADRS T32 program, which will train the next generation of leaders in the fight against cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Positron emission tomography (PET) is the premier imaging modality for diagnosis and/or guiding treatment of diseases such as cancer and neurological disorders through its ability to visualize and quantify the distribution of radionuclide-labeled biological probe molecules. Current PET systems are unable to image multiple tracers in one session, however we hypothesize that visualizing and quantifying multiple biomarkers in the same imaging session will lead to more accurate diagnosis and effective guidance in treatment decisions. This project will enable simultaneous multi-tracer PET through addition of an endcap detector and signal processing techniques to increase detection efficiency, increase quantitative accuracy of measuring the activity of multiple radiotracers in the same imaging session, and reduce the amount of systematic error in the ‘multiplexed PET study’ due to random or misclassified events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Corneal blindness affects more than 12.5 million people, yet less than 2% of patients worldwide have access to the human donor tissue needed for its conventional treatment. To address this major global health need, my work seeks to develop a 3D bioprinting strategy for precise spatial patterning of bioinks composed of collagen and human corneal mesenchymal stromal cells to study and leverage the effects of their microenvironment on their regenerative potential. This interdisciplinary approach will recapitulate the unique structural, optical, and biological features of the human cornea toward the goal of restoring vision on-demand with bioengineered tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Huntington's disease is a fatal neurodegenerative condition caused by a genetic defect that worsens over time as a result of faulty DNA mismatch repair. This proposal seeks to use small RNA drugs to modulate key mediators of mismatch repair in a mouse model of Huntington's disease, and determine the impact on blocking or reversing the gene defect and reducing disease progression. Findings from this study will inform the rational design of therapeutics for Huntington's disease and other neurological disorders associated with faulty mismatch repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative In the United States, one in 44 children is diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), the symptoms of which can sometimes lead to significant disability and stress for affected individuals. Enlargement of the dorsal striatum may contribute to patterns of restrictive, repetitive behavior, a core feature of the condition and the developmental regulation of which is not understood. Cellular and molecular investigations of striatal enlargement will lead to better understanding of the role of striatal abnormalities within neurodevelopmental disorders including ASD, as well as new methods of prevention and therapeutic treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Nicotinamide N-methyltransferase (NNMT), a key enzyme in the NAD+ salvage pathway with unclear functions, is expressed highly and specifically in basal-like breast cancer (BLBC). We propose that NNMT, which is regulated by the FOXC1-CARM1 complex, is a critical gatekeeper to promote tumor progression, metastasis and drug-resistance in BLBC. Our systematic and complementary analyses will lead to a major advance in the understanding of breast cancer biology and the development of novel therapeutic strategies for metastatic BLBC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of this project is to determine if dysfunction of the autonomic nervous system (ANS) is one of the earliest pathological features of Huntington's Disease (HD). To accomplish this goal, I will 1) quantitatively characterize functional and structural changes in brain areas that control the ANS and 2) investigate physiologic measures of ANS dysfunction in children who carry the gene expansion that causes HD. The proposed research aims to explore novel pathological mechanisms that underlie the progression of HD in order to improve therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurovascular coupling (NVC) is a crucial mechanism that translates neural activity into local cerebral blood flow changes. This study aims to investigate whether the endogenous activity of Tacr1 neurons, a unique type of cortical inhibitory neurons that mediate NVC, is regulated by substance P across different brain states. A better understanding of the mechanisms mediating NVC may provide critical knowledge for understanding blood- oxygen-level-dependent (BOLD) signal and for identifying cerebrovascular targets for future therapeutic treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance These investigations focus on uncovering a window of opportunity to provide novel targets and treatment approaches for pancreatic cancer, a painful and deadly disease. Our approach seeks to understand the intersection of normal processes required to duplicate the genome and how they then tolerate rapid division of cancer with the goal of using this knowledge to find targetable vulnerabilities. Thus, the studies in this grant proposal align with NCI’s mission to advance scientific knowledge and help all people live longer, healthier lives with our ultimate goal to advance toward informed and improved therapeutic strategies for pancreatic cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Obesity afflicts millions of American adults and children and is a problem of enormous public health relevance as it exerts a heavy burden on patient suffering and social costs. Its causes remain incompletely understood and, while available treatment and prevention approaches are improving, there is much room for improvement. We will train postdoctoral fellows and position them for independent research careers as they evolve to be our future scientific leaders in obesity, and will provide summer research fellowships to medical students to nurture interests in careers as future physician scientists.
PROJECT_TERMS: Obesity;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: UAB Obesity Training Program
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Diabetes, Endocrinology and Metabolic Diseases B Study Section[DDK-B]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Understanding the highly multifaceted nature of force-based manipulations, particularly for spinal pain, is complicated by the physiologic mechanisms involved, which require the integrative synthesis of fundamental insights from the neuroscience, physics, engineering, physiology, and clinical fields. SPINEWORK is a network of researchers and activities that will be created and evolved to address the need for interdisciplinary research exploring the potential role of force-based manipulations in alleviating spine pain. The network will provide members with the opportunity to identify new collaborators, to learn about other disciplines, to disseminate ideas and information to their colleagues and the larger community, and to foster better interdisciplinary communication.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Texas Developmental Center for AIDS Research (Texas D-CFAR) will facilitate collaborative and multidisciplinary HIV research. The Texas D-CFAR will align with NIH HIV research priorities to foster synergy, promote efficiency, and support coordinated research between its home institutions - Baylor College of Medicine (Houston), University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, and the Texas Biomedical Research Institute (San Antonio). The Texas D-CFAR will build research capacity to achieve its goal: End HIV and Optimizing Health in Texas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The constant assembly and disassembly of actin filament networks creates a treadmilling system at the front of motile cells that must be coordinated with motor forces in the cell rear to drive normal cell motility, cancer cell metastasis and neuronal growth cone advance. New evidence suggests that the actin filament severing protein, cofilin, can be activated by mechanical stress. This project investigates a role for cofilin activation as a result of actin network shear stress buildup during growth cone responses to local chemotropic cues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The studies proposed here will define the anti-tumor effect of a new treatment strategy based on targeted elimination of highly tumorigenic cancer stem-like cells combined with tumor debulking with conventional therapy in preclinical models of resistant salivary gland mucoepidermoid carcinoma. The overall significance of the proposed research lies in its potential to lead to discoveries that will ultimately improve the survival and quality of life of patients with salivary gland cancer. This is critical since current benefits of therapy are modest for these patients, and their survival rate remains unacceptably low.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE In the current study we will establish the mechanistic links between decorin (DCN) expression, diffusion MRI, and anti- VEGF treatment efficacy by first (Aim 1) performing a deep exploration into the association between diffusion MR phenotypes and DCN expression in human GBM using image-guided biopsies and examining DCN protein and gene expression, as well as the relationship with genotypes using whole exome analysis, genetic subtypes using bulk RNA sequencing, cellular states using single-cell RNA sequencing, and blood plasma levels of circulating DCN. Concurrently, we will (Aim 2) establish the causal links between DCN expression, diffusion MRI measurements, and anti-VEGF treatment in GBM by conducting a genetically modified patient-derived orthotopic xenograft (PDX) preclinical trial through editing a series of patient-derived cell lines to silence of overexpress DCN within PDX models using a tetracycline-controlled gene expression system, then perform diffusion MRI and treat with anti-VEGF therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is the most common genetic cardiac disease and causes a variety of cardiovascular events such as arrhythmias, heart failure, stroke, and sudden cardiac death; however, effective pharmacotherapies to prevent disease manifestation or cardiovascular events are not available. In an ongoing, large multi-center cohort of patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, the investigators will define the role of signaling pathway dysregulation in disease pathogenesis and the development of cardiovascular events by performing proteomics profiling in both plasma and myocardium. This research has the potential to identify potential molecular targets for the prevention of disease manifestation and progression, and to offer novel approaches to specify high-risk subpopulations that benefit most from preventive interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic pain is a significant health problem that has led to an epidemic of opioid analgesic overuse and overdose, yet most novel therapeutics have failed to translate to human subjects. To address this problem, it is necessary to fill in a critical gap in knowledge pertaining to how acute pain progresses to chronic pain conditions. We propose that lymphotoxin-beta receptor (LTβR) controls the process of chronic pain development via a conceptually novel peripheral mechanism, providing an effective therapeutic target to prevent the development as well as reverse chronic pain and suffering in multiple pain conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease affects nearly half of all adults in the United States and is responsible for a quarter of all deaths annually, with rates rising. Within the context of three of the largest and richest microbiome profiling studies, this proposal seeks to develop statistical and computational approaches for enabling a more robust and sophisticated understanding of how microbes are related to cardiovascular disease risk factors. This information represents an imperative point of investigation both for possibly improving etiology and for possible development of therapies, particularly as the microbiome is modifiable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE While treatment with aortic valve replacement (AVR) for aortic stenosis (AS) has historically been reserved for symptomatic severe AS, cardiac remodeling and irreversible injury occur before the onset of symptoms and before AS is "severe" and contribute to death and persistent heart failure symptoms/rehospitalization in up to 40% of patients 1 year after AVR, suggesting that AVR before onset of irreversible changes to the heart is likely to improve post-AVR outcomes. We hypothesize that myocardial remodeling and dysfunction early in the course of AS (mild-moderate; asymptomatic severe) will be accompanied by alterations in the circulating proteome pointing to known and novel pathways contributing to heart failure and providing an early molecular barometer for clinical surveillance and pharmacologic targeting. If successful, the current application will identify a set of circulating proteins linked to early cardiac remodeling phenotypes in AS for potential mechanistic study, pharmacologic targeting, clinical surveillance, and personalized treatment decisions.

PHR: Project Narrative (relevance of this research to public health): The studies of this application will investigate the mechanism by which components of the natural anticoagulant pathways, thrombin-thrombomodulin and protein C-EPCR complexes, initiate cytoprotective signaling responses to regulate and maintain the integrity of blood vessels. The mis-regulation of these signaling systems can impair vascular function and lead to debilitating thrombotic and inflammatory disorders including heart attack, stroke, and severe sepsis. A better understanding of signaling mechanisms that modulate vascular functions as outlined in this application is essential for discovering new drugs potentially useful for treating ever-increasing inflammatory and thrombotic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Excessive alcohol use and alcohol use disorders have an enormous impact on public health, with annual costs in the U.S. estimated to be $249 billion, and the social costs ranging from family disruption to criminal justice are also immense. Alcohol use disorders reflect the interplay of neurobiology, genetics, psychology, and socio-cultural factors. This underscores the critical need for inter-disciplinary research to understand, develop, and test science-based approaches and the necessity of inter-disciplinary training for alcohol researchers in order to develop appropriate interdisciplinary approaches to reducing the harms from alcohol.
PROJECT_TERMS: Alcohols;Etiology;Research Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Research Training on Alcohol Etiology and Treatment

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Therapeutic outcomes following the natural killer (NK) cell-based immunotherapy for hepatocellular carcinoma may be limited if an insufficient number and activity of NK cells reach the targeted tumors. We seek to develop a new image-guided combination liver cancer immunotherapy approach including a) image-guided transcatheter IHA infusion of NKs directly into the blood supply of targeted liver tumor(s) and b) concurrent infusion of nano-size sorafenib-eluting microsphere (nano-SEMs) not only to enhance sorafenib therapeutic efficacy (to avoid severe side effects) but also to strengthen NK antitumor activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This SEPA project has the potential to increase the diversity of the STEM/health workforce by increasing interest and motivation among high performing students who lack access to opportunities to cultivate their talent. This project will create Hexacago Health Academy 2.0 Game On (HHA 2.0 GO), a theory-based, game-based STEM/health pathway program and The UChicago STEM/Health Pathway Program (UC-SPP), a traditional pathway program. The study will recruit rising 11th graders. The study hypothesis is that High-performing students randomized to HHA 2.0 GO will score higher on a composite measure of self-efficacy, outcome expectations, knowledge, interests, goals, and behaviors regarding STEM/health topics, STEM/health careers, and the college admissions process short term and longitudinally compared to those randomized to UC-SPP or a non- intervention control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  While alcohol use disorder is characterized by compulsive drinking and inflexible behavior, which is likely to involve the brain areas of the thalamus and striatum, little is known about how excessive alcohol intake alters connectivity between these regions, or how such alterations affect behavioral flexibility in alcoholism. The studies in this proposal seek to elucidate the mechanisms involved in thalamic input-mediated changes in striatal cholinergic activity, and investigate how this impacts on reversal learning in flexible behavior. The results obtained will provide important insights into the promotion of behavioral flexibility, and potentially identify new therapeutic strategies to reduce excessive alcohol consumption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The “Cardiovasology” Training Program at Mayo Clinic is an avenue for advanced training of the specialized workforce of physicians/scientists focused on heart health and disease. This proposal expands Program faculty and scope, deepens and broadens its scientific expertise, fosters diversity of mentors and trainees, and integrates new training in emerging technologies and innovations. This Program builds on a four-decades long history of excellence in attracting, mentoring and retaining talented individuals that will form the next generation of science leaders and scholars in this country.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The purpose of this grant is to develop a method for acquiring a set of MR images in one orientation with modest slice-to-slice overlap and for reconstructing the data to allow improved visualization within the acquired slices. This will allow high quality spatial resolution in all three directions. We will evaluate the method in men suspected of or known to have prostate cancer, and we expect it to provide improved image quality and reduced overall examination time compared to the current practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy is a dose-limiting toxicity of many drugs used in cancer treatment and can adversely affect patient quality of life for years after therapy. The studies proposed in this application will examine the significance of sphingolipid signaling in this neurotoxicity. A detailed understanding of the mechanisms for chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy will support strategies for its prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The sense for touch is essential for navigation in the environment, manipulation of tools and objects, foraging, detection of physical pain, development of social behaviors. Despite its fundamental importance for physiology, many molecular and physiological aspects of the sense of touch are poorly understood. The goal of this proposal is to unravel the mechanism of touch detection by the specialized end-organs in the skin of vertebrate called Meissner corpuscles. Results from this study will provide general scientific knowledge which will contribute to the development of pharmacological tools to alleviate somatosensory disorders associated with hypersensitivity to touch in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Our proposal focuses on building advanced animal models of lung and pancreas cancer so that researchers can use these models to make and test new immunotherapies for patients. There are currently no models to test these drugs, so they fail in clinical trials. Our models could help doctors know their therapy will work in patients before the trials, making trials more effective and saving the lives of cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative: Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a major public health concern worldwide. The whole-genome, as well as mechanistic, approaches to investigate epigenetic and molecular changes in key brain regions underlying behavioral phenotypes of AUD will lead to the identification of novel mechanisms that mediate this disease. The new epigenetic targets can be used to develop drugs for the treatment and prevention of AUD. !
