IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Infectious diseases remain the second leading cause of death worldwide, and the rapid rise of antibiotic-resistant bacteria, combined with the emergence of viral diseases, threatens to markedly increase the public health impact of these illnesses. To combat this threat requires new drugs with novel mechanisms of action, a goal that can be achieved by the application of chemical biology to the study of microbiology. This proposal will combine the resources of the Vanderbilt Institute of Chemical Biology (VICB) and the Vanderbilt Institute for Infection, Immunology, and Inflammation (VI4) to train young scientists who will be able to bridge the gap between these disciplines, preparing them to discover the next generation of infectious disease therapeutics.
PROJECT_TERMS: Biology;Chemicals;Communicable Diseases;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Chemical Biology of Infectious Diseases (CBID) Training Program
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Microbiology and Infectious Diseases B Research Study Section[MID-B]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This goal of this proposal is to determine how metabolically heterogeneous lung cancer cell sub-populations cooperate to drive invasion and metastasis. We will elucidate the molecular basis and mechanistic underpinnings of how differential metabolism maintains the distinct but cooperative biology that drives collective invasion and conceptually test if co-targeting different metabolic sub-populations limits metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Program Director (Last, first, middle): Kleinfeld, David Narrative  We propose to disseminate a direct wavefront sensing adaptive optics system for multi-photon microscopy that will enables investigators to probe subcellular dynamics in individual synapses along the full depth of cortex. This is a crucial advance, particularly as layer 5 and 6 cortical output neurons lie deep to the surface so that essentially all current cortical imaging studies are performed on intermediate layer neurons in layers 2/3. Our approach will open up a new subfield of in vivo studies on subcellular determinates of cortical output, as well as in vivo studies on the transformation of layer 4 inputs to layer 5 and 6 outputs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cell polyploidy is emerging as an inducible and variable feature of tissues, where it is linked to disease physiology across a range of tissue types and organisms. Due to the complex 3-D organization of the lung, alveolar epithelial polyploidy has been unrecognized and its contribution to alveolar homeostasis and repair is unknown. The proposed experiments will address this knowledge gap and provide a mechanistic understanding of alveolar epithelial polyploidy and its contribution to lung fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project describes a new extracellular entity, the pathogen exosome. In diseases such as COPD this type of exosome drives chronic inflammation, tissue damage, and cell death. A complete understanding of the pathogenic exosome may lead to new diagnostics and therapeutics for chronic inflammatory diseases such as COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Our recent pilot studies of neoadjuvant immunotherapy in resectable hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) showed unprecedented pathologic complete responses associated with changes in specific clusters of immune cells, justifying larger trials to test this innovative use of immunotherapy in HCC. The goal of our project is to evaluate the feasibility of this approach and the ability of an established immunotherapy-based regimen for advanced HCC to induce high pathologic response rates when used prior to surgery. We will also examine novel tumor tissue, plasma, and imaging biomarkers that correlate with response to this preoperative therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are no biomarker-selected, molecular targeted therapies for human papillomavirus (HPV) positive cancers. Aurora kinase inhibitors lead to cell death preferentially in HPV+ cancers and this death may sensitize HPV+ cancers to immunotherapy. To meet our long-term goal of improving cure rates for those with HPV+ cancer, we propose to test the hypothesis that Aurora kinase inhibition leads to cell death in HPV+ cancers due to Rb loss-induced genomic instability, to test the hypothesis that Aurora kinase inhibition will result in increased sensitivity to immune checkpoint therapy, and to identify biomarkers predicting response to the combination of immune checkpoint and Aurora kinase inhibition in patients with recurrent HPV+ cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Young adult cancer patients experience more distress and greater impairment in health-related quality of life compared with older patients, but current psychosocial care does not address their unique needs. The proposed randomized trial will evaluate a novel problem-solving skills training intervention designed to enhance patient problem-solving ability, reduce distress, and improve health-related quality of life. Results will advance clinical practice to reduce the cancer burden among this vulnerable group. ! !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascular diseases such as coronary heart disease represent a pressing unmet medical need. One approach to identify new drug targets is to study DNA variants that influence risk for disease, but identifying the functions of these variants has been challenging. We will map the 3D structure of the human genome in blood vessels to identify new therapeutic targets for common vascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Though large racial disparities have been described in clinical prostate cancer outcomes, there has been limited investigation into racial disparities of patient-centered outcomes specifically in patients with advanced prostate cancer, the population experiencing the highest morbidity and mortality both from the cancer itself and its associated therapies. The proposed research aims to use data from approximately 1500 patients in the International Registry for Men with Advanced Prostate Cancer (IRONMAN) to quantify racial disparities in treatment patterns, patient experience with the health care system, and quality of life in patients with advanced prostate cancer in the United States and United Kingdom. This work will provide novel information on the spectrum of care received by patients with advanced prostate cancer and propose potential areas for intervention by health care providers towards decreasing racial disparities in prostate cancer mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Ischemia-reperfusion injury causes early morbidity and mortality after lung transplantation for which there are currently no preventative therapies available. The objective of this proposal is to understand the cellular mechanisms responsible for lung ischemia-reperfusion injury and specifically how calcium uptake by TRPV4 channels contributes to ischemia-reperfusion injury and vascular inflammation. If successful, our studies will define TRPV4 as a novel and effective therapeutic target for the prevention of ischemia-reperfusion injury in lung transplant recipients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Single-cell genome sequencing has proven to be a valuable tool to advance our understanding of tumor initiation, evolution, and resistance by providing the ability to catalogue the genetic subclones present within a tumor. However, current methodologies to profile single-cell genomes are either underpowered and expensive, or require designer reagents that are inaccessible to most research groups. Here we will develop technologies that produce improved data quantity and quality at a reduced cost that target the three major applications of single-cell genomics in cancer biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Great Plains Rare Disease Summit held at Sanford Research in Sioux Falls, SD will be a dual scientific and community conference. The first day of the summit is devoted to current updates from clinicians and rare disease researchers. The second day of the summit is tailored to patient advocacy groups, patients, and caregivers. The goal of the summit is to foster new relationships between research and advocacy, while building a robust community of rare disease advocates across both spectrums.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This proposal is relevant to public health because it aims to understand the role of a key ER co- activator (MED1) and its crosstalk with Jab1 in HER2-driven breast tumorigenesis in the process of cancer growth, stem cell formation, metastasis and treatment resistance. Completion of the study is expected to not only broaden our knowledge base in these areas but will also provide potential new therapeutic agents for the treatment of human breast cancer. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the mission of NIH to conduct research for the prevention and cure of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health as cleft palate is the most common craniofacial congenital anomaly and cleft palate repair is associated with wound healing complications in up to 60% of patients, resulting in an oronasal fistula (ONF). ONF occurrence is associated with poor feeding and speech and typically requires multiple additional surgeries to repair. This proposal is relevant to the NIH's mission to develop innovative therapies and we propose an immunomodulatory strategy to improve oral cavity wound healing, reducing ONF formation, by attracting pro-regenerative monocytes and macrophages using FTY720 containing nanofiber delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute lower respiratory tract infection from Klebsiella pneumoniae is a common problem affecting hospitalized patients with higher mortality in the critically ill. The long term objective of this proposal is to elucidate how host metabolism drives host defense and resilience against this bacteria within the lung. Understanding host- pathogen interactions will lead to rational, targeted therapy design to improve clinical outcomes of Klebsiella pneumoniae infections in vulnerable patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative Breast cancer remains the second leading cause of cancer death and for many survivors, contributes to significant disease and treatment related physical and psychosocial side effects, medical costs and reduced quality of life. As such, primary prevention of breast cancer in women at increased risk with an agent that is safe and well tolerated is highly desirable. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), including aspirin, demonstrate anti-cancer activity in breast cancer models, with observational evidence that supports lower odds of breast cancer among regular users. We have found that the NSAID sulindac, after one year of use, significantly reduces breast density, an established risk factor for breast cancer, and changes the structure of collagen in breast tissue in women taking aromatase inhibitors for the treatment of their breast cancer when compared to a control group. We propose a clinical trial using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and tissue biopsy to test the effect of sulindac on breast density and breast tissue in women at increased risk of breast cancer and we will compare its activity on breast density and breast tissue to aspirin and a control group. Ours is the first evidence of an effect of an NSAID on breast density, an established risk factor for breast cancer. Furthering our understanding of this activity is important to advancing the beneficial actions of NSAIDs observed in epidemiologic and animal studies to primary breast cancer chemoprevention in patients at increased risk of developing breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Spinal cord injury (SCI) affects 1.3 million Americans. The proposed experiments in this application are relevant to public health because they seek to identify therapeutic strategies to either prevent or decrease the severity of multiple, potentially life-threatening effects of sympathetic dysregulation after SCI.
